Instead of the guitar and the singer intertwined in a mushed melody, they separate and complement each other. It is really amazing, I don't think some professionals realize the impact such headphones have on people who haven't tried the best. You know their worth, we don't.So if your holding off because your ears are not quiet what they used to be, don't. If anything, get them because of that. Everyone needs a bit of excellence in their lives to compensate. I think they taught me that I might not have lost as much as I thought.Is there a downside? Actually there is. I can now tell when something wasn't recorded correctly, it sounds awful. I don't how or why, but I can hear the messy result. Thankfully, only a few songs in my collection had to go. I can just imagine what professionals are hearing with their trained ears on that mess.You don't have to be a professional to enjoy these. They sound just as wonderful sitting on your head on your recliner.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: this is the best cans you can have under $100, period!! I have several cans vary from Bose, AT, Phillips, AKG, and Koss, yet this is one of the best sounds from my collections. No artificial bass or re-engineered sounds, just flat but you can appreciate what a headphone should be. The weakest point could be the cans is not comfortable for longer usage. I limit less than an hour and taking a break for awhile.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: What's not to like?  These headphones are the best I've tried.
review_body: Listening to my iTunes music collection with these Sony MDR7506 headphones, it's like my mp3's got a free upgrade to a higher bit rate. My other headphones (Audio-Technica ATHM40FS Precision Studio Headphones) sound somewhat flat, imprecise and washed-out in direct comparison.  The Sony headphones are superior, without question producing clearer and more accurate sound. The Sony's also weigh less on the head, resulting in less neck strain after hours of use, and they fit more comfortably but without sliding off. The Sony's have a coiled cord which is less likely to tangle or trip people.  The Sony headphones work great when plugged directly into my portable MP3 players (Sansa Clip and Coby models), do not require an adapter, and can be worn around the house because the cord is coiled and does not drag or tangle. The Audio-Technica is not practical for use with small portable devices because of the very long cord and need for a bulky adapter.  Over all, the Sony headphones sound better, fit better, work better and are well worth the extra cost as compared with cheaper products.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I'm working in a small home studio where I generally record no more than two musicians or singers at a time. I needed to purchase two pairs of headphones so that I could monitor the recordings while also allowing the musicians to hear themselves. After doing considerable research, I settled on these the Sony MDR7506 headphones.First, they're widely used in professional studios, so you know they're going to have good build quality. Second, they have a relatively flat frequency response. If you're looking for bass-heavy phones, something from Beats will probably make you happier. But in a studio, the flat response of these phones really works well.I also really like the coiled cable. I've had phones with both coiled and straight cables, and the coiled seem to be less of a hassle overall, especially when you've got a dozen other cables snaking around the room to mics and instruments.Being able to easily convert from a 1/4" jack to a 1/8" jack is a really great feature that's fairly common on headphones like these, and it's appreciated.Finally, the price is what really seals the deal. You can find better headphones, but they're going to cost a good deal more than these. Altogether, I think they're great for small studios or traveling musicians that need a solid set of phones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Excellent Audio Quality, Not the most comfortable
review_body: These headphones are excellent if you want to hear the music exactly as it was intended to be heard.  These are easily the best value as well.  You don't need to spend hundreds of dollars for top tier audio.  The only sacrifice is that I don't find them to be very comfortable.  The headband has very little padding and the earcups really clamp down causing hot spots.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Perfect sound. Not too bass heavy but capable of hitting that low range.  Was worried the cord would be too long but when it's not stretched the cord on only probably a little over 3 feet long.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I don't normally do a lot of product reviews, but had to put one out there for this product. These headphones are simply fantastic! Why?1) Sound quality: These things just sound great. Even for MP3's. I know you hear folks saying 'I heard things I never heard before when I listen to the same old songs' - well, in this case it is true! I really did hear more than I did with my previous pair, which were a pair of Acoustic Research Noise Cancelling over-the-ear headphones. Really pleased with the sound. I also use them for tv, streaming video,etc. and they sound just as great there. When you put them on, they by default mute sounds from the outside world, which of course helps as well.2) Comfort: I have worn these headphones for hours on end and can vouch for the fact that they are comfortable. The band is able to be adjusted, and the pads on the cups are very comfortable - Absolutely zero problems there.3) Quality: The quality of this product is rock solid. The expanders on the sides to let you adjust the sizing feels good and sturdy; you are not worried you are going to break them. The cord is very heavy duty. Definitely don't have to worry about that working itself loose or coming undone somehow. The joints where they fold (Yes you can fold them - they even come with a travel pouch) also feel ok.The one thing I will say is that these, would not be a good pair of earphones to go jogging in or other exercise type activities; The big cord and their size makes  them too bulky for that in my opinion.I have had these headphones for about a month and a half now, and couldn't be happier with them. I can honestly say these were money well spent!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These are some of my favorite headphones... They sound great and aren't bass heavy like many others are. They run a little hotter than many other headphones I have like my AKG's. Great quality at a great  price. These work better than many other headphones costing significantly more.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I've sat in many recording studios and mixed/mastered on a variety of speakers and using a variety of headphones for reference.  I'm not a "professional" but I've interned and later worked at a studio and had bands that recorded at different studios as well.  I've been able to get great results but sometimes lackluster results due to the variables envolved in any studio - equipment, room acoustics, placement, influences of others, etc.  With that background in mind, here's what I've found:  These headphones are revealing, and they are not "warm" or "full".  They have helped me to spot trouble areas in mixes that I've missed in the studio monitors, and to make the minute adjustments that bring balance to a mix.  They are clear without being overly "crisp", and the low end is detailed instead of trying to be "boomy" like so many consumer-grade units. In fact the entire range is detailed.  I've read of some folks wanting to break them in, but I've not had a need for that.  They were great right out of the box, and I hope they never change!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Workhorse headphones... provided you take care of them.
review_body: I work primarily as freelance radio producer and occasional DJ and am no stranger to Sony headphones.  Having babied a well-worn pair of Sony MDR-V700 headphones for the past decade for general studio/work use, I was in dire need of a new set of cans.The 7506 has a long reputation as a solid set of workhorse headphones with above-average sound quality.  I've seen them used in countless radio and recording studios time and time again for years now.  Having logged about 20 hours or so with them thus far, I can see what all the praise is about.The fit is comfortable for longer sessions and the earphones themselves, as mentioned elsewhere, can be driven quite loudly before any audible distortion kicks in.  I'd describe the overall sound quality as balanced: highs are sharp without a piercing quality, mids are present without any muddiness and the bass is punchy and warm without overpowering the rest of the spectrum.Mind you, this is only as good as your source material, but in playing back typical 16 or 24-bit WAV audio in the studio (as well as 320 MP3s and even some older vinyl) the 7506 has done well with each source so far.  No complaints.I'd say the only caveat with the 7506 is in its design.  They're NOT the sturdiest of headphones on the market in terms of build quality.  They're considerably lighter than others nowadays which adds to the comfort factor but can be an issue over time where durability is concerned.  They do fold up for transport but the wire to each earphone is exposed - another rarity compared to other current models - though said wires are held somewhat firmly in place.I'd say the key to getting the most out of these in the long run is to handle them somewhat delicately.  My older MDR-V700s were notorious for breaking at the hinges but having babied them for so long it's not terribly difficult to keep them usable with a bit of proper care.  These ship with a soft leather carrying pouch which should be adequate for carrying these around in most situations but a hard-shell or zippered vinyl case (Slappa, UDG, etc) wouldn't hurt to have on hand either.Overall, on sound quality alone and comfort alone, the 7506 is a must-have for anyone who spends a good chunk of their life living in headphones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great headphones with faithful sound reproduction
review_body: OVERALL: Great headphones with faithful sound reproduction. Cannot imagine there's a better value out there - was surprised to find that these industry standard phones are under $100. I 100% recommend these.I run sound at church and needed headphones that will faithfully reproduce the signal. An audio pro who does both studio and live work gave a clinic for our sound team and recommended these.I cannot be happier.Affordable, comfortable, perfect amount of noise cancelling, exceptional sound reproduction - what's not to love?I'm also a drummer and these work great for reducing the db assault on my ears during practice. I hook them up to my iPhone to listen to the click or songs I'm trying to learn. Everything sounds great. While the db from the drums is reduced it's not muffled in a way that interferes with practice. For example, I still know if my rim click sounds right or is slightly off.I love that the 1/4 adapter screws on and off so it won't accidentally get left behind when I pack up or switch jacks.The cord does not seem like it will tangle easily and I have not had any issues yet of it kinking up and don't anticipate that to be a problem.The 1/8 inch plug housing can interfere with connecting it to a phone depending on the case you have so you may have to modify your case (enlarge the hole that goes to your headphone jack), take the case off, or what I do is carry an extension cable.I do recommend buying a case for them.I can't imagine anyone regretting buying these especially for under $100.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: ... old pair of Technics headphones that felt and sounded great. Unfortunately the "leather" portions on the headband and ...
review_body: I had an old pair of Technics headphones that felt and sounded great. Unfortunately the "leather" portions on the headband and ears are flaking and look horrible so it came time for a new pair. I bought Sol Republic's but wasn't happy with its sound quality. After looking up headphones this Sony headphone had good reviews and are apparently used in many recording studios so I figured I'd give them a shot. I was blown away at how good the sound quality is on these. The Sol Republic sound like CRAP compared to these. I bought my GF a pair of limited edition Hello Kitty Beats by Dre and these destroy the Beats as well! For the price and quality sound these are hard to beat. I definitely recommend buying these.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I love these, I’ve had them for about 4 years and they’re just now starting to peel on the headphone area, but they work great.Music sounds fantastic, very rich and full of base but not too overpowered.For gaming they give fantastic directional accuracy.And they’re pretty cheap. I’d recommend these to anyone asking and I plan on buying another in the future.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I was a medical transcriptionist for 10 years, and I do closed captioning now.  These are by far the best headphones I've ever used (and I even tried a pair of those fancy $300 headphones.  Beats, or something?).  The sound on these is crisp and clear.  I bought my first pair a few years ago, and I'm only buying another pair now because I've worn out the cover over the ears and am finding little pieces of black material that have fallen off the headphones.  They still sound great. Would definitely recommend these.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These are great headphones. I've owned them for several years now, and very happy with them. The sound quality is fantastic. Everything from low bass to crisp highs are rendered accurately. They sounded a little harsh when they were new, but once they broke in the sound softened up and mellowed out. Now they sound sweet and smooth. I use them for everything. They are also light and very comfortable. The coil gives a long reach, while still staying short when that is preferred.I would recommend these to anyone.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I have a pair of these I got from I think Crutchfield back in 1998 and I broke those a few times and repaired them by buying some replacement parts and by making some parts, I even rewired it because the wire gor messed upI finally decided to replace them and after doing some research I decided to just get the same type since I loved mine so muchthe new ones look the exact same and they have the exact same box, my old ones said "Made in Japan" and the new ones say "Made in Thailand"they sound great and the dual tip is useful for travelingthere are better headphone manufactures out there but for this price these are the best deal by far if you arent looking for ultra portable
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Fairly comfortable, but sound was not to my preference.
review_body: These are widely regarded as some of the best headphones you can buy under 100, maybe even 200. I found them to be a little flat and harsh in the mid range for my preference. I also found the cable to be a bit ungainly if you're using this on the go or moving from room to room (like in an offfice). Overall comfort was surprisingly good for my big noggin.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: sound is really good. I replaced my broken Koss Porta Pros with ...
review_body: I'm impressed, sound is really good. I replaced my broken Koss Porta Pros with these and it was a good move. They're not quite as small/packable but they're very comfortable and better sounding. On Koss I always had the small metal pin, which is used to secure them when folded, cut into my ear after wearing them for a longer period of time.I also own AKG K7XX and Shure SRH840 and I'd place Sony's below them but I could easily only own Sony's over Shure's if I was on a budget and had to pick between the two.For people with a very narrow head and/or no hair - these are fairly low profile, flat, flush with the face and don't make you look obnoxious when worn in public :-) The other two mentioned above i.e. are quite the opposite :-)
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great sound initially, but beware the very short warranty
review_body: Despite its old design, the Sonys were initially very clear with a wide frequency range. The materials and workmanship are good, they are lightweight and reasonably comfortable, with soft but durable ear pads. They fold and are easily carried. However, the coiled cord is too long and not replaceable. Another negative is the short 90 day labor/1 year parts warranty, and the repair warranty is also only 90 days! In comparison, Audio-Technica and Sennheiser headphones feature a 2 year warranty. Even inexpensive Monoprice headphones include a 1 year warranty. After about 7 months of use, the left earcup developed a pronounced rattle and distortion from low frequency inputs. Gave them away to a local library.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Very good pair of headphone.Pros:Very good audio reproduction.Lightweight and comfortable design.Low leakage.Excellent headphones for the money.Cons:Not very good noise isolation.Some weak build quality  (But for the price they are not bad).Cable is not detachableProduct Description:  Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm HeadphoneLink:  https://www.amazon.com/dp/B000AJIF4E/ref=cm_cr_ryp_prd_ttl_sol_23
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great if you want a brighter pair of headphones.
review_body: Very bright headphones. Great for VO artists or vocalists.I had had many pairs of these in the studio over the years.Would not be my choice for everyday listening.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Try switching back to any other headphones after using these Sony's...
review_body: I intended to write a review after my purchase, as I am 100% pleased with my Sony MDR7506s.  In the past, I typically balked at paying for "expensive" headphones and went with the cheaper options.  But after annoying pain from earbuds or over-ear headphones, I was convinced that around-the-ear headphones would solve my discomfort.  And with these Sony headphones, I have absolutely no discomfort from extended periods of use (10+ hours).  No wonder you see them in recording studios and other professional settings.But what prompted my late review was being put in the unfortunately position of having to use a pair of my "old" (i.e. cheap) headphones yesterday.  It was distracted to try to listen to music while working, because of the huge difference in audio quality (coming out of the same computer, same playlist and same streaming service).  I have grown too accustomed to the quality you get with these (very reasonably priced) headphones.  And like clockwork, about 2-3 hours in my ears started to hurt and I had to take them off for an hour or two to let my ears rest.  Thankfully, I'm back with my MDR7506s today and it's business as usual.Don't fall for buying the newer or better promoted headphone brands... these Sony's may not come in a variety of flashy colors with shiny coating, but they are tried-and-true and I can attest that they are worth every penny!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I've been through several pairs of headphones to include Beats, Bose, Apple earphones and even Skullcandy but these have to be the best I've ever owned.For less than $100 (and a lot of fancy brands like Beats and Bose are more than that), these are honestly a steal.The only downside I would have about them would be the cord. It's long and bulky and sometimes it becomes a hassle to  deal with or untangle, but if that's the price of excellent sound quality and truly being able to enjoy my music with pristine quality, so be it.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Exceptionally clear highs and lows.  Really a very accurate sound all the way through.  Band over my head isn't uncomfortable after extended use.  Cups sit well though I wear glasses and that often causes a problem with how the over ear cups sit.  Padding gives enough the glasses temple didn't dig into my head.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: They sound really good without the bass drowning things out
review_body: I use my headphones for music production.  I had a pair of $300 Sennheisers (don't remember the model) that I loved but noticed that what I was hearing did not match the sound on my Bluetooth speakers or my car audio system.  The Sony headphones still sound good and the frequencies match with my other devices.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: I brought one pair and had to get another.
review_body: I got this home and plugged it into my Yamaha MOXF keyboard, IPAD, and IPHONE--WOW.  I own some audiophile quality stereo gear and did so I am very selective. After reading tons of favorable reviews, I purchase these headphones with some reservation in that they were so affordable yet so highly rated. They blew away my Sennheiser 380 HD Pro's which cost more than twice as much. They are so good, I brought another pair for my office. The best review I found was at thewirecutter.com site:http://thewirecutter.com/reviews/the-best-150-over-ear-headphones/
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Skeptical at first but just great
review_body: I was very skeptical at first due to the price , below 100 bucks , but I took my chances , I was very inclined to get the Bose Quiet Comfort 15 for $300 which sound great and are very comfortable .What a surprize when they came , beatifully packaged , I thought I had a jewel in my hands , instantly reminded me of Steve Jobs and how much thinking he puts in packaging .At first when I first tried they sounded kind of flat , but by reading the reviews I broken them in , just a few hours , maybe 6 hours , but I know I have to do it for approx. 40 hrs . Then I tried them again .........WOW what a sound out of my I Pad , then I tried them at my digital Sony amp ..........just brilliant .How come for just below $90 they can offer something like this ?I am much into sound and try everything I can at local stores and with friends , these cans are amazing , I am sure there are some better out there but for this price do not think twice , what an amazing piece of art , just fantastic !I am listening to them as I am writing this review and I feel like flying in the sky ....just incredible .You can't go wrong with these , I am going to say they sound as good as the expensive Boses. Needless to mention , extremelly comfortable .Great product Sony.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Everything as expected.  A great pair of headphones for the money
review_body: When you're the industry standard, you're going to get a lot of critical reviews as well as stellar reviews, but not much in between.  Personally, I love these headphones.  The dynamic range is great and they fit comfortably on my huge head.  I've tried a lot of headphones and I keep coming back to the Sony.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Excellent headphones for a very fair price
review_body: I bought these based on a recommendation from a web site that specializes in headphones and headphone amplifiers. Their advice has always been good and was again. These circumaural, closed headphones replaced Sennheiser HD580 (not HD-140 as originally reported) headphones  that were circumaural, open.This sound evaluation is from the point of view of a classical music listener. The response seems to be pretty much pure, even, and uncolored across the entire audible spectrum. I heard bass down to frequencies that, heard on loudspeakers, you would feel in your whole body, not just your ears. But no headphones can reproduce that effect. The sound seemed at first hearing to be very subtly different than on the old headphones, but the ear adjusts almost immediately to this.My impression is that these are not high-efficiency headphones. You can get adequate, but not impressive sound levels from a CD-player (I've tried two different ones) without a headphone amplifier. I have not tested the headphones with an iPod or iPhone, but I would guess that the amplifier would enhance the results with either of those, or similar, productsThey are very comfortable. After as much as three hours of continuous listening, still no discomfort at all over the head or the ears. The Sennheiser headband caused an itchy scalp after a few hours of use, which the Sony headphones apparently are not going to do.They appear to be constructed very solidly. They fold up quite easily with just a little practice, and seem small enough to be practical on an airplane flight. I have not yet tested whether these will shut out enough aircraft noise to be useful for classical music listening, or whether I will have to use my Etymotic earphones for that purpose. But the coiled cable would serve aircraft use well. (It also stretches enough [ten or more feet] that I can listen to Shostakovich's 11th Symphony [a good test for both highs, lows and dynamic range behavior] on my audio system to confirm the audio response as I write this.)I don't see how the last two attributes "Takes a beating" or "durable" can be rated until I have used them for several years. But externally, at least, these phones seem well and solidly made, and I don't plan to give them a beating. (The Sennheiser headphones these replaced failed internally after three years. And I thought they were good, too, also recommended by the same specialist site, but apparently no longer available. In comparison with those, these are more comfortable and don't collect lint and dust as the Sennheiser did.In short, I'm happy with them and consider them an improvement over what they replaced, and at a lower price to boot.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: These headphones are so amazingly comfortable that I sometimes forget I am wearing them
review_body: These headphones are so amazingly comfortable that I sometimes forget I am wearing them! They sound great, had a wide range, and respond very fast. They are worth every penny. I use them with my laptop while watching movies, or plug them into my amp when I am practicing my bass guitar. I have also used them on film sets to monitor audio.  I mainly use them to listen to Dubstep and Electronica and the bass is amazing.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Don't mess with a great thing
review_body: Sometimes older is better. I was looking for over-ear travelling phones (as I have grown tired of earbuds). I have used MDR-V6s in the studio for two decades and have always loved their clean, try, reasonably flat qualities. They are also comfortable. Sure, the cushion material eventually cracks and flakes, but they just keep sounding great.Anyway, as a love of Blue mics, I was holding out hope for the Mo-Fis, which I ordered within minutes of their availability and primptly returned because they are so heavy (see review). I continued my search for a short time before putting on the V6s, suddenly realizing that the answer for my travelling needs was already on my head. Shopping Amazon led me to discover that the MDR 7506 cans were about $15 cheaper (and are basically the same). So, I used the savings to buy a pair of the Beyerdynamic velour pads (much softer and cooler).They arrived about an hour ago and haven't left my ears since. The 7506s compare favorably with every set of headphones or earbuds I have ever used; Sennheiser, AKG, B&W, Etymotic, Shure, and now, Blue. They sound amazing with little or no coloring (I want my audio to sound like it was recorded). Pus, they are light enough to wear for hours (half the Mo-Fis), fold better than most over ear phones for traveling and they hold up. They are efficient enough that my iPhone and iPad drive them with plenty of leftover head room.Apparently, the proverbial "wheel" doesn't need to reinvented. Now, my V6s live in the studio and the 7506s travel in my bag.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: The best old school headphones for audiophiles!
review_body: Excellent headphones! I use these coupled with a portable headphone amp for gaming, youtube viewing, music listening, etc.. These have a very flat audiophile sound that's meant for the most accurate listening experience. That said, if you are someone who doesn't care for accuracy and who just wants that exaggerated bass sound then these will not be the headphones for you.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: The shipping was great and the package arrived brand new and never opened
review_body: Have been using this product for some years now since purchased from Amazon. One of the speakers stopped working, found out that there is a short in the cable. Other than that, the product done it's term and will probably be replaced by another headset soon. The shipping was great and the package arrived brand new and never opened. You would only expect this from USPS/UPS/FedEx and not the one that Amazon has been using for awhile now. Have heard a lot of weird and negative comments regarding the delivery server Amazon uses when they don't use those three main ones. The product was great while it lasted. Would probably purchase one with a sturdier wires compared to regular ones next time.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great sound quality... beware if you have glasses.
review_body: Wonderful sound (I'm used to $10 headphones) and it's nice to be able to turn these up loud enough to not hear anything going on around you.... only problem I have with them, and for me it's a big one, is glasses. Yes, because the headphones are so big and if you have glasses, the headphones squeeze your glasses into the side of your head. It's really painful and so I can only use these when I'm not wearing my glasses.Maybe I don't know how to adjust them, but I've tried and tried. They're so big and heavy they just hurt too much when I'm wearing glasses.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I bought these for my audio production class and they work great. There are a bit on the bright side, but don't lack bass -for under $80 they are an incredible deal. I also use them to listen to Pandora on my mobile and iTunes on my laptop and both sound amazing --there are songs I've never heard through headphones and therefore parts of them that I had been missing out on.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Best bang for the buck! I love these!
review_body: I really love these headphones! I work at my desk over 40 hours a week and have these on for over 30 of them. They are really comfortable and the long coiled cord prevents snags that would rip them off my head. I can even stand up and talk to my cubicle neighbor while leaving them on my neck.I also run Spotify Premium so I get a high quality stream and wanted headphones that would take advantage of that. These make music so much more enjoyable! Highs are very crisp, bass is low and strong but not overly so like Beats and the like. At low and at high volume, there is no distortion and the ear cuffs do a pretty good job at reducing ambient noise. They also look very unassuming which I like. I don't like the headphones that are a really bad fashion statement.While I have worn better sounding and more comfortable headphones, they have all cost more than $200. Maybe if I worked at a record label instead of a tech company I could justify it but I really care about best bang for the buck and not paying a premium for incremental improvements.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: So far, so good. I needed a headset that wasn't too tinny or heavy on the base. I have tinnitus and a issue with sound sensitivity and these work perfectly for me. I don't get the sharp stabbing pain in my ears when listening to higher pitched female vocalists or some of the harder Metal music that I enjoy. They have a very natural sound. It was very surprising.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I have purchased and used Sony headphones for at least the past 20+ years, I have listened to other premium brands at various stores  during that time and found little to no difference between them and the Sony 7506. I find the 7506 to be well balanced (good to excellent bass, mid ranges and highs) and of good manufacturing quality. I just recently learned that ear pad replacements were available through Amazon and purchased a pair to replace the ones on my now older 7506 (which I gave to my wife to use on her computer and Kindle Fire). If I had any complaints it would be that the coiled cord stretches significantly over a relatively short period of time leaving you with a goodly length of loosely coiled (and sometimes tangled) cord to deal with. The ear pads are good to excellent in keeping out ambient noise and I can wear the headphones for long periods of time with little to no discomfort whatsoever. I would heartily recommend the 7506 to any one shopping for quality headphones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Finally, a worthy replacement for my old MDR-V700
review_body: I've been looking for a MDR-V700 replacement for a while now and glad to have stumbled onto the MDR7506.  I've tried many with really really disappointing results.I would say these sound a bit mellower than my old reference V700 with same really deep bass and smooth mid-range and treble.  It might have something to do with the heavy duty use my V700's has gotten over the last 15+ YEARS.  Overall the MDR7506 is a great sounding headphone that is extremely neutral and is good enough to mix with as well as field/DJ work like the V700's.  The build, however, does not seem as solid as the V700 nor has any styling cues.  It's a much lighter, simpler design (eg, the cable feed to the right side is curiously exposed and can get snagged where the V700's are hidden).If you're looking for a flat wide band headphone with very low distortion and nice smooth transient response, give these a listen.  After my Martin Logan Monoliths main speakers, these come pretty close and can be had for a bargain.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Purchased the MDR-V6 about 7 years ago. Loved them and bought these for my brother. They are identical to the MDR-V6 and he fell in love with them too after listening to mine for a few days.These headphones are for monitoring thus they have an exceptionally flat/neutral sound to them. This is something I love. You will hear imperfections and minute sounds that are hard to hear on headphones that "color" the sound (be it with bass or treble). But these just play whatever you give them.Excellent presentation with the red satin. They also seem to last forever
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I love these headphones for the approximate year I used them as my first professional-grade studio monitors. Their accuracy, clarity, detail, and well-represented spectrum of sound always impressed me. Even better, it would be hard for me to imagine a more comfortable pair of headphones than the 7506's, I could wear them for hours on end and completely forget I was wearing them. However, after about one year of VERY gentle use, one ear pad has ripped at a seam and detached itself from the unit, and the other ear pad is starting to go the same route. I read somewhere the ear pads are replaceable for ~$10, but honestly, I don't want to keep funding a pair of headphones that I have to keep repairing as frequently as once a year. For that reason alone, I've migrated to a pair of KRK 8400's and won't look back. They're nearly as comfortable, but even more detailed and refined than the 7506's, and seem significantly more durably built as well. Check my review on that product page if interested. The 7506's will always be the pair of headphones that introduced me into accurate/pro-level reference monitoring which gives them my respect, but quality of workmanship is key to loyalty. Sorry Sony.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I will not do a 5000 word review on $100 headphones, or an audiophile "let me tell you how smart I am" dissertation either. Sound is purely subjective. I like em or I don't.I bought these after getting the Sennheiser HD 480 Pro. I connected both to a Touch at 80% volume for 31 hours straight. The HD 480's always needed near full volume (love the low end) but that muffled effect didn't go away. The 7506's were clean and crisp, perhaps a little too bright, bass is tight and NOT boomy. The 2 side by side; Sony is my preference, although bright the overall sound is more pleasing and comfortable to wear.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I purchased these headphone on the recommendation of a co-worker. He's a video editor and sound is important to him. I'm am continually impressed with the sound quality and comfort of these headphones. On a typical day I will wear the for close to 6 hours and they don't hurt my ears or the top of my head. An added bonus, they do a great job of eliminating background noise of the office to really help my concentrate.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Classic - but that's a good thing!  Reliable studio headphones from a product family with a long history of success.
review_body: I've had a lot of good success with Sony's "Digital" MDR-V6 headphones and wanted a pair of headphones for doing studio AV editing.  Given the more flat (or is it?  I guess that's for debate) response of the 7506 I decided to spend a few dollars more.  They didn't disappoint - sound great, feel great, and I expect they will last me for years.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Very good sound & worth the money
review_body: The headphones are comfortable and fold up to fit nicely in a small pocket of my backpack.  I sometimes get static when I move around with the headphones on.  This may be caused by the headphone plug rotating slightly in the jack of the iPad.  It's hard to tell.  The length of the cord is just right.  The amount of coiled cord and straight cord seems to work well for me.  I use them quite a bit in a Barnes & Noble cafe which can get noisy at times.  Since these are an over the ear design, they isolate me just enough to let me concentrate on the videos I am watching.  I can still hear some ambient sound but these are not meant to be noise cancelling or for total isolation of sound.  Overall, they seem very rugged and well worth the price.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Best sounding headphones I've ever owned
review_body: Best sounding headphones I've ever owned. Well-built. The cord is a bit obnoxious, but I don't know how I would better solve the situation. It's just really long, yet at the same time stretchy due to the spiral construction that you would see on old telephones. Anyway, I use these for recording, mixing, mastering music. My main instrument is a Korg M50. Lots of different sounds over a large range of bandwidths, these headphones played them all well. Decent noise-cancellation too.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great sound, definitely different from the MDR-V6's
review_body: I was used to my MDR-V6's.  But after years they were starting to wear out.  I purchased these headphones as way to find a flatter response for mixing music production with headphones.  I found these phones to have less high frequency response than the MDR-V6's.  When working on the MDR's I found myself turning down the highs too much.  But with these, I found myself turning the high frequencies up too much.These headphones do give you a wonderful clear sound that lets you pick out delicate sounds in the mix.  But I found myself over compensating for the flatter response by boosting high freqs too much.  Switching back to my MDR-V6 headphones I had to lower the highs, sometimes too much.  Don't get me wrong, these are great headphones.  You just have to be aware that some of you may find the high frequency response to low.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great sound, great price, no frills
review_body: I've had these headphones for a few months now and I get it.  I get why these are the little secret that only those that know, know.  They're absolutely perfect sounding.  There's not a set of headphones I've ever put on that have the detail in sound that these do.  They're FLAT - and that's a very good thing.If you want to alter your music from the way it was intended, use an equalizer, and/or over pay for a pair of Beats.  If you want the audio coming through raw, unfiltered, and pure, these are the only headphones you need.These headphones have been around for 30+ years because quality is timeless.  I don't even like most Sony products because they're typically overpriced and buggy - and there's the whole unforgivable Sony BMG Rootkit Scandal of 2005 (http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sony_BMG_copy_protection_rootkit_scandal).  But I'll make an exception for the exceptional - I could care less who makes them.  These are it.I contend that the ultimate status symbol is being seen as someone that understands quality.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Hear it like the artist heard it.
review_body: These are all about flat, natural sound reproduction. No boosted bass, or enhanced anything. To my ears, these are near perfect. I could pick nits, and say they are a little tight after a couple hours, but most people won’t have them on that long. You should also know the outside world will disappear when you have them on. So, if your significant other is talking, you won’t hear them. Overall, I love these headphones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: It’s not even close to what you see in the product description. Low quality material.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Stunningly clear sound and at an amazing value.  What's not to like about these universally highly-regarded headphones.Well, it would be nice if they had a replaceable cable, and that way you could choose a length to suit and whether it was coiled or straight, but other than that quibble, they sound great and are comfortable to wear, and surely that's the main thing to keep in mind.I have several other pairs of headphones, costing many times more than these, but the stunningly clear precise sound from the MDR 7506 draws me back to them, time after time.My thanks to Sony for not selling them for $500, even though they probably could.  An amazing bargain.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: They are popular for a reason...
review_body: This is my third pair in over 10 years. These ones sound similar to my older ones. They give you the sound that is in the mix; do not expect something that will transform your music. If it sounds bad, they will tell you. They are flat-sounding, so their sound is honest. But you can use them to enjoy music, too. They can deliver solid sub-bass, clean-sounding mids and crisp highs. They will make your speakers or monitors sound "bad", because they are very revealing. Do not compare them to anything else, regardless of price range. Their sound is a standard in Hollywood for a reason. Professionals use them for critical stuff. I like them so much I've been mixing with them for years, instead of using my monitors. My brain is used to these headphones and anything else sounds coloured or "fake" to me. These are "in your face" (well, ear) sounding. You could say they are worth more than what you pay. The long cord is a blessing, even if it tangles sometimes.  The only bad thing is that they make your ears hurt after wearing them for extended periods, but they do not fatigue your hearing. I still recommend resting after mixing for a while to allow your ears to return to baseline. Get them, even if you have $10,000 headphones. It doesn't matter. They are a useful tool, not gimmicks. You will like them.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Perfect fit,  acoustics are wonderful, comfortable to wear, love the coiled cord which stretches across  the performance area, BTW this is my second purchase of the Sony MDR7506 Professional Headphones. I bought my first pair I'd say some 20 years ago! I had to buy the second set as a 2017 Christmas present to myself.  Because my rambunctious cat bit right through the cord. and I actually believe the replacement headphones cost nearly $50.00 LESS then the original pair I bought. same professional quality!!!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: they are the best head phones i have ever had..the sound is so clear..i was listening to billy joel all day..out standing sound..im a pro drummer and i have to here all the sounds and beats..and they sure come out..they are a little bit pricey but well worth the extra money..if you want grate sound and bass..they are the ones for you..sit back listen to the music drink a cold beer and do a bone...(;~!)))
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Got these as a back up for my Sennheiser 280 pro HD's for recording.  I ended up using these mainly for listening to music after replacing the ear pads on the Sennheiser's which I perfer more for recording music.  These are nice and compact compared to those though.Definitely not as harsh sounding as people make them out to be.  They need to be broken in though, because out of the box they do sound shrill on the high end without much bass.  After about 10-20 hours I was pretty impressed, especially for the price.  Really easy to drive too, which is a bonus.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: The only problem with these headphones is that they make the limitations of most compressed MP3 files clear.  I'm no longer willing to use my older MP3 players, and even my Android smartphone no longer seems attractive. On the other side, listening to native CD's and loss-less audio through a state of the art DAC and amp is breathtaking. Music never sounded so good.  It makes the limitations of the recording decisions made in the studio very clear - for example many of Clapton's recordings are mediocre, while Knopfler, some Neil Young and others are just incredible.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Listen to music the way the artist intended it
review_body: Since these are likely the exact headphones that were used to mix the music, you will hear it the exact way it was intended. These really are the best most crisp, clear and balanced headphones on the market. They have been an industry standard for producers for years. I have tried others, but always come back to these.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Classics never go out of style
review_body: Bought for my teenager as a holiday gift.  She wears them for hours a day and loves them.  She listens to a wide range of music including classical and jazz, and she praises these headphones above some of the other, more popular "rap artist" headphones because they are more balanced and accurate.  From my perspective, they seem fairly sturdy and they are priced quite reasonably when compared to the "more popular" headphones that seem to appeal to the eyes more than the ears.  Sony has made this model for a long time, and they stay in production for a reason.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Disappointing :( I do not know why these headphones have such amazing reviews. I am coming from a pair of (entry level) Sennheiser HD 205. The HD205's are not bad, but I had listed to some other great headphones and wanted something "next level" for Christmas. What I really wanted were the Sennheiser Momentum but I could not afford those. Based on reviews, these seemed the best in the sub $100 range and they were on for a good price on Amazon.TL;DR: These are good earphones but not great. Everybody carries on about how they are as good as a pair of $200 cans but in my experience they are in the same league as my DH205's and only ever so slighly better. I vastly prefer some more high end cans.PROS: Clear sound. Not muddied at all. Very good noise isolation.CONS: Treble is way too hissy and sibbilant. I need to turn volume down on high treble tracks. Uncomfortable ear cups (maybe because I have big ears? After 20 mintues I really wish I could move these things or take them off).In the end they are actually quite good. I mean the sound is good. But it is "just" good, not great. Maybe with a proper amplified driver or high end Hi-Fi system they would be as amazing as people say (I am just using my phone) but I can't help but feel let down based on all the stellar reviews.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I was debating Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone vs Sennheiser HD-555 Audiophile Headphones because at the time (November 2009) they were priced within 20-30 dollars of each other. In the end I ended up buying both. I can honestly say I love both for different reasons. I would say the sound quality of the MDR7506 is amazing. While the same is true for the Sennheiser  headphones in the treble range, in the bass range a lot of instrument timbre is somewhat lost. Which is not to say that the level of bass output is low, because the bass can get pretty loud, but the ability to tell what instrument is producing a very bass note is kind of lost. The reason I love the Sennheiser headphones is that they are extremely comfortable! After using the sony headphones for more than a few hours my ears start to get kind of sore, however the Sennheiser headphones remain comfortable after 4+ hours of straight listening. As far as durability go, the sennheiser headphones seem like they can take more abuse than the MDR7506 based on the fact that the MDR7506s have more moving parts and exposed wiring. Because of this fact, I actually ended up later buying a second pair of MDR7506's in case the first break.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: The Sony MDR7506 genuinely surprised me. If you don't want to read the rest of the review the takeaway is that these are some of the best headphones for the price. I own a pair of Grado se325's (which is my personal favorite) and the MDR's certainly measure up. For a third of the price these headphones provide great audio, even throughout the high and low frequencies. From the image of the headphones I thought they would look clunky and unattractive, but in fact they are lightweight and slim (I could wear them for a few hours before I need to take a break). I wish I could add another half star to the rating because these headphones barely missed the 5 star mark. My only complaint about these headphones is simply that they lack a certain brightness, and tend to be weaker than some high end headphones on the high notes. That said, they are a great buy, and easily beat out headphones twice the price.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Excellent headphones for the price, super comfy and great sounding.
review_body: I needed a pair of reliable headphones for my studio work. After doing a lot of research, I decided on these and am so glad I did. These have crisp, clear mid-range sounds, perfect for vocal work. They are light, too, a huge help when you've got them on for hours during recording/editing. Most importantly to me, aside from all of the above? If you wear glasses, you'll love these. They cup the ear perfectly, but the cushion is soft and doesn't drive your glasses into your head, nor do they make your ears feel like they're on fire.These are a solid pair of headphones that I know will get many hours of use in the years to come.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Found these after doing some research to find a good pair of headphones. I had recently purchased a different pair of headphones and was very unhappy with them. I wanted some that were not only great quality but comfortable too. When I got these and tried them, I could tell a huge difference. These are SUPER COMFY & AMAZING QUALITY! The audio sounds amazing. I couldn't be happier with this purchase.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I like the headphones, but I prefer the smaller ones.  Don't like the big headphones cause they don't fit my ears very well.  The sound is clear and precise.  So, the headphones are really good however, because I tend to prefer the smaller headphones over the larger ones.  Is the reason why I gave it only three stars.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These headphones are amazing!!  I purchased them because I do transcription at home and the noise in the room was distracting me.  I wanted a good pair of sound cancelling headphones and boy did I find that with these!!  I do want to note that I had to adjust the volume setting on my computer in the Control panel under sound.  At first there was no sound coming out of them but it was definitely an easy fix!.  These have increased my productivity and I would recommend these to anyone looking to an excellent, professional pair of sound cancelling headphones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: (Out of box) Just got them several hours before the due delivery date...
review_body: Sweet Lord in Heaven, these are incredible! I'm hearing sounds I didn't think were possible to hear. Glad to know I'm not deaf. My older headphones made me think I was.I usually don't leave five star reviews on items since I'm extremely nit-picky, but I could not find any problems. Their sound is amazing and they are comfortable as hell. They're not squeezing my ears and there's no fuzzy cushions making my ears itch.I can't say if I'll be happy with these down the road since I've only had them for just today. The only problem I came across with them was a high-frequency buzzing noise similar to the one you hear plugging in a speaker system halfway. I found out it was a problem on my end. I fixed the issue by making sure my computer battery was plugged all the way into the socket.I will leave a year's use review when it comes time on how I feel about these guys. In the meantime, they have become my new best friend.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Thoughts from a current M50X user
review_body: Right. This model is such a legend that I think I don't need to address here anymore. There is only one information I want to inform you: this batch I got is made in Thailand. Not like the earlier ones that are made in China, even in Japan. Some rumors suggested that the sound quality ranking goes by Japan, China, and then Thailand. Since I had only ONE CHANCE to listen to the Made-in-China model, I can only tell you that I failed to tell  any difference. It's the same good old flavor, in my perspective. As a current ATH M50X user, I think both these models produce phenomenal sound for both producers and casual users. If you are thinking about getting one of these, I can only tell you that the M50X is more sturdy and has a slightly more bass, but the 7506 got a more "natural" flavor, and the comfort is better. In conclusion, you can't go wrong with either one.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: The review I read said, "You buy these headphones once - and for life.".
review_body: Remarkable sound reproduction at a very reasonable price.  I purchased after an extensive review on an "underground" TV show available to TiVo subscribers - for computer geeks, basically - and found out that these Sony headphones are ubiquitous in recording studios across the globe and that bands and radio DJ's love them because they not only sound good but take a beating over time and just keep working.  THAT'S FOR ME.  And, I play a Roland electric keyboard so now my poor wife can go on about her life without me driving her half crazy.  Another benefit to me - piano is one of "the" most dynamically difficult instruments to sonically recreate and the Sony MDR7506 Pro headphone seems to "breathe easy" up to a reasonably loud level with absolute clarity and no distortion.I assume that the $300 and $400 (and up) headphones will, in fact, get louder before they begin to distort - but I don't need screaming loud.  I want and need complete tonal accuracy - deep bass - delicate treble highs - up to a reasonably loud level.  Thank you Sony for keeping this product in your line for so many years - UNCHANGED.  Fantastic product - arrived (as always) as promised - nicely packaged.  Could not be more pleased.  Am in no way affiliated with Sony or Amazon - just a happy customer.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Even better than expected.  The vocals are much clearer than my other headphones.  These headphones play all types of music well, although some may prefer exaggerated bass.  This pair of headphones brought me to the realization that my USB sound dongle distorts bass like crazy, even when using the pair of headphones it shipped with.Compared to my gaming headset, the fit is firmer.  The gaming headset doesn't attempt to fold it's earmuffs into each other to save space.  I preferred the looser grip of the headset.  During intense gaming, I found I don't really care how good the music sounds.  I prefer the gaming headset for the inline volume control and less sharp sound so I can focus on the game better.  Not a con against this pair of headphones, just personal preference.Update: As mentioned by other reviewers, the ear pads will start to peel after a while.  Mine lasted 1.75 years before peeling.  The chord becomes a bit cumbersome too if you are using it with a phone / media player in your pocket.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great for computers, not so good for phones.
review_body: The title of my review pretty well sums it up. Immediately upon receiving these headphones I plugged them into my iPhone. I was less than thrilled to discover that no sound was coming from them. When I jiggled the jack, I could get sound, but only if I held the cord really straight. After that, I plugged them right into my computer, to which I had no problems. I planned on using these cans for my computer anyway, but it would have been nice to be able to plug them into my phone as well.As for the actual sound, it's about what you'd expect at this price range. If you're a serious audiophile, you should probably be looking at a more expensive set of cans. To the average music listener, or the the people looking to use these for home recording and production, they sound wonderful.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: You can wear them all day with glasses
review_body: Other people who haven't spent years in engineering spaces can regale you with stories of these headphones audio fidelity and so forth, but here's what's important to me:  I can wear them all day at the office, and I don't have hotspots under my glasses' earpieces, even after eight hours of wear.  It's unusual these days to find a fairly inexpensive - comparatively speaking - pair of over the ear headphones that can accomplish this simple task.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: So LUCKY I got these headphones at such a great price!  I will guard them!!
review_body: I just received on time a week ago my Sony Studio headphones and I love the clarity for my at home Studio voice over work. I have done a lot research, checked around, listened and compared, asked folks and I found exactly what I needed with these headphones.  Very comfortable and they do fit over my ears just fine.  Beautiful sound quality. Like having an orchestra in your ears!  The crispness of sound is wonderful!  I received them in perfect condition and they are worth every penny and more actually.  I will also say that I compared the sound quality with the Shure model SRH240a and the slight difference is more of a matter of preference. I almost want to keep both but for my work but will keep this model and the Shure as my back up especially since I was somehow lucky enough to get both for roughly the same price. ($65) This model is commonly higher in price than the Shure model mentioned.  Thank you to my vendor who had the last one!!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I don't use them that much, but so far they seem pretty good. WAY better than my old blue tooth ones. They seem fairly comfortable and as with every headphone I have had they aren't very comfortable when wearing glasses. I can get a hour or two before they get to uncomfortable.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Not Much To Say That Hasn't Already Been Said: These are Unbeatable
review_body: This headset has stood the test of time. They sound great, feel great, and are built great. Not much to say that hasn't already been said.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: So far they have been very comfortable, and reproduce sound very well
review_body: The bass is not what I imagined it to be, but I wear these both for listening to music and monitoring my electronic keyboard playing.  So far they have been very comfortable, and reproduce sound very well.  I like the long coiled chord, the neat way the ¼" and ½" plugs are designed and their weight.Are they worth $80-$100?I don't think so but I'm overall quite pleased with them thus far.I'll update as I get more mileage under them.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: The sound on these Sony headphones is just incredible. We bought them to use with podcasting but because they have both size tips included and we love the sound so much we now use them to listen to pretty much everything when we're in the office. I even use them to listen to music and podcasts from my phone instead of the terrible sounding and uncomfortable earbuds that came with it. The difference is really unbelievable. From what I've heard and read the sound is as good as models costing many times as much and I sure can believe that - any improvement from these will be hard to achieve as these are already so amazing. Highly recommended!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Best Sounding Speakers in the House
review_body: Absolutely the best sounding speakers (of any kind) in the house.  And we have a lot of speakers.  But these headphones have the best total sound quality, character, and articulation of the full range from deep bass to the tinkle of a triangle.  I also have a pair of the MDR1000x, which are wonderful for a noise-canceling headphone, but still not quite up to the same audio quality as the MDR7506, despite being 4x the price.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: good sound, gives music clear definition, very pleased
review_body: Enjoying these very much.  Made me appreciate music all over again.  Would love to get this soundstage and quality on long lasting blue tooth.  All things considered very reasonably priced.  Lightweight and comfortable. Ear cups almost flat enough to sleep with ear against the pillow. Ear cups somewhat flip-floppy which leads you to wonder if they are durable enough.  But, so far these provide the best listening experience in the house.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Beautiful reproduction for playing back voice recordings
review_body: Beautiful reproduction for playing back voice recordings.  While I'm not a professional, I've always been impressed with my Bose QC-17, but the bass is too strong in those.  Much more natural with the Sony MDR7506.PS, the packaging is utterly absurd and should be updated one of these days, haha. Comes in a clear case with a silky fabric liner.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I purchased these for my daughter after I bought her Beats, that she had to have like every other teenager,  that fell apart six months after purchasing them. What a pain in the rear to get a warranty issue handled. I got tired of dealing with them so I just bought some new ones at half the price. Sound quality is far superior to the beats and the quality, well what can I say, if you hold the beats in one hand and these in the other you can feel the weight difference. They are a little heavier but the parts can be replaced easily. I will NEVER buy another pair of beats again. I just ordered another pair for myself because I loved them so much.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Great headphones!Love the sound, love the fit, love how long the chord is, love everything about them!(Also the fact that they came in a gorgeous silk package, AND with a carrying bag!)I used to have some old skullcandy headphones like this, but I highly recommend these for great quality!Of course I can always use more bass, but these are still really nice :)
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Great reference headphone. For all the reasons we seek out NS10 monitors, we use these and make sure to have them in the arsenal. Sony is horrible except for this one product. I almost deducted a star because they've eliminated the leather pouch. Watch it Sony, thin ice. Better not change anything else.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I bought these, as I needed a pair of closed over ear headphones. I have a pair of Grado SR125's that sound great, but everyone else hears them, too.  I purchased these because I have used this model of headphone many times in studio and live mixing environments, and have always been pleased with the sound reproduction. I would not argue that these have a perfectly flat response curve from 20hz-20khz, but they are decently so.  The high's tend to roll off a little bit, but not too much, and the bass can definitely have some added punch. I find them very pleasant to listen to.  Like most over the ear headphones, these can get tiring to wear, as they have a fairly tight clamping force.  I am use to that though, and these are a little less fatiguing than my Grado pair.I've never had quality issues with the pairs I've used in the past, and I am hoping that is true with these.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: but not enough to effect how I like them. Headphones fold up nicely to fit in ...
review_body: Arrived neatly in package with all pieces. I am a student of digital video and sound design and use these quite a bit while editing. The sound from these headphones is very clear and natural. Wearing too long is slightly uncomfortable to the tops of the ears, but not enough to effect how I like them. Headphones fold up nicely to fit in the small drawstring sack which keeps them safe in my camera/laptop backpack. Recommend for anyone needing quality headphones for sound editing or to anyone who doesn't like the increased bass, noise cancelation or other modifiers that come with headphones like Beats by Dre, Skull Candy etc.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: They are as good as everyone says. I have mine modded with the Beyerdynamic EDT 250 velour ear cups, and a nice amp on them, and they are heaven.Even with the stock ear pieces though, these are extremely comfortable headphones too. And I was surprised that they look much nicer in real life. Very attractive with the thick velour cups and speaker foam gone.If you want reference level fidelity and strong isolation from outside sounds, look no further.They are also extremely efficient and sound great just off my S4 phone or tablet.Great headphones! Enjoying them on an audiophile headphone amp with good specs but looking forward to building them a nice tube amp.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Outstanding headphones - light, comfortable, nice step up from previous sets
review_body: I have had several Sony headphones.I like Sony - clear sound, not punchy, and has great high frequency response.My sons have co-opted my MDR V6 for their Xbox, so I had a dilemna - get more of the ones I had or try some newer model.I am glad I tried these - they are very light weight, come with a heavy duty cord that has plenty of length, and is much better at isolating external noise.  For music (of any type) they are truly beautiful.  The light weight makes them comfortable.  I wear them, frequently, in the office (which has a full server rack in it) just to cut the fan noise.  When I do play music, or training files, they delivery crisp response with natural sound.  For the price, I think these are a bargain.Highly recommended.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: After using these for a few months now, they sound great and have been holding up very well.  I love the sound quality from these headphones as there is really no processing going on within the device.  You are going to hear the material you are listening to as it was meant to be heard.  No extra bass or sound processing.  These are the industry standard for a reason!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Okay I just received the headset few days ago and I might say the "packaging" is rather "MEH" the flop was like open and the box specially the gold print on it got scratches on it I was hesitant to open it but I did and with those aside I thought the headset I got are the fake ones or imitations but it is not so I was glad.With that aside here's the review of the headset:4.5/5 - Sound Because it sounds really good on acoustic(s) but not so much on songs with beats but it does pack a punch but not as much as beats and my gaming headset.4/5 - Aesthetics it looks great I thought it will be bigger on my head but when I put it on it just looks great I feel that I can wear it outside without looking st*pid or ridiculous.5/5 - Price it is really not that expensive because I got it on sale and it's a good deal.I will recommend this on my friends/family I'm not really a fan of long reviews because there's a lot in here already but all of them are pretty much accurate.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These headphones are definitely the successor to the old faithful Sony MDR-V6.  Those who assume the MDR-V600's are the successor are definitely making a mistake if they go that route.The only difference between the MDR-V6 and the MDR-7506 is the frequency response spec.  The V6 range was claimed to be 5Hz - 30kHz.  The range of the 7506 is listed as 10Hz - 20kHz.  However, since the human ear cannot hear sounds below 27Hz nor above about 18kHz, this difference is moot.The MDR-V6 and this successor, the MDR-7506, are easily the best headphones I've ever used (and I've used many), and they are both the professional standard by which all others are measured, especially when considering the price.  If you're looking for headphones, don't hesitate to buy these.  You will not be disappointed in the least.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Being in radio for over 21 years plus voiceover work for much of that, these have been and are still...my go-to headphones of choice. The Sony MDR7506's are awesome and I find give a good overall sound. I have 2 other ones around the house and studio. Which, I just realized, they now make replacement ear "muffs" for them. So I can fix my other two. But if you need new ones, you just need to get them. And not worry about whether the wife will be happy or not. Say you need them for work. Bonus:  you get to write them off if you're in "the biz".
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: The sound quality of these guys are ridiculous.  I have a ton of headphones, these are the best I've ever used.  They are a bargain at the current price.  These are super comfortable, but for people with big ears, the cup may pinch the outer portions of your ears.  My only wish was that the cord was replaceable.  My wife likes to use these when she works out, so a shorter cord would have been ideal for those times.  Hope this helps!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I used to own a pair of Sony headphones many years ago and kept it for years. Since then I've tried so many headphones. I found Sony is still the best for me. Sound quality is good for practice and rehearsals. I can wear them for hours without feeling any discomfort. Chord length is perfect -- no extension needed.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Does It Get Any Better Than This?
review_body: I've had these for only a few hours use.  I don't know what other people are talking about for a break-in period because these headphones sound fine across the audible range right out of the box.  These headphones reveal detail that other headphones just don't.  The sound is realistic with excellent imaging. I listen primarily to classical music and these Sony 7506's maximize the quality of the recording coming as close to a live performance of almost any set of speakers or headphones that I've ever owned. The only headphones that come close are Sony's 700 DJ Headphones with deeper bass and greater sensitivity.  My only reservation about the 700 DJ Headphones is durability.  The Sony 7506's might also be a tad more realistic in sound.  To me the 7506's are reference for sound.  So I have to ask "Does It Get Any Better Than This?"EDIT: I've been blowing Sony's horn pretty loud and you know what?  I'm going to blow it a little louder.  I have now since obtained the Sennheiser Pro HD 280's and Sony has nothing to worry about.  See my review of this product for more information on Amazon.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Wanted to love them, but sadly incompatible with elf ears
review_body: I've been searching for an over-ear headphone that covers my ears entirely for years, but sadly the search must continue. I don't have large ears mind you (unlike my head), just apparently odd shaped ones. Comfort wise these actually have a pretty light grip, nothing like you find in the M40/M50s or VModa products. The build quality was solid right out of the box. The sound is neutral but that is what I prefer. Sadly the ear thing just didn't work for me. My ears are super sensitive to touch and having the headphone pressure rest on them makes it uncomfortable after about 15 minutes of listening. But I can't blame Sony for that, just my parents.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great buy for the money. Great quality and sound quality.
review_body: I am really happy with these. I did some research and determined, for the price, this was the best way to go. I am really happy with the purchase. The sound quality is great and I don't get a lot of outside noise will listening with them.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: This is the first pair of headphones over $50 I've ever spent money on. Worth every penny. This is the all purpose headphone. Whether it's music, audiobooks, it's been a rock solid set. I also use them for studio monitor headphones, again, well worth the price. If you want a pair of headphones that covers all your bases, this is it.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great for keeping sound where you want it.
review_body: I gave these to my girlfriend as a gift.  She likes to watch TV on her iPad while i read next to her.  She can turn them up to the volume she likes (uncomfortably loud for me when she is not wearing them) and it does not bother me at all, I cannot hear any sound coming out of them even when I'm quietly reading next to her.As for using them, I have tried them a few times while watching videos and it does a great job of canceling any outside noise.  Even when people are talking and making moderate noise around me, I can listen to a video with long silent pauses and not be disturbed.  However, if people are shouting loudly around me, I can hear them though it is still muffled.Neither of us use them to listen to music so I couldn't really say if the quality is great for that, but the audio and music I hear when watching videos is fantastic.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: After reading so many reviews I decided to get a set. To be honest, I'm disappointed. The mechanical design and construction are excellent. These are obviously quality headphones. I just don't care for the frequency response. I am used to the AKG K240 series which has a very smooth, flat frequency response. The highs and mid-lows on the Sonys sound very exaggerated to my ears. Maybe OK for listening to some types of music but not what I want for mixing or critical listening,
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These headphones are solid, but become better with after market cushions.WARNING: these headphones really show off high frequency sounds, this is very good if you want to spot hisses and problems during sound editing, but will sound harsher than other options when just listening to music.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Best headset I've owned in terms of comfort and durability. (It's been working great for a year now.)The fit of this headset is amazing. The over ear padding on these are the best I've seen. I can wear these for several hours and my head/ears don't hurt like many of my past headsets. The padding also blocks outside sounds a decent amount so I find myself often uncovering 1 ear and the headset adjusts and pivots and is still comfortable to wear.
