Such a good design.These things are so durable. I am rough on my headsets. Joints, cheap plastic, low quality cords have all plagued my past headsets but not this one. It gets dropped and banged around but you'd never know it. Still looks and works like it's brand new.The sound. First, understand what I use them for. I play a lot of games on my computer, talk with friends on software and listen to music and movies/shows. I'm no audiophile but I have been able to compare how these sound vs other headsets. I feel like for the price they are really good. Most of my other headsets have been for gaming purposes and I will drop $60-80 for a good headset. (I've had several plantronics, a steelseries and logitech headsets). One of my plantronics sounded a bit better than these. In comparison, these sounded flat, like it was missing the fullness of a layer of sound. Honestly though, time has pasted and these sound pretty good so I don't really care. That plantronics also broke at several joints.Overall; TLDR: Most comfortable headset I've ever had, very durable and in the price range sound really good. I've got these and my Yeti microphone so I'm good to go for the long run. I'm done buying headsets every year or 2.Picture of the headset looking good as new more than a year later.Edit: The ear pad wrinkle material has started to tear and flake off. The great thing is, they are replaceable, which I have done. Good as new.Update 10/12/17 : Quick new update. I bought my wife a headset - Audio-Technica ATH-M30x and I have to say, they sound better than these and are cheaper. That said, I still like these for the durability and part replacement.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: UPDATE: I have had these headphones for only a year and a half and there is something wrong with the cord and cannot be used unless I lay them flat on a table and play with them until they work. I got an email from a rep. from Sony telling me to go to their site and I called them to file a complaint. All I got was that the warrantee expired and all I can do is write a "question/complaint" to customer relations and "hope" they will send me a new pair. They were also supposed to get back to me via email and haven't. Will not be buying anything Sony in the future as these were not cheap and will let all friends and family know of their lousy product and customer service.. Very Unhappy!!!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I have used these phones for more than 10 years for professional field video production.  They are quite comparable to the consumer version, the MDR-V600.These are an over-the-ear headphone, meaning that they fit around the ears without touching them - they sit on your head but not on the ears, which means that your ears don't get sore.  This also acoustically isolates you from your environment, which can be great or bad..if you need to hear what's around you for safety.  If you sweat heavily, they also tend to trap moisture.Sound reproduction is excellent and full-range, and due to the acoustic isolation of the phones, you will hear well and you won't hear much of what's going on around you outside the phones.  They do slightly emphasize bass in comparison to other frequencies, but that's something that most people don't mind.The screw-on 1/4" tip screws off to reveal a 1/8" stereo plug, so the phones work with most playback devices.  I highly recommend them as durable, acoustically excellent workhorses that you will use for many years.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Sony MDR7506, the workhorse over my Sennheiser 580s . . .
review_body: . . . don't get me wrong, I love my Sennheiser 580s (I treasure them), the Sennheiser-line  in fact, but the Sony MDR7506's are my default reach-for 95% of the time, whether for casual or critical listening and whether on the move or at a desktop or console.  I'd say I've lived with the MDR7506 for 8-months, though in truth that they've enlivened my head-space since then is more apt.  These headphones strip-away aural-layering to reveal voices and instrumentation that otherwise get lost in the mix, allowing the listener to go as "deep" into the mix as their equipment and source material will allow or yield.  Durability adds to their value and why I reach for them as I'd reach for a favorite pair of jeans before heading out the door - for nothing short of they'll allow me to do all things I want, within their purpose, with confidence.  Thank you for having read this far and in parting, believe me when I say, "You haven't heard what you're missing."
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: 5-stars for $25-$75 range.They are very comfortable, they even stop some sound coming from the environment.The presentation is top notch, they look like they are worth a lot more. But the sound is, you get what you paid for... better than way more expensive iem.I don't have many headphones but I'll put them in this order, from worst to best audio quality only:Sony XBA-H1, Samsung Level on Pro, Sony MDR7506, Bowers & Wilkins P7, Grado Rs1e, Fostex TH-900mk2.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Best bang for the buck I could find.  Classics
review_body: These things sound so good.I'm not an experienced audiophile.  I wanted a set of solid, clean and clear sounding cans and these have such an impeccable reputation and are offered at a price that is too good to refuse.They sound super clear and crisp.  The highs are very present and can be a little oppressive.  The mids and bass are very clear and well balanced.The cable is sort of annoying.  It is very long and floppy.  I mostly use these at a desk or on the bed but if you want to use these for travel/on a commute the cord might be a little much to deal with.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Great headphones! i usually play guitar in my apartment and a do not have the chance to connect it to a amplifier (because the noise would not take rest to the neighbors) so i needed this headphones and people trust me the quality of the sound its very particular, the bass sound from de diaphragm is pretty awesome. It's very important to mention that this headphones doesn't mute 100% the noise around you unless you put a middle sound volume. I recommend it!

I have a pair of beyerdynamic headphones that I would probably prefer to these in terms of comfort, but the sony pair is perfect for bringing to work and not worrying about.

review_body: When you consider the ridiculous price some of these headphones are getting, rest assured you needn't look any further nor spend any more!  I'm a software engineer and sit at my computer all day, every day, listening to Pandora with these.  They're extremely comfortable even after 8 hours and the sound is so pure I can finally hear the music the way it was originally recorded without emphasis on any one frequency.  These are awesome and I'd recommend them to everyone especially if you care about how your music really sounds!

review_body: The earphones fit very well on my somewhat large head.  The sound when used used with either my Samsung 4 phone or my Dell laptop is fine, with sufficient volume.  The long, partially coiled cord is nice, and I appreciate that it's thicker (and therefore hopefully longer lasting) than the cords on some other earphones, although for normal use with a phone or laptop it is perhaps a little too long.  If I have a need to use it with the TV, however, it will come in handy.  They fold nicely and fit well in the included vinyl case, but I can't be sure how well the hinges will hold up.

review_body: I have 4 pairs of Headphones priced between $79.99 and $250.00 and I must say these are very impressive. They have a well balanced sound perfect for my recording studio. I use these most of the time for mixing. They are comfortable as well.

review_title: Great Headphones, quality headphones at a great price
review_body: I bought these headphones after having run through countless pairs of earbuds.  I commute into New York City on a daily basis and have been searching for a pair of earbuds or headphones that are durable yet can provide quality sound without breaking the bank.After heavily reviewing other products (Bose, Monster, Beats, etc.) I settled on these.  At roughly $85/pair, you can't get a better set of cans.  Yes they are a bit bulky for a trip on a commuter rail but the MDR7506 headphones offer great sound quality.  The one detraction is that the cord is quite long but that is expected as they are built for use in a studio and not for commuting.  Plus I am able to get good use out of them by running them through my guitar amplifier (with the 1/4 inch adapter that is included).Specifics on the sound quality?  In a word, fantastic.  You can hear the nuances and details in songs that.  These hold their one when matched up against the other headphones that I have (including a pro-studio set of Sony's and Bose).I highly recommend them for anyone looking for a high quality set of headphones who wants a balanced sound experience.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: The Sony MDR7506 model headphones sound great and are quite comfortable
review_body: The Sony MDR7506 model headphones sound great and are quite comfortable. They are an excellent value for the price.I bought them based on some good online reviews and was surprised to find that they are the very same models that we use at the post production house where I currently work. They sound great, are very comfortable and reliable and you can't beat them for the price.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I love these. I just got an email asking if they met my expectations, and felt compelled to write my first review, as i was using them at the time. They arrived early, and perfect condition, with a beautiful package. The closed back means they block out most outside sound. They came with a 1/4 inch adapter which is perfect for plugging in to my mixer. The coiled cable means I can walk around my room freely while listening, without having to worry about damaging them or the device they're plugged into. I record a music in my home studio and these shine for that. The closed back keeps sound from coming out and bleeding into the track, even when I crank them (which I often do.) These aren't intended for everyday listening, but I use them for that, too. The fact that they're studio monitors means they give the listener exactly what the studio engineers and musicians wanted the audience to hear. I prefer that to boosted bass B.S. even for bass heavy music like hip-hop, EDM and pop. If you don't know what studio monitor means, look it up so you aren't surprised by these. The cups are comfortable and are easily adjusted to any size head. I wear them for hours, and they never hurt my ears. The one con I can think of is that the closed back means they get hot fast. When I have all my recording gear running in a hot house with no air conditioning, these compound the issue. Seriously, thank you sony. For the price, they're absolutely perfect.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: If you are upgrading from ear buds, you aren't going to want to go back. These head phones deliver pristine audio quality. Whether you are using them for music or other sound work, they provide the results you want. They are quite comfortable and block out essentially all the sound around you. I still use ear buds when I want portability, but when I'm working on a project or just looking for an optimal audio experience, I use my Sony Studio Headphones. They come in a carry bag, so they are portable, but aren't good for light weight packing, or for use during travel.Pros: Comfortable, Phenomenal sound quality, Great noise cancelling.Cons: Not good for use during travel, Padding wears out after long term use. The pads are replaceable, although replacement can be a little frustrating.Overall: Fantastic product. I would highly recommend them.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: These headphones look super cool but they didn't work for me
review_body: These headphones look super cool but they didn't work for me. They were a little heavy on my head. After wearing them for a while I realized I far prefer an earphone. But if you need a headphone, these sound great. I compared these headphones to several others at the guitar center and these rock! (Pun intended!)

review_body: I have wanted a pair of these headphones for years. The folding design and reputation for great sound sold me on them long ago, and a strong recommendation from a colleague with plenty of professional experience took away any doubt.Bought them on a Warehouse deal and couldn't be happier! Great sound, excellent isolation and comfortable enough to wear for hours!Highly recommended!

review_body: My son lives these headphones. He said that they're very crisp. He said at first you have to get used to them, because you hear things you didn't hear before with normal headphones, but soon realize that you have been missing so much ! He uses them to create music and to game online.  I'd recommend these. For the price, these are great headphones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: The most honest, useful headphones created. Simply the best cans ever.
review_body: 7506's are in a different leauge than AKG, Shure, Sennheiser and even beyerdynamic headphones. They are honest, transparent and incredibly useful. The badmouth on 7506's is they sound "harsh", " too sterile", etc. These aren't for listening to your Kanye playlist while hiking or "bassing out" on some Dubstep. These are professional audio TOOLS used to mix,  check recording quality,  track overdubs, etc. They are made to be honest, flat and unflattering to recordings with faults so they can be addressed. I got my first pair in 1994 and those boys are still working great. The only thing was recently spending $10 or so here at Amazon for replacement earpads, now they look new just like the pair I just bought from here a few months back. The new ones will take some "breaking in" as the first few months the drivers are still settling, etc. These headphones age incredibly well because my 20+ year old pair sounds just as tight and true as the new pair but a certain roundness and expansion of the stereo image is present, really cool. Sony 7506's are essential for checking mixes and excel in isolating sound while overdubbing vocals and mic'd instruments. Even mixing is great on these...of course nearfield monitors are the rule for mixing but if you "know" and learn the way 7506's sound and react it is entirely possible to produce awesome mixes without a monitor in sight. Try really listening to classic albums that have reputations for being recorded and mixed extremely well and you will soon "get" why 7506's are so essential. Albums like "Who's Next" by the Who, "Aja" by Steely Dan, "OK Computer" by Radiohead, "Full Moon Fever" by Tom Petty and "Abbey Road" by the Beatles are prime listening lessons. Most of those records were made on analog tape and in studios without the DAW ease of today as digital  crystal clarity but 7506's show you how the engineer/producer/artist carved out the sonic space and frequency zone for each instrument. Go to school on stuff like this and your own favorite stuff and then when you check mixes, track and even mix with 7506 headphones you'll have so much insight and experience to apply to your projects.Sorry for the novel but I can't put these over enough, truly exceptional tool that any audio pro should have. The only thing even close are beyerdynamic DT100's but they don't have the sound stage and dimension that the Sony's have. And for non Recording & Pro Audio enthusiast's still reading at this point I think if you can accept going in that these aren't gimmicky noise cancelling, "extreme bass" headphones, 7506's can be great for hearing how the artist produced the music and intended it to sound. I know I'd rather have these than some beats by dre for an international multi-hour flight anyday.In closing, these aren't necessarily headphone versions of the venerable Yamaha NSM10 monitors but like those  studio standards 7506's can give honest insight into what's right and what's wrong about what you're listening to.Highly recommended.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Durable, Comfortable, and Provides Quality Sound
review_body: I really can't say enough for these headphones. I'm only a casual listener, nothing to do with sound editing, but I absolutely love these headphones. Great bass, great depth of sound. When I have them on, they provide full immersion into the music. My only issue with it (as a casual user)  is that the cord is really long, so it's nearly impossible to wear outside my own home. Otherwise, it fits comfortably, completely over my ears, and I can wear it for hours without discomfort. Definitely recommend.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Good job guys, not great job guys
review_body: These have additional presence in the hi's so they might fatigue your ear a little more than some other headphones. The bass response is tempered but even for a studio monitoring point of view. If you're looking for something to thump bass really loud, look elsewhere. But for monitoring purposes they are pretty decent. The only downside is for monitoring they will most likely fatigue your ear so kind of defeats the purpose. But a good alternate monitoring source for noticing clicks, pops and other issues that might go unnoticed with mixing on speakers.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Love these headphones. This is my 2nd pair. The 1st pair is still going strong, I just use them in 2 different locations and don't want to have to carry them back and forth from home to studio. I use them when practicing electronic drums at home and when playing acoustic drums as a vocal monitor in the studio. I would recommend replacing the pleather ear cushions, though, as they tend to dry rot over time. The faux leather pads will work fine for a while, but I replaced the ones on these with the Brainwavz HM5 velor memory foam replacements.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great for Video Editing! Super Comfortable
review_body: I've been using these headphones while editing videos on Adobe Premiere and I couldn't be more than happy using them.  You can really hear a lot of different tonal ranges that you wouldn't be able to hear with regular headphones. You'll also be able to hear more accurate sounds while watching movies or music!  I didn't really understand what everyone was talking about in these reviews but after you get these and put them on, you'll be able to notice the difference almost immediately.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Very true to sound.  Some complained about them not having enough bass or being "flat", if you know how to use your equalizer on your device, they sound amazing.  I use them for movies, games, and music.  Especially good for gaming, allowing the user to listen to ambient sounds in the background with great detail.  Also the noise blockage feature is really nice for the user and anyone else that might be around, it does block the noise really well both ways.  These headphones are also really comfortable for a long time and they seem quite well made.  I have not had them a long time, but they seem as if they will stand the test of time quite well.  The carry case is not anything amazing but should help keep dust and dirt out of these when they travel around in my backpack.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great value, presence and punch, solid construction
review_body: The industry standard for studio tracking for decades. A mild but pleasant bump in the high mids leave no doubt about what the drummer and bassist are up to; the hi hats and dead notes will come through. These have a sweet, round middle, yet plenty of punch for the kick to be felt. Stereo imaging is realistic and accurate on playbacks and captures.My only issue with these is that, compared to my old Sony MDR V600s, the ear cushions are a little skimpy. On me (and certain others) there is a bit of compression on the outer ear which tends toward minor discomfort and, worse, attenuation of the upper highs resulting in a little muffling across the spectrum. I find that careful placement and seating of the cans is crucial to avoiding this aggravation. And I must fiddle with this before every take. Sometimes I even have to shim them a bit if I've had a recent haircut.All in all, I've come to prefer high-end in-ears for most applications. But for general tracking and playback, this is the model to buy. For the price, they are, hands down, the best of the breed for studio work and general listening.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Minus 1 star for comfort. *Upgraded to 5 now!
review_body: First of all, I'm not an audiophile or am not aware if I was one. However, I do listen to a wide variety of music including rock, pop, (a lot of) classical, hip hop, so I'm your normal average Joe. And here's my short take: Like what everyone's been saying, the built quality and the sound quality are extremely good! No complaint in these departments. I did take off one star because of the discomfort. I have average (if not smaller than average) head and ears, and these cans are just barely circumaural. The right cup barely fits comfortably over my ear, but the left one does not (guess how I know my ears have slightly different sizes?). So after about an hour of being pinched, my left ear would become red and irritated, and well, that can certainly distract me from enjoying music. I'm hoping that after a while, they will loosen up a bit, but as I already have them for about 2 weeks, I don't think there's much of that, so I'm considering returning it for another different pair. I'll give you an update later.To sum up, if you have larger than average (I'm curious to know that the official "average" ear size is), you will experience discomfort during and after use. I would suggest that you try them out in a store before buying them. I didn't do that and so regretting it.Update 09/24/2013:I've been using this for over 8 months now. The sound quality is still, if not even more, superb. The good news is that somehow the left cup now fits my ear! It's comfy to wear now! Although it can get hot during the summer, and the cans can (pun intended) get quite irritating if sweat gets on it. So I would suggest an occasional clean with some gentle cleaning agent. But overall, the only thing I regret is that I bought this for about $90, and now it's $80.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Sound and work great. Seem poorly made.
review_body: Got as a gift. LOVES THEM! Says they work and sound great. Said “best Xmas gift ever”. My complaint is the built of the head sets. The strap that goes over your head seems like it will break very easy. Just have to be careful and enjoy while they last.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: The only reason I cannot give these a 5star rating is because the cord/plug just gets in the way sometimes. Don't get me wrong, I love the sound, comfort, durability, and everything about these headphones except the cord/plug. I mainly use these while listening to music on my laptop and while playing my guitar, using my miniamp. While on my laptop the plug, or jack, whatever you want to call it, sticks out a little far and I am always worried about breaking it. Wile using my miniamp with my guitar the cord stretches to far down under its own weight and I am worried about tripping over it and possible damaging the plug/jack. Other that these two minor problems, I love these headphones. The sound is amazing, sounds great no matter what I'm listening to and no matter what volume. I have stepped on, sat on, dropped, and abused these and they work flawlessly. Definitely a great investment.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: First, the build quality is nothing but excellent and the folding design is extremely convenient. Ear cushions are very comfortable and fit perfectly. Sound isolation is very good also. Head band is padded just right. (I imagine some may want more padding but it does not cause discomfort.)Second, sound quality is amazing right of the box.I tried many premium headphones in stores but I do not think I would trade mine for any of those.One thing that took me a bit by surprise was the coiled cord.At first, it looked somewhat large for personal use.But I like it now as it allows me to walk away from my computer (or even walk in a room) not taking off headphones.I also cannot get tangled in it as I did with a 10' straight cable on my other headphones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I needed something to help with audio editing when I podcast or doing video production.  I like ot hear only what is on the recording, not the external noises of the office.  These are the best I found and are affordable.  Once they are on, the rest of the world goes away and you are listening to what you recorded.  No outside interruptions.I like the fact that there is no volume control, its pure sound form the source (computer) one less break in the line! Very comfortable to wear... If worn for an extended length of time, I do occasionally get some moisture around the ears. They just reminds me I've sitting their in my own little world and need to take a break....  Its not a problem as someone else commented,  and only happens if you wear them too long.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: A step up, but not a huge difference
review_body: I have 3 sets of Sony headphones - the ZX100, the V150 monitor series and now these.  There is not a huge difference between the ZX100 and the V150 - both are good.  I actually use the cheaper ZX100s more as they have a shorter cord that is easier to manage when going for a run.  Compared to those headphones, the MDR7506 professional series have a step up in clarity.  It is not huge, but it is noticeable.  As a very rough estimate (based on my iphone volume settings) they also have higher sensitivity.I rated these at 4 stars.  They are great headphones and I am really pleased that I purchased them.  However, I think the ZX100 and the V150 are such good value, that the price of these suffers by comparison.  For the price, I would like to see padding on the headband or perhaps a more comfortable fitment system (they don't quite fit my head perfectly).Overall, if you want a great set of enclosed headphones, you will be very happy with these.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Finally got the headphones that so many budget audiophilia were raving about. And honestly, the second I put them on I could see why. These are definitely the best pair of headphones I have ever owned. Granted, these are the most expensive that I've purchased and don't have an pro-range headphones to compare them to. However... many who do own other $300+ headphones claim that these are some of the best they've ever owned, and even prefer them over their more expensive pairs.They're comfortable, look great, sound amazing, and seem very durable. The cord is definitely thicker than any other pair of headphones I've had, which is good because it seems like cords are always the first to break on headphones. It's also pretty neat that it's of like a scrunchy cord, and I can walk about 8 feet away from my mixer to pick up a guitar and it stays firmly on my head.Listening to regular ear buds and other headphones just isn't enough once you try these. I can't stand listening to or recording music with my ear buds anymore knowing I'll be missing out on my MDR-7506's. Seriously, get em. Their flat out response will blow you away, without blowing away your money.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Great quality headphones!I will post an update if anything changes, but I've had these for around a couple of months now, and I've had no flaking of the earpieces or the earmuffs slipping off, like some other people have reported. No shorting in the chord, either. I use these for at least 2 hours per day, and I am not sure how the earmuffs could even flake or slip off, as they feel like a sort of leathery material and are well secured. Either they have updated their design to fix the issues, or I've just been lucky so far! Mind, I have been careful to be gentle with them when I put them on and take them off, and care has been taken to not sharply bend the chord. I do see there is some reinforcement where it plugs in, to help prevent it from shorting out there. .Overall the sound quality is great on these. I like how things don't sound too bassy or too treble-y , but give a nice sharp sound that avoids altering the sound of music from what I can only assume it was intended to sound like when recorded. I'd recommend them.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: If you want a balanced reproduction of all frequencies, with good instrumental detail, nice presence and clear, crisp sound, you will probably like these headphones.  They're definitely not for everybody, and listeners who like hip-hop and/or music with deep, pulsing bass, should read no further.  But for my taste, these are great headphones, even when compared to products 3-4 times the price.Like most headphones under $100, the "build" quality of these does not appear to be anything special, and for over-ear headphones they could be a little larger and more comfortable.  But my overriding criteria in rating headphones is SOUND,  The lower registers are tight and solid without being overdone, and the mids and upper-mids seem perfect with great voice presence and absolutely beautiful reproduction of acoustic guitars, woodwinds, etc.  If I had to nitpick, it is that the very high registers (for example, massed violins) seem a little "tinny", but a few minor tweaks to the equalizer seemed to pretty much solve that problem.Bottom line, I really like these headphones and highly recommend them..
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: A bit bright but still a studio standard
review_body: I went back to these headphones as my vocal booth phones of choice after a brief affair with a pair of Audio Technica ATH-M50's. I love the Audio Technicas and I still use them, but for different purposes. My non-audiophile ears feel that the M50's are better at reproducing music while the brightness of the Sonys makes them a great choice for tracking (singing or voice-over). The voice tends to cut through better on the Sonys while on the AT's everything is more balanced; but when you're tracking you need the voice to stick out a bit. I'm not an engineer, I don't have fancy testing equipment, this is my own opinion as a professional singer and voice over artist. Your mileage may vary.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Back in the 90's, an audio engineer recommend that I get a pair of MDR7506's to use for home recording.  After nearly 20 years of use, one side started to get a little buzzy on loud bass tracks so this is a replacement.  I thought about replacing just the diaphragms but it only cost a bit more to buy an entirely new pair.There isn't much new to say about these.  They're a studio standard for a number of good reasons: sound, comfort, durability, easily replaced ear pads...  and price.  With the Sony's, you get a lot of headphone for the money.Highly recommended.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Nothing to be said that hasn't already been said
review_body: I'm no audiophile, but I sat for an hour with my previous Bose Triports and these headphones are a world of difference.The Bose, while having a warmer sound with more bass, were clearly muddier, while the 7506's were sharp and crystal clear. You can literally hear EVERYTHING, which is what I love to do with music - go deep into the track to find all the subtle tones and harmonies and extra riffs and things that are put in when the songs are recorded but rarely get noticed.I do field monitoring with DSLR's and a Zoom H4n, which is another reason I bought these wonderful monitoring headphones. Knowing what audio you're getting is pretty dang important. The music is just gravy.Comfy, and I also like the foldable sides and the ability to fold up as well to compact the shape. They are far more durable and well built than my Triports. I got the coiled cable because straight cables inevitably tangle on me. Works well.Not much else to say about these.Do buy if you like an extremely balanced set of cans that really pull every little bit out of each track, and are perfect for monitoring.Do not buy if you like a richer or warmer sound, heavier bass at the expense of some clarity and sharpness (I assume there are headphones that do it all, but can you find some for $88, which is what I bought the 7506's for on sale?). There are probably bigger, heavier, and more immersive cans for studio or home use, but for travel and field work, not much can beat these suckers.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These headphones have been around since the 90s for a reason. They're monitor headphones, so the sound is amazingly clear and balanced. I use it alot for gaming along with music at my computer. The coiled cable is VERY long, so it could be cumbersome at times, but it's very handy for rolling around in a computer chair. I love the vintage aesthetic too. They're comfy for hours of wearing as well. I bought these many months ago and they still work fine with heavy use
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: These things are awesome! I use them strictly for electric guitar monitoring ...
review_body: These things are awesome!  I use them strictly for electric guitar monitoring with garageband and the sound quality is great.  If you're using with a computer I would suggest also purchasing a headphone amplifier which you can get a decent one for under fifty bucks.  All in all I'm happy with this purchase.  I've had them for probably six months so I will update on durability after I've had them for a while. But for now, five stars!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Best earphones in the sub $200 range. I've had Bose and Sennheiser that I loved, but the levels weren't what I wanted. The levels (Treble, Mid, Bass) are perfect, it really has that "true sound" which is why they're used in nearly every recording studio across the world. Don't be mistaken though, these are perfect for home use as well as travel (used them on airplanes with no problems hearing). They of course aren't for sport-use, but I wouldn't expect them to be.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I could barely fit my ears inside of the ear cups.  Tight, hot and uncomfortable after 2 minutes. Yes, I have normal ears.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Bought these for my Daughter and now I want a pair.They sound amazing and sound very clear,  they are very comfortable and feel good around your ears.The high reviews on these are true and well deserving.The vendor also mentions portability however, I don't think I  would lug these around an airport.They are being run thorough a small DAC Nobsound NS-08E Vacuum Tube Integrated Amplifier Mini Audio HiFi Stereo Headphone Amp . (Which was also surprisingly good.)This sounds great on  these headphones:https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=bnsUkE8i0tU
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Excellent headphones for my stereo receiver system in my living ...
review_body: Excellent headphones for my stereo receiver system in my living room. They have very good bass and very clear and distinct sounds all across the frequency ranges, with very good highs. Really enjoying listening to them the last few days. They really excel with orchestra type music and reproduce all the instruments well. Would highly recommend them to anybody.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Audio range very natural and non fatiguing.
review_body: I am not an audiophile, but i have over the years collected a number of headphones and earphones,  in an attempt to chase the perfect sound. All of the items I have purchased have been in the budget range. (Cannot afford the high end items). Each earphone has a slight impact on the sound signature such as more bass, less treble, more midrange, less midrange, etc.Of all the headphones,(6 in total), I found the Sony MDR7506 to be a headphone that seems to present the music in a natural way, without any fatigue from strong bass or high treble. The only thing that I have trouble with is that the earpads seem to get hot around the ears, but besides that they are a very good headphone.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Fantastic headphones. I only use them for home use, and I think they are as nice as any home casual user needs. If you're any type of headphone user I would recommend these actually. They sound perfect and I heard all sorts of stuff I didn't hear before. One thing to note! I do notice ( and it's noticeable) a hissing sound in very high pitched S sounds or Ch sounds. I hear it in these and not cheaper headphones I've had, but perhaps it's just the clarity coming through. It's not bad but it's something worth a mention. I haven't listened to ATH m50X which these are widely compared to, but the specs don't seem very different, and I think that these are perfect for anyone. The ear pad space is very small, they were borderline on ear, so I recommend BrainWavs memory foam Earpads, they add a lot more space and feel amazing. Either way these are beautiful headphones for anyone, and plenty professionals use them or have used them for personal use (Howard stern, Tyler The Creator, and Anna Kendrick, just to name a few)
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I initially went searching for a good set of headphones for some international flights coming up and of course the Bose were the first I thought of!But after some research I decided to order a set of these in "used-like new" condition and they came packaged in way that makes me think they had never been opened!But anyway, they have amazing sound quality that can blow me away with just the clarity and sound quality!I don't think these will be ideal for canceling out the noises of an airplane, but considering I use these headphones frequently in my own home (they sound that much better than my $80 computer speaker set up) and are comfortable to wear for hours on end.Do your own comparison and take into consideration your needs and uses, but don't be afraid of getting junk from these headphones, I have been overly impressed and plan on using wax ear plugs with these head phones just in case I end up on an especially noisey flight!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Comfortable, really great sound quality not even considering price.  But if you compare it to the price of other over the ear headphones it makes me like the quality even more.  Does a good job of noise isolation, the only thing that would make me give this 5 stars is if it blocked out more noise. I would give it 4.5 stars if there was an option  But overall extremely happy with the headphones, some of the best I've ever bought.  I bought these to mainly listen to jazz, blues and classical music because of the reviews I read, and they do not disappoint.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Well balanced sound  Highs are crisp, mids are very clean, lows and sub are very distinguishable between the two. Not an overly enhanced sound in either direction.Such a great sounding and well fitting lighter weight headphone and a great price. You can spend more but I don't think yer going to get a better sounding headphone set with out spending a lot more. ( country- classic rock-electronic and modern vocals) sound awesome even hip hop is very accurate. If yer looking for something with a lot of enhanced lows(sub) probably need to look at the beats pros much higher price and very heavy on yer head.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I use headphones in my work as a transcriptionist and this is my second pair of Sony.  They are wonderful, drown out outside noise and give me the ability to pick up dialog I wouldn't be able to hear with conventional headphones.  They are comfortable after hours of wearing them.  My last pair lasted over five years, finally the leather started flaking off the ear pieces and the coil was tangled up so badly that it started wearing through and wires were exposed.  My husband use electric tape and still uses them for his Ipod.  This new pair seems (so far) to have that tangled cord problem fixed, which is so annoying.  The cord seems heavier and doesn't twist up.  I've been using it for several months with no cord problems, but we'll see how that lasts in the long run.  Comes with a nice leather bag for storage.  I would recommend.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Not much else to say about this model. There's plenty of information out there since it is a very critically acclaimed professional tested monitor with crisp clear reproduction. This does not distort the bass like some of the more trendy consumer or gaming headphones for people that like extra rumble. If you're looking for accuracy, but don't want to pay $300, this is it.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Im hearing things in my favorite music I've never heard before. Don't bother shopping around anymore if you value sound quality and crisp depth with Rich lows and crunchy highs. Better than headphones priced double, you don't need noise cancellation with these comfy cups either.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: New audio enthusiast. Hearing things iv'e never heard before in my favorite songs
review_body: I'll preface this with these are one of my first "studio quality" headphones other than really bass heavy sets like Dre. Beats (ehh) and bose. DO NOT buy if your intending on only using your phone to drive these. Sound card or amp is basically required to get what I would consider as normal loudness, but once you get em there... OMG the detail and accuracy of these headphones are astounding. I personally don't have deep catalog of hi-fi monitors but I have listen to countless head phones and at double this price range I don't foresee much accuracy gained if that is what you are going for.. In my humble opinion.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Why did I not know about the MDR-7506 25 years ago!
review_body: They have been around since 1991, but never caught on to them until a couple of years ago and after spending more than a few hundred dollars on big name cans and one headphone preamp. When I finally found out and bought these, The sound aced them all out. I got that "why didn't I figure this out earlier?" feeling. They are now the only ones by my side.Don't be like me. Get the best, forget the rest.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: The industry standard for good reason
review_body: For the price you can't beat these. In fact, in my experience you can't even come close if you spend double the price. There is a reason that these are the standard in recording studios. I just gave my original pair that I got 17 years ago to my brother and I bought a new pair for myself. The old ones still work great! I just replaced them because the ear pads were a little worn (what do you expect after 17 years?) but there was nothing wrong with them. If you're looking for new headphones for music production then don't think twice, just buy these.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: THESE ARE THE BEST ALL AROUND HEADPHONES...price, quality, sound
review_body: I've bought many, many headphones through the years including outrageously priced Bose (that broke after the one year warranty), and other noise canceling headphones.  NOTHING....I'll say it again....NOTHING is better than this pair of Sony.  My 21 year old son had researched these and they are outstanding!  Time will tell if they hold up to his part-time DJ job.  The sound quality is second to none and the price won't kill you like a pair of Dr. Beats, by the way I refused to pay $200 last year at Christmas for those cheap quality "the in thing" headphones.  I could tell that marketing scam a mile away last Christmas. This pair cost under $85 with tax included.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These are awesome and reproduce sound like nothing else I've owned. They're very comfortable to wear for long sessions. My daughter owns the model MDRV6 version and has replaced the ear cushions with ease. The MDR7506 seems to carry the bass a bit better so us older guys get a closer to full bandwidth experience. I've used more expensive makes and models, but find these to be better than any other non-noise cancelling headset that I've tried.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great buy for a reasonable price.
review_body: Just love these headphones. I've got a fairly good size pumpkin (head) and these fit nicely and block out outside noise very well.  The sound quality is just what I was looking for with my demo studio. I get up early in the morning sometimes and I can work on things without disturbing my wife. I probably will be getting another two or so soon for when I'm playing and recording with other people and using my Samson headphone monitor. I would recommend these Sony MDR7506's to serious recordists who are working on a tight budget. You will not be disappointed when you get them.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Excellent quality headphones. I tried out many high dollar headphones before purchasing these and have since tried many headphones and these ones are for me. First the sound is incredible! As good as any headphones I have tried. The fit is right for me. I also like that I can use these on my laptop as the impedance is low enough to use with low level audio outs like laptop outputs or iPod outputs. No need for an amplifier.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Second time I ordered these. Great sound, soft on the ears, comfortable on my head. The bag is better quality than a few years back. If not for the long, irritating chord, I would have given it  5 stars.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I was in the market for a new headphone, one that could give me a nice, crisp sound along with great bass for all genres of music. I've checked beats, bose, audio technica products; as good as they are they were quite pricey. After doing research online I hear that the Sony MDR7506 provided studio quality sound along with an affordable price tag. Unfortunately for me, none of the electronic stores near me carried this product in the store so I couldn't just test it out like other headphones so I was skeptical on buying it. I'm glad I bought it though because the sound is amazing. I listen to all sorts of music like EDM, Rock, Metal, Country, Classical, Jazz, etc. The amazing thing is that you get amazing quality sound out of each genres because it doesn't heavily rely on "extra bass". I definitely recommend to someone who has a home studio or just wants to listen to music to get this headphone. It may not look as sexy as other brands, but for someone like me, it's all about the inside that counts. With great sound quality for $79.99 on Amazon, it's a steal when compared to other brands like Bose which can cost at least twice as much. First time buyer and I'm a fan already.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Yeah, if you rake the dollars up there, you'll find better headphones than these.But for anything cheaper than 300 dollars, this here will be your best friend.My brother has a large head, and these fit right over his without any semblance of problem.The cord is studio ridiculous in length, so you won't have to worry about straining your head to listen to your music.And the cans are just simply awesome.I can't vouch for the earpads falling apart or whatever, because I went ahead and bought the Beyerdynamic Ear Cushions to replace them with (the installation is pretty annoying).
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: but these are by far my favorite. They sound great and I really appreciate that ...
review_body: I've purchased much more expensive headphones than these, but these are by far my favorite. They sound great and I really appreciate that they are slightly less bass-heavy than other, more expensive sets. Instead, these really let the treble come through and I can hear everything, even finding new bits to songs I've listened to for years. I only wish these had an integrated microphone and volume/track controls, but I guess that's a different product category.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Best Value Headphones for Mixing at Home
review_body: Wonderful pair of headphones for mixing. I heard Andrew Scheps mixed a record on these and saw them on here for a good price and took a chance. So glad I did. I will be buying more of these.Pros:Noise isolation. These create a good fit with your ear and its great for that.True Reference Headphones: Most headphones have hyped bass response. I found these to be a great natural response. I own Audio Technica ATH-M50s and these are way better for mixing. I have tried the Sennheiser HD models. They are great. But not for the price compared to this. And personally I liked the response from these bette.rGood form fit: Really I mean these are comfortableComes with 1/4 inch adapter.Cons: 1/4 adapter only works with these headphones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I have just got a new computer sound card (Creative ZxR) which allows me to hear things I have been missing with my Bose Speakers and Bose Headphones so I decided to go further with a new pair of headphones. After hours of researching, I ended up getting this one and when I tried this pair headphones with some of my favorite songs and a movie, I fall in love with it instantly. In my opinion, I believe they produce universal extremely great and accurate sounds so no matter what kind of preference you may have, I'm sure you will also love what these pair of headphones produce as well. If you feel suspicious why they are not so expensive (like I did before I decided to give it a try), it is because of they are selling tons of this product each month (supply-demand logic).
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Great headphones, with one small caveat-  smaller than I wanted on the ear coverage. I read multiple reviews on different sites that lead me to purchase these headphones, and they were all fairly spot on. They sound great, fit comfortably, fold up and travel VERY impressively... But they don't completely cover my ears, and I wanted a pair that did. Besides that, they are pretty much perfect for me. I really like them and would recommend them- But I cannot get over the ear coverage.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Minor annoyances here and there, but overall GREAT.
review_body: To start things off, these sound incredible. They sound extremely clean, and have a tight a punchy bass but its not overpowering at all. Great for mixing and overall music production, or if you just want really flat sounding headphones these are great. Under $100 I think these are the best music production headphones you can get in terms of sound and build quality. Sure there are better options, but for what I paid ($79.99) its hard to beat. I do have some complaints though, which are very minor. The way the headphones fold up are great, but if your not careful they can snap out of your hands and fold up really hard and it will flip the ear cups and they get scratched. I had a friend wearing them and he scratched it this way, although its never happened to me. Also the cable is fine, I wish it was detachable but whatever, it functions fine and the only problem I have had was that the coiled cable gets caught on the arm of my chair and will snag and its noticeable but once again, MY chair does this so it doesn't apply to everyone. Now for my biggest complaint- if you move your head sometimes the top part of the ear cups will touch the top of the base that holds them in and makes a noticeable tapping sound and recently has been bugging me more than ever. To put it into perspective, it sounds like tapping your finger nails on plastic when you are bored, but maybe not as loud. If you keep your head pretty steady it doesn't really do this but if you rotate your head as if to look upside down (just in that general rotation, by no means am I wearing headphones upside down) they will touch and it makes a noise. You could fix this by taping some sort of soft fabric like felt onto that area, I just haven't done it. Overall, I'd give them a 9/10 and say that they sound amazing but have a few quirks just like every pair of headphones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: these are awesome monitors. I have a set of AKG K240 ...
review_body: Seriously, these are awesome monitors. I have a set of AKG K240 Studio headphones I have used religiously for the past year in my studio for Voice Over auditions, and client directed sessions. I really like the AKG K240's - but as soon as I put the Sony MDR7506's on after doing some VO work, man what a difference. The mids, lows and highs are so much clearer. I can't believe my ears. Very pleased.One major reason I got these Sony MDR7506 was because it's what I see in EVERY high end professional studio I've recorded in. They fit well, and are very comfortable. No wonder these have been industry standard studio headphones for the past 20 years. I will be getting another set or three for my field bag.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great if you get new earpads!
review_body: These are great headphones. They will be a major upgrade to any sub $50 headphones you buy at a store or online. My one complaint is the earpad comfort. When I first got them I couldn't wear them for a long time because my ear was pressing on the speaker which became very uncomfortable. I bought the Auray Extra Deep Ear Pads and it makes a world of difference. It makes the sound better also because the speaker is not so close to the ear. I would say these earpads are basically a requirement if you buy these headphones (or the V6).
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: These have been great, I can wear them all day without a ...
review_body: I purchased these after reading the review on Wirecutter. I don't consider myself an audiophile or an expert, but I do spend most of my workday listening to music, so comfort and affordability were more important than sound quality. These have been great, I can wear them all day without a lot of discomfort, the sound is crisp and they drown out plenty of ambient noise even at low volume, so I can hear my music but not my coworker's obnoxious chewing. Even at the affordable price range, they sound great.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: but they are perfect for home listening and recording and have satisfied my ...
review_body: My boyfriend bought these headphones for home recording, to use on his Nord keyboard so he doesn't wake the baby, and for listening to vinyl in bed. The sound quality is clear to the point that they pick up on way more of the scratches and dust bumps on a record than our speakers do. The tones are rich and reflect the price point - they're not $300 headphones, but they are perfect for home listening and recording and have satisfied my audiophile musician boyfriend.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Not even just for the price.  I have had pricey-er cans that sounded much flatter.I wish they made a version with a little more padding, that did not collapse, and an uncoiled cable for us musicians that sit when we play.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These are the go to headphones. Nice retro look to it. The comfort is nice as well. It'll give me a bit of an ache on my ears for around 6 hours on having them on but I don't think that's normal. The cord is sooooooo long but retracts back nicely, I can walk around my room with them plugged in my laptop and manage to walk around. I still believe that there is more potential in this which one can mess around with the sound settings. They seem extremely durable and i have stepped on them a couple of times but the headphones didn't seem to mind and worked like new. These are very portable if you travel a lot and it comes with a little bag that closes which is nice and kind of sony to do. I have to listen to music to any music in this or not I'm not experience the quality of the music. Definitely  an engaging head set compared to others out there.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great headphones for cranking OR atmospheric music..
review_body: I really enjoy these a lot. These are a replacement for my older Sony headphones that just plain wore out (30+ years old). They have good solid bass, and yet seem to be fairly efficient as they have plenty of juice on my phone and tablet. I'm no audio expert but the highs seem very clear and distinct as well. I listen to loud techno/industrial as well as very soft ambient music and the the headphones work great on both types. I cant think of any down sides. Well done, Sony. Oh and they fold up pretty compactly as well for travel..
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Quality and comfort of the highest order
review_body: I wanted to wait a few months before I reviewed these, as I've had experiences with dips in quality with other headphones in the past.At this point, after many hundreds of hours of listening, I can say with certainty that these headphones are an incredible deal for the price. I can't claim to have compared them with many competitive offerings, but I can't imagine that a casual listener like myself could find better quality in the same price range (or indeed beyond that range!)In addition to the sound being crystalline, they're really comfortable to boot, which is crucial if you're at work trying to focus on a project for several hours at a time. The padding around the ears provides a degree of passive noise-cancelling that's not to be sniffed at, either, although outside noises will of course filter through if they're loud enough.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I had a previous pair of SONY headphones and they were great except for the plastic headpiece. When that broke, I asked a friend of mine in the radio business and he stated the MDR7506 Studio Monitor Headphones were the best headphones for the money. I have to say he was right. I will recommend these to anyone anytime. Love my SONY!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great work headphones. Collapsable feature is annoying
review_body: Got these for work. Not too expensive. Fit is good. Comfortable. I don't like how they are constantly flipping when removed, so I have to mess with them virtually every time I use them. Sound is great. Great price for the office.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These phones are absolutely kick ass!  For anyone with Asthma, these are like taking an albuterol puff for the ears!  They make anything you want to hear clear, dynamic, and intimate!  A MUST HAVE!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I usually have a couple pairs on hand for my shoots.  This seems to be the standard model that has been used by me and other video folks that I work with for years.  Durable, realistic sound at a price point that makes it more attractive than some of the very high priced headphones.  For what I use them for, which is mostly studio shoots, these work just fine.  I've never had them fail and would order more if I ever need to.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Music has never sounded so great!
review_body: Everything you read in the most helpful reviews is 100% true. I'm not a music "professional" per se, but I have played and enjoyed music ever since I could play a piano, and I would consider these a must-have for any audiophile, especially for the price.  I primarily use them to listen to vinyl records, but I also have a premium account with Spotify, which allows you to stream in 320kbps.  These combos seriously make for unparalleled music enjoyment.The sound quality is impeccable -- bass is full and punchy, but not too much "thud" or overly thumpy, the mid is well-balanced and clear, and the treble accents every note and beat to their fullest extents.As a side note, all the materials seem and feel very sturdy, including the carrying bag that comes with it.All in all, one of my favorite Amazon purchases so far.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Excellent sound for the money!!  Nice balance with tight clear bass.  Easily driven by a phone or laptop computer.  Comfortable, I can wear these all day, with minor discomfort from my reading glasses.  Well made.  The long coiled cord is great for office use.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: This is, by far and away, the best headset I have ever used.  The basses are richer, the highs crisper, and the midranges completely natural.In addition, the ample padding makes them effectively noise-cancelling; so, Bose Quiet Comfort at a quarter the price.  A bit more cumbersome, yes, and for that savings, count me in.I've owned many headsets over the last forty years, and have used them in professional and personal settings.  These are simply my favorites.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: sony mdr 7506..dont wait.rejuvenate your listening pleasure.
review_body: compared the authenticity from youtube after receiving. these are authentic,not heavy on the head,and make my hard rock sound explosive again...I may MOD the cord to a female removable 3.5mm jack..but not right now....love 'em...
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I read some of the other favorable reviews of Sony's MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphones, and I thought that they were the headphones for me. Alas, beauty is in the ear of the hearer. These headphones, to me, have a tinny sound. That is, they are weak in the bass and too strong in the higher frequencies.It's not all bad though. I adjust the bass and treble controls on my receiver to compensate for the weak bass and too-bright high frequencies. These phones are also reasonably comfortable to wear. I can go 45 minutes or so and not experience the "vice on my head" feel that a lot of other headphones can inflict.So I'd recommend that you listen to the Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphones if you can prior to purchase. That way you can decide if they have the sound for you. Depending on your own ears and preference in music, you may love these headphones. For me, they're only fair.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I bought these originally for practicing bass guitar with a headphone amp; a use that'll push any set of cans to the limit. They work ok for that purpose, but honestly no set of headphones is going to replace a pair of 15" speakers for bass response. They're good when I want to practice quietly (emphasis quietly, too much volume and they'll cut to fuzz).I *love* these phones for just about everything else...listening to music, watching movies, playing video games, etc. Sound is just terrific, full and very clear.I'm no audiophile, but I do produce professional sound & video from time to time at work, and I've tried a lot of phones over the years. These stand out for their simple clarity at all frequencies, and I'd say they're known as an industry workhorse for a reason.The coil cable can be a bit of a pain, and after four years the earpads are starting to shred a bit. Very minor complaints given the sound quality.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Very nice reproduction of the sound from my digital piano.  They are quite comfortable, though I've not yet tried wearing them for extended periods.I notice that there is some faint white noise whenever I am not actively playing.  I tried them also with my Galaxy S7, with which there was zero extra noise - Very clear sound and they go completely silent when I pause the music - no no white noise or hissing whatsoever.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: My husband loves, loves, loves these headphones
review_body: This is his second pair in about a decade.  (The first pair still work fine but, they look a mess.)  They enhance the clarity of the music that he enjoys listening to.  He had me listen to a few familiar songs  like George Michael's "Father-Figure" and Eric Clapton's "Layla" and it was like i was listening to them for the first time.  They also have some external noise cancelling properties.He is a tech-guy so any headphones that distort sound or produce an artificial sound do not please him and he is a tough critic, but really likes these.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: I'm not disappointed. Definitely sound better than my previous headphones
review_body: This is my first pair of higher quality headphones, and for the most part, I'm not disappointed. Definitely sound better than my previous headphones.The bass, treble, and mid all seem pretty balanced, which I really like. I've noticed things in the mixes of my favorite songs that I've never heard before. It's been fun rediscovering all my favorite music again.Couple things to consider:1. If you like a lot of bass, this probably isn't the pair of cans for you. I'm sure there are others that are much bass heavier.2. These aren't the most comfortable if you're planning on listening for long periods of time. These start to hurt my ears after about 2.5 hours, which is a bit disappointing.Overall, if you're looking to get your first pair of nicer headphones and don't want to spend a ton of money, these are a good choice.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I bought these phones because I was in a temporary situation in which it was difficult to play my studio monitors at any volume, and I needed to do some preliminary cleaning up of tracks and mixing.  I've always had pretty poor results trying to eq or mix over phones, but these did very well, They sound flat, and have the required upper mid and high end detail needed for basic sound work.  The rough mixes I did transported quite well to loudspeakers.I understand the the ear pads do not always last long, and they are a little hot, but this is the price you pay for a good seal and outside sound insulation. In short, if you're looking for something that is reasonably flat, and reasonably emulates a pair of studio monitors, these are a good choice.  I personally like the sound of dead-flat monitors, but this may not be to eveyone's taste for home listening.  if you want hyped-up bass, or a nice "warm" sound with the high mids scooped out, these are probably not for you.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great Quality (both sound and actual headphone material)
review_body: This was fun purchase I decided to make. I am not too fond of ear plugs anymore (they just don't stay in my ears well.) I am in no means a musician who would require such professional grade headphones, but with money and influence from a movie, I decided to purchase these. I have no regrets. (btw, the movie is Pitch Perfect, it's the headphones that Anna Kenndrick's character uses.)They work very well. The sound quality is phenomenal. With just the headphones on, it provides roughly 40% noise cancellation, so the world around you will be slightly muffled, but then again these headphones aren't marketed for their noise reduction. Moving along, as I mentioned the sound quality is fantastic. The high tones and bass notes are very clear. All the sounds that it produces are very crisp and clear. Listening to music, you can hear nearly every beat/note and hear every lyric (as clearly as the artist is singing them).The only thing I'm not too fond of, is that they do get hot to wear. Because the material used for the padding is not very breathable. It gets quite hot when using them. If in a well air-conditioned room it's not as bad. But if you're walking outside with the sun casting death rays upon you, yea it'll get hot. Other than that minor nuisance they are phenomenal headphones that I have no regret purchasing. Also the price really isn't bad compared to other commercial brands (ex. Beats)
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great Sound but not for on the go users and wiring is terrible.
review_body: The headphones itself is great, the sound is crystal clear and it feels comfortable on your head. However it is a bit heavy and bulky, hard to carry around and the wires are very heavy and take up a lot of space. My biggest complaint is the wiring, it makes it hard to carry around and is very heavy as well. Don't even bother trying these headphone outside on the go, you need a lot of space to place the wiring otherwise the coiled area will start to sag and this can be a nuisance. The headphones are also too big so trying to hold it on your neck is very uncomfortable. I really wanted to like these headphones, I wanted to so bad, I'm not even able to return them anymore cause I took them out for a bit too long. Keep in mind however that I purchased this item with the main intent of using it on the go so perhaps this review maybe a bit biased as it's used purely for production and recording.-If you're looking for something to use at home, for recording, production or editing, I would recommend these. However if you're looking for a great pair of headphones to use on the go, look elsewhere.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I bought these headphones so I could read in my family room while my wife is watching her TV shows.  I previously had a pair of $200 SONY headphones until my son adopted them.  The SONY MDR7506 headphones put out great sound quality and are extremely comfortable to wear.  I was sold on these by reading the other reviews documenting their use by professionals, etc.  I have not been disappointed.  I like listening to classical music and jazz, and, as I have said I am extremely pleased with the sound and comfort.  My only concern, is that these phones may be somewhat fragile (see the other reviews:  wires disconnect, ear pads disintegrate, etc.) but I can see no reason that if I treat them gently they won't last quite a while.  I am NOT an expert on headphones, but these seem well worth the price.  And of course, Amazon delivered them in their usual punctual manner.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: They have a cult following for a reason...
review_body: I first wore a pair of 7506's in a college MIDI lab. 25 years later these headphones are still a first choice. I use these headphones daily and they sound great either flat or running through equalizers. If you appreciate the nuances of slight overtones in recordings or the crispness of chord changes in acoustic guitar recordings, you might hear a whole new layer with these or any of Sony's Professional MDR-75xx's. They are incredibly lightweight and comfortable for all day wear, sound good loud or soft, and no one questions if you heard things correctly if you are using a pair of these for pre or post production.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These are really the best sounding headphones I've ever owned and I've bought several that are more than 3x the price. And I'm not just comparing them with the usual suspects (or punching bags) Bose and Beats. These blow away the Sennheiser Momentums, for example, IMO.But the cord is annoying and the fit is pretty tight with glasses. Why can't someone make a headphone built like Bose QC's with a sound quality like 7506's? I'm tempted to get the newer Sony MDR 1R/A but apparently they have followed the trend into bassier, "warmer" sounding phones which mask the inferiority of mp3's. Say it ain't so.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Best headphones I have ever worn. I've been looking for the best headset for a long time. Bose was always too expensive though. Music quality is really important to me and other headphones are overpriced and constructed very cheaply. This is easily one of my favorite possessions and it was worth the price. A good alternate to Bose for those who want a great pair of headphones with a lower price tag. Might not have the noise canceling of Bose, but it has the symphonic gumption to be a real contender.P.S. I let my mother try them and she ended up buying herself a pair that night. lol
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: The best headphones I've ever owned
review_body: Best headphones I've ever owned. Totally neutral sound - no bass boost - no treble boost - just solid, neutral sound out of these. Just what you want to listen to any style of music. Use an EQ to adjust sound to enhance the music or recording you are listening to.Also, I find them extremely comfortable and they block out external noise well. I can wear them all day long with no issues. I find it refreshing that you can order parts for these when they start to wear out - which I haven't had to yet. Very durable, professional grade headphones. Don't pay more for flash, hype and gimmick. These are really great.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Excellent earphones at a reasonable price.
review_body: Wow.  I finally have a good set to earphones at a price I can afford.  I have been "making do" with some very inexpensive phones for several years.  These earphones really do the job right.  I did add replacement Wicked Cuhsions ear pads and that provides a tight fit over my ears.  Very happy with the end result.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: It's like listening to a symphony Hall wherever you are. I own a ton of headphones and these are my favorite for sound. The ear cushions are soft but they don't feel like they're going to last. These are the perfect headphones if your goal is to listen to music unmodified. The better the audio source quality, the better these are!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Since purchasing these headphones, I have gone through Audio Technica ATH-ANC7B's, Bose QC15's, Soul SL300's, and a host of budget headphones from Panasonic, Sennheiser, and Sony.  These headphones are by far the best.  The sound reproduction is true.  Unlike some of the other headphones I have used which were heavy at the low end, these are very good at all frequencies.  There is sound leak with these but that doesn't seem to be a huge problem.  I also like that the cord is very long so you can move around some with the headphones on and you don't have to worry about pulling on the connection with your stereo/ipod/computer or whatever.  Would definitely recommend these headphones to anyone looking for great sound at a reasonable price.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Very good sound reproduction, I am using for medium bandwidth streaming over mobile (think pandora and spotify mobile). I'm comparing the MDR7506 to standard $20-$40 over the ear headphones (SONY) and $50 in-ear buds (KLIPSCH, SKULLCANDY). Of course they are more expensive, so better sound is expected. But the amount of clarity and depth of sound reproduction was an excellent value for a $50 upgrade. Very happy with this purchase. I will try these versus comparably prices over-ear headphones and report back.Pros- clean, accurate, sound that does not sound "over-processed". I've heard subtleties in the tracks (notably the vocals and drums) that were not there with other phones I've tried.Cons - heavier weight and lower portability may make it slightly uncomfortable for listening while laying down. Minor con, the large size of the diaphragm and resulting better overall sound is totally worth the slight inconvenience.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I am going to cut to the point after reading sooooo many reviews about headphones.  What you hear is dependent on so many factors I won't go into the specifications of these but say they are and have been my go to headphones.  The specs are very respectable.  They are extremely comfortable, lightweight and not tight.  I have monitors that are very 'true' and I would compare these with the monitors.  There is little coloring even at high levels.  You can get some distortion though at very high levels.  Like I have said, how you hear things is very personal and has a lot of variation from person to person.  For me these have fit what I needed perfectly.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: How can you go wrong?  These are great.  Buy them  . . . . NOW
review_body: These are simply awesome headphones.  They are exceedingly comfortable, sound superb, and are fairly cheap.  I wear them on a large university campus and enjoy having folks try them and compare to their many hundreds of dollars Beats units.  The look on their face usually says it all as they then gag when I tell them the price for these fine units.These are very true to sound and allow you to hear nuance in music which is missing from lesser headphones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone
