review_body: I was worried by the number of reviews that stated they would be uncomfortably hot for extended wear, but they are as comfortable as any over-the-ear phones.  Sound reproduction is very good.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great Cans At A Great Price!
review_body: I'll just add a simple comment to agree with the thousands of reviewers who rave about the audio quality and value that these phones deliver. So far, I love every thing about 'em. Even the way they're 'presented' in the packaging is impressive -- looks like a piece of fine jewelry in the box!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I recently purchased Sony's MDR7506 headphones, specifically because I was looking for headphones with good, accurate response.  The large diaphragm provides the excellent bass response for which I had hoped.  Unlike some other headphones that I've owned, these are lightweight (but seem plenty sturdy) and very comfortable to wear.  In fact, the over-ear design, padding, and overall comfort may even be more impressive than the sound.  And, even though these are by no means "noise-cancelling" headphones, the over-ear design does a decent job of blocking out low levels of noise.  I couldn't be happier about this purchase!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Excellent for normal people looking to upgrade
review_body: I'll start this off by saying that I am not an audio professional, and don't use these for anything audio quality critical tasks. I love these headphones. They were $80 when I got them, and they've been worth everything penny. They are extremely comfortable and can be worn for hours at a time without  becoming irritating or uncomfortable. A big part of that is the ear pads. know some people have had problems with the quality of the pads, but I've had these since May and haven't had an issue. They sound very nice, very powerful and full compared to the crappy ear buds I've used in the past. I they also cut out a lot of outside noise. I love that they fold up and become very compact. Case star makes a very nice case for these headphones that I would highly recommend.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Awesome phones. I mostly listen Rock, soft Rock, jazz and some rocky pop. I do not have an amp, just take it straight from line-out of the computer or ipod.Sound...Those who complain about low bass are likely just guys that are used to exaggerated bass of apple ipod products and corresponding ear-buds. I found the sound to be very balanced, everything is in the right place. In my ipod I had to turn down the bass ! My only concern is a slight exaggeration of some high frequency tones as in some rock songs the hihats and cymbals are a bit too pronounced (for my taste). Sony MDR7506 is unforgiving for the quality of recording, low quality/low bitrate music (like in some online radio stations or youtube) will be a pain to listen in these ones... not that you would do it by choice anyway.Comfort ... I am wearing them now at work when I am working on my computer and it is not tiring at all. I can wear them all day.I tried to replace the earcushions to velour once, as the leder-like material makes my head sweat ,  but it made everything much worse: sound, comfort, isolation from outside world. Back to stock ones.Quality ... I do not have this set for too long to tell for sure, but I can tell from the way things are constructed ... it will last. Most of hinges are made from metal. I was glad that Sony is not touched by the plastic disease of the modern era. Whatever is build from plastic is of high quality and looks very durable.Overall, I am a very happy listener.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Balanced sound, the way it should be!
review_body: Balanced sound, the way it should be! the reviews on this are accurate for this headphone, great sound and noise canceling, not overly bassy, but if you want bass that's what an EQ is for right?  I paired this with a Creative Sound Blaster Omni Surround 5.1 USB Sound Card with High Performance Headphone Amp and Integrated Beam Forming Microphone and Mod Mic to replace my Astro A50's (First Gen), I may not be a professional studio audio tech but this has been a great experience.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I received these headphones a few hours ago an haven't taken them off yet. They're really excellent considering they only cost $100. I love the metal parts like the plug and driver housing. They fold well and are rather compact when folded. I like everything about these headphones except one thing: the ridiculously long cord. This cord could only be desired if you needed to plug your headphones into a device that's halfway across the country. If mobile listening is important to you, you might want to consider another option. The cord is around 5.5 feet long coiled, but can stretch out to around ten feet. Still, excellent sound. The included bag is nice looking. All in all great headphones. I'd easily pay double for the remarkable build quality and sound that these headphones have.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: As a former semi-audiophile I have always had semi-high end audio gear and I had a hard time making the transition to portable digital audio. I think I have finally found a good compromise with these Sony MDR7506 phones. First of all, I import all my music with a lossless codec (file size be damned). I do not need every recording I own on my player at the same time. And I have always felt that when listening to music I want to hear the music as it was recorded and not the device that is producing the sound. The headphones (or the speakers) should be transparent. To a large extent these Sony phones accomplish that. They have exceptional clarity and detail through all frequency ranges with a natural organic sound and minimal coloration.  And when I can hear the picks on the strings and the rosin on the bows, I know I am in the right place. I also find them comfortable for extended wear and like that the cord is coiled and not too long. I cannot imagine anything much better in this price range and would recommend these without reservation.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Super headset.  The sound quality is outstanding!
review_body: Aug 26, 2018 update:  I have used these for almost 3 years and are still excellent!  My wife likes to watch streaming video with the sound up rather loud.  These allow me to listen to music, videos, classes, etc. at the same time.  the sound isolation is good and the the sound quality is incredible.  I highly recommend them.Super headset.  The sound quality is outstanding!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: They are amazing quality, great sound, did up nicely to fit in the small carrying bag. The sound is loud and clear.**Edited**Heavy, not so much for everyday New York City lifestyle. However, it's still amazing. The sound gets better with use. Hubby is using them for sound editing/mastering in Film School. He loves them. The best you can get, especially at the price you pay. I highly recommend.

They don't have the sound of a pair of Beats, but they're close and you won't freak out if you drop them because they don't cost a whole paycheck. My only problem with them is that they crush my ears and it hurts to keep them on for extended periods of time. And I don't have particularly big ears.

I love that the cord is spiralled, because it doesn't get tangled between uses. Oh, and the sound is great through them. I use them in my music studio. They have replaced my Sennheiser headphones, which I also loved but which weren't nearly as comfortable or sturdily built (the head band cracked and snapped).

review_title: Awesome.  Don't Fix What Isn't Broken.
review_body: I was tired of breaking headphone cables because they were too thin and flimsy.  I'd also heard the MDR7506's provided excellent value.  I bought them and couldn't be happier, the sound quality is excellent and the headphones are comfortable.  I have no fear that I'm going to break the wiring inside the cable, it's very thick and nicely coiled.  If you're looking for a pair of durable headphones at a good price with great sound quality, you need MDR7506's.  There is a reason they haven't changed since 1991.  Would not recommend for exercise.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: The sound is pretty good, the comfort is OK
review_body: I wouldn't buy these for your iPod.  I believe the structure yanked the headphone jack out of my iPod.  The sound is pretty good, the comfort is OK.  In hindsight, I would have went elsewhere.  If you're buying these to mix and master tracks, then I recommend them.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I don't write many reviews but I felt like I should for this one.  Like the title says, these are great for the price.  I have a pair of Audio Technica ATH-M50 and I think those sound the best for a reasonably priced, $140, set of studio headphones, they're way better than Beats which are over-priced hype.  I also have a ATH-M40fs, a pair of AKG k240 (which are soft on volume when used with a digital source like a computer, best for analog sources)  and now this pair of SONY MDR7506.  For the price these SONY's are far and away the best of the group.  The M50's sound a little better but cost almost twice as much.  If you want a great pair of studio headphones my first choice is the ATH-M50's.  If you want a pretty close second that costs a lot less, get these.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Definitely professional quality and that’s definitely a good thing. Used daily for video editing. Cable coil is long, so plenty of reach (wireless option would be cool, if they don’t already make one)

review_body: I really like these headphones. They’re very comfortable while wearing for long periods of time and the sound quality is great for the price. They do fit kind of loose which is why they’re so comfortable, but if I move around a lot I find myself having to readjust them periodically.

review_body: After about a year, the right side of the headphones stopped working. It seems like it's impossible to file a warranty claim with Sony or Amazon. I'd strongly prefer to repair these, but I'll have to buy another pair of headphones and throw these away. Not exactly what you'd expect from professional headphones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I've owned Sony MDR headphones longer than I can remember.  The last pair lasted nearly 10 years and sounded great up until the end.  I'm no audiophile so I'm not going to pretend to talk audio tech in this review.  They're solid headphones that sound great and last forever.As a software developer so I'm constantly taking these off and putting them on.  They provide a perfect isolation from the noise of the hustle and bustle of a busy office.  Often I'd find myself wearing them with no music, just because the silence they offer is a welcome treat from time to time.  They've been dropped more times than I can count, and no matter where I positioned it, I managed to roll over the cord with my desk chair almost daily.  Despite the abuse, they've been the highest quality and most comfortable headphone I've ever owned.Not sure why I'd anyone would three times as much for flashy headphones by popular rap stars, other than the "cool" factor.  Save your money and buy a quality product for less.  The Sony MDR headphones are perfect.

review_body: I have to agree with the other reviewers: these are wonderful headphones.I love the sound so much, that I now wear them when performing my live show.  With these headphones, I can quickly dial-in such things as the vocal/guitar balance, the vocal and guitar effects, and (perhaps more importantly) I can finally hear the nuances of my vocal and instrument performance. review_body: These have been my daily headphones at home & at work for a couple years now. They're awesome, and rock solid.First, the sound quality on these is excellent: well balanced, clear and probably suitable no matter what you're listening to.Second, you're probably not going to find anything that sounds better until you start spending a lot, lot more money. Yes, there are better headphones around, but they are a *lot* more expensive.Bonus: these fold up pretty well and don't weigh too much, so they're fairly portable.Bottom line, unless you're budget is more like $400-500, these are the best over ears you're going to find.

review_body: I was recommended these by a headphone enthusiast who uses headphones costing over a thousand dollars and they do not disappoint! Big, beautiful sound, Sony quality, and light & comfortable. I can't believe Sony charges so little for these great 'phones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone
review_body: Good headphones.  Sound is clear, no exagerated bass or anything.  Slight pressure point on the top of my head, might be the shape of my head, but massaged the head band and fits nicely now.  Out of curiosity plugged in my iPod Nano and it worked great with it.  Use it to watch movies late at night.  Wish the ear cups were a little bigger.5-2013About a year later the headset is deteriorating.  Pads are peeling and coming off the foam backing, and I HATE the trapeze monkey motion the ear cups are mounted on.  Little pieces of plastic break off of it.  This is not a quality product made to last, I should have bought something else.  No more Sony headsets for me...
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These headphones are great, especially for sub $100. Sound seems flat and have a good response at all frequencies. These are not boomy but yet can produce low and detailed bass.  No need for an amp, the low impedance makes these great even for portable devices. They are light and I don't notice any discomfort after several hours of wearing them. For around the ear type headphones they are also not big or unsightly.  I have owned several headphones at this price range and so far like these the best.  I also like the even and accurate sound they produce over my friends more expensive (+100) Audio Technica, Bose and Senn's. I am picking up a second pair for the office so I don't have to carry them back and forth. BTW, these are closed headphones meaning they block out sound around you and do not bleed sound out. They are good enough that at a fairly high volume no one will know what you are listening to or the volume they are at. This is a plus for when I use them at work or in bed. I am not saying they are noise cancelling, but if your looking to be more aware of your environment I suggest an open air style headphone over these.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: No, they are not the flattest sound, but that's no reason to not use these for mixing and editing.  You can get a good sound out of these and know that it will sound good on any headphone or earbud
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Not going to find much better for less than 3 times the cost. My decision finally came down between these and the Audio Technica ATH M50 at $40 more. Which is better? I can't say and most of use probably can't tell anyways.Keep an eye out, I frequently see these being worn by professionals in behind the scenes, making of type videos unlike the ones with the B on the side you see being worn by paid endorsers and individuals with more money than desire to research headphones
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Great headphones for the price. Exactly what I was looking for.
review_body: I bought these primarily to plug into my receiver so I can watch the big screen after my wife goes to bed. I've since started using them to play video games (PC). article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: The Sony MDR7506's have a fantastic, if not almost true to life, sound. They sit comfortably on my large melon and the length (and spiral design) of the cord is most convenient without being too obnoxiously long. The build quality feels sturdy enough to last some years, and the ability to reposition the cans to lay on my fiance's pregnant belly to pipe some music to my baby girl was a nice plus.As usual, my experience with Amazon's shipping was AAA+ and it actually arrived before schedule (though I missed the initial UPS delivery while at work). I'm more than satisfied with the value received for the price paid.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I have had these headphones for four years, they still sound and feel as good as the day I got them. Sound is remarkable, like being there. I have worn these for hours with no ear pain or discomfort of any kind. I have had many different brands and type of head phones, these top them all, for almost any price. Bose sets are far over priced for about the same or less sound quality. These are the best I have ever had for sound reproduction of mostly classic rock. Will buy another set when these where out, if they ever do. I do treat them with the respect and care such an important part of my music experience deserves, they have not fell apart or one side stopped working as others have said, you need to just treat them like a fine piece of equipment they are, they are not meant to be thrown around and the wiring tugged on, they are not a toy. For anyone that appreciates good sound of their music these are the ones to get. Buy them and sit back and enjoy.Update : I have now had these for {8} years, still the best sound I've ever heard in head phones !
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

They have been comfortable to wear for long periods and fit around my ears perfectly. If you have larger ears this may not be the case. review_body: i really like these headphones. You can hear all the details of the source signal clearly without the sound being colored. Many headphones change the sound of the signal making them overly bright or extremely bassy. Also, the screw on 1/4" plug screws on tightly and stays that way providing a solid connection eliminating the dropouts and static in sound I have experienced with other headphone adapters. I am very glad I purchased this item.

review_title: Great sound, dissapointed that they broke.
review_body: I bought these for 172$ roughly three years ago, and now they are broken.I have had lovely times with these headphones, the best i have owned so far ,- I have not had many phones and none cost above 40 dollars, so i cannot really compare.When i first heard them, i though they were too good, i mean, i heard the flaws in the mixing, and had to equalize the music when i heard certain songs in my computer.It was very special, borderline fun, but also a pain in the beginning - it might be because they were brand new, or that i just had to adjust my ears from mediocre sound to good.My music-taste is very, very broad, and i see no particular music these fit for, it seems to be an all-rounder.Some songs can be a bit descant, almost piercing - but i have never been too much into sharper soprano-music, and as i said, i often use a equalizing-program.Bass is pretty good in these phones, not perfect - but better than my computer-speakers.All is about taste in sound, these will not fit everyone - what i can say is that both my sister and mother got jealous of these, so that says something.Yesterday it happened, the left channel left me, only to return, and leave me again.I think that it was a bit soon for phones in this price-class, at least when i bought it.Now i see that the price is about half of what i payed for, i also had to pay a juicy bill to customs.The price i payed was a total of 219$. I would not pay that price for these again.Now these sell half the price - and they are worth it!I will not buy another pair of Sony-phones, because Sony builds a lot of electronics - none of them built to last, sadly.As with a lot of other mainstream-brands.To sum up: Worth the price, but they will not last - if you want something you can have for years and years i recommend to check out the audio-devoted brands instead.I would recommend that actually, before you buy these - that's where im going next.Goodbye Sony - we've had some beautiful times, but quite a short romance.Have a nice day, friends!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I didn't realize music could sound this good!  I am amazed at the clarity and the overall quality of the sound which these headphones provide! review_body: This is the first headphone of its type that I've owned. Prior to this, I'd bought into the Bose marketing and sprung for the over the ear designs. Compared to my Shure IEMs, the sound is more neutral (Shure it turns out lean more towards the bassy side). It is comfortable to wear for extended periods of time although I imagine that in the summer, it might tend towards the hot side. I will update this review should any issues arise.

review_title: Unbalanced frequency range, fit uncomfortable (for woman)
review_body: Overall, I can tell these headphones are high-quality. I had a few complaints that ended up being significant enough that I returned these, however. First of all, I was surprised to read the reviews about how comfortable these are... perhaps it is the size or shape of my head but they were incredibly uncomfortable for me. The head band sat directly on top of the crown of my head and didn't provide enough cushion to keep from having a constant awareness it was pressing firmly on a specific spot. Maybe I have a pointy head. I am a women so maybe my head is smaller than the average user's. Either way, I wanted so badly to dismiss this, but after wearing them for an extended period, I just couldn't.My other complaint was what seemed to be unbalanced levels. Treble was really hot and forward while bass seemed never to be forward enough. The brightness began to fatigue my ears after an hour or so. For certain kinds of editing/monitoring maybe this is what you want, but if you also want to rotate these as casual listening headphones too, I would steer elsewhere.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Hi, my name is Enrique. Let me tell you my story.I come mostly from in-ear headphones, as I run, walk and travel several miles/kilometers per week.I enjoy listening to music, talk shows and TV series. But I personally prefer a good set of speakers than headphones. Or at least I used to! Generally, I listen with headphones when I feel speakers bother my girlfriend or coworkers, but with these headphones: no more!My relationship with Sony headphones is vast but always on the lower price range. I've been with the brand since the late nineties. I've tested some of them and most of the times they lasted long enough for me to feel like it was time to get a replacement.Lately, however, I've switched brands. First with the Sennheiser CX-300 II (broke them in less than a year, cable problems) and the more expensive (but rather cold) Etymotic Research MC5 (didn't enjoy them, they hurt my ears).Now I decided that I should get a new set to use in the office (about 3 times a week, as I work twice from home) and leave them there.I received them two weeks ago and I noticed Sony's copyright is from 1994! These are almost 20 years old! And they sound better that anything I've tested before.I tell you, it is impossible to leave them! I can't listen to any other headphones if I know I can use these ones. They are incredible!Sound quality is so clean and natural, whenever you try others, you'll feel them artificial or unbalanced.These are perfect cans for the money and I feel my only upgrades are at least twice the money (as the Audio Technica ATH-M50 or the Beyerdynamic  DT770).They sound neat, mostly strong in the middle, good on bass (but not excessive) and perhaps a bit bright on the high side, but the overall result is amazing.Sometimes my ears get a tad hot, but I got used to it. My next upgrade are the Beyer EDT 250 pads, I've read that they help with the heat problem.I walk with them on, no problem at all.I love the long, strong and coiled cord. I am not afraid of breaking it, which is always a worry with the in-ears.The whole package feels and looks sturdy.Best choice I have ever made. 100% Recommended buy. Stop reading. Go buy them.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: The previous reviews on the Sony MDF-7506 headphones are pretty spot on. These headphones deliver about the most clean, accurate audio reproduction I have ever heard, throughout the entire frequency range.The audio seal around the area is amusingly superb. You can be standing right in front of someone, see their mouth moving and it's like they are miming. If you set the headphones to a pretty nice, full volume, and then take them off and allow the two ear cups to close against each other, the music disappears, demonstrating how good the audio seal is around the ear cups when they are on your head.  I think this really helps with allowing the sound reproduction to reach your ear drum without contamination from outside noise.I use these for audio monitoring mostly for video production professionally, but I can't help but use them for music while working at my desk.There is ONE minor complaint I have. There is a little Achilles heal with the wire going from the headband to the ear pieces. It seems contemporary technology and engineering should be able to hide/contain/conceal them without so much external exposure without quality loss. But alas, certainly makes me watch for snag and catches on the wires as I shuffle them around. I wish the wires were more concealed. But because of the way I use them (I am not continually packing them for travel or things like that), it does not hamper my usage of them, hence I keep 5 stars.Considering the cost, these headphones could easily be double the cost and still be an outstanding value. At < $100, these are a steal. Don't sink time into comparing, just buy these.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: It's really difficult to decide what pair of headphones you need. There are so many options out there, it's a bit bewildering. Thankfully, the mdr7506's can come to your rescue. I'm not an audiophile, but that doesn't mean I'm not a discerning listener. I was just an average college student, looking for good vibrations on the cheap. It was basically between these and the senns that are in this price range (280?). I decided to go with these, and I haven't regretted that decision yet.These cans are pretty comfortable to wear. My ears do tend to get hot for extended listening sessions, but it never gets to be uncomfortable. It is like a breath of fresh air when you take them off though. The 7506's are made very, very well. I won't go into any technical details, since you can read those for yourself. I can't imagine them breaking down unless I sit on them or something. Their quality is vastly to superior to my friend's Bose triports. His look like a toy compared to mine. I love the professional quality of the cable. This may seem like a minor issue, but it's really very important. the cable doesn't really pick up any noise from banging it up against a desk or wall for instance. It's also very thick. I hate those flimsy, thin cables found on lower quality headphones. I also like the fact that it connects to the headphones through only the left side, instead of both. I wasn't a big fan of the telephone-like design at first, but it's much better than having a really long cord. The padding is fairly comfortable, and the best I've every experienced on around the ear headphones. The headphones also do a nice job of filtering out external noises.The sound quality is great. The sounds is flat, but this isn't a bad thing. This leaves all of the tweaking up to you, unlike other competing brands ::coughBosecough::. the bass is pretty healthy on these headphones, and you can of course get more juice out of them by adjusting the bass levels of your songs. The sound is very clear, with a good representation from the lows, mids and highs. It has really brought my music to life. There were so many details I had never heard using cheap phones. You will be motivated to go back an re-rip all of your music at a higher quality, because these phones will make any low quality rips PAINFULLY obvious. I've stopped listening to some of the songs that I couldn't re-rip because it was basically torture.These are great pair of headphones, and probably the best pair you can get without spending at least $100 more.*why a 4 rating? Well nothing is perfect, and I anticipate that the padding will eventually start to shed over time, as all good Sony headphones do.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I just bought the 7506s to compare them with the Shure SRH840s I also bought. The radio gives these cans a real workout, just like they do the 840s, when I'm trying to pull faint signals out of the ether, but I love both sets.  Right now it's a toss up: the 840s are noticeably heavier, and I'll use them more for quiet listening and for studio work; the 7506s will get used as I move around the radio gear and laptop late at night working distant stations.

review_title: I tend to hate closed (vs padded but open open ear) headphone sound
review_body: I bought for home studio seeking non colored  mixing EQ reference, and sound leakage containment for recording.  I thought they would be accurate but somewhat sterile sounding.  I tend to hate closed (vs padded but open open ear) headphone sound.  To my surprise they sound really good for a closed headphone at very affordable price point.  My only compliant s the ear cups are a bit small and that can be  uncomfortable if used for 3 or more hours - same for almost any closed design. article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I purchases these 'phones because I've started listening to a different genre of music that features very low frequencies and the ol' laptop speakers weren't cutting it. I read the reviews and the ratings and this product seems to be the strongest for the price.I haven't been disappointed. I work in a sometimes-noisy office and they do a great job of blocking out external noise. I have a big head (an Irish potato head as it's been called) and these fit comfortably for long periods. If you need to wear them for more than 3 or 4 hours straight, the tops of your ears may ache a tiny bit, but they're well designed and nicely padded.The headphones themselves have a solid feel to them. The earpads are soft and the whole unit just feels like something that's intended to hang around for a while. One note on the look of the product; they are studio monitor headphones and that is printed in gold lettering across the top of the headband. But hey, I get to look like I'm running a sound board for a band. The fact that they fold into themselves (the ear pads come together and push up toward the head band) is a plus, though I don't know how much use I'll get out of the pleather carrying bag.The drivers are very responsive and efficient. Between the insulation from outside noise and the excellent quality of these large drivers, you can turn the volume of your source down quite a bit and still get plenty of sound. There aren't any noticeable holes in response and both bass and treble is handled equally well.I highly recommend these if you're looking for reasonably-priced audiophile gear.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Perfect sound and perfect comfort.  Best money I've spent in my setup yet.

review_body: I bought these because of their rock solid performance. review_title: Excellent sound and works great with behind-the-ear hearing aids
review_body: Absolutely wonderful audio coming out of these things. You'll be able to hear things you couldn't hear through your speakers.You'll hear all the notes, not just "boomin' bass," which makes them an excellent choice for professional sound mixing. Although I'm no longer in radio, I wanted professional-quality headphones and needed something that fit over my ears because I wear a behind-the-ear hearing aid (the hearing aid mic is behind my ear, not in it) -- and they fit great! I  can use these at work for listening to training videos and conference calls. And at home, they're delightful for gaming because they pick up all the nuances of detailed soundscapes in the games, making it much easier to detect something/someone sneaking up on you.

review_title: Great Headphones For The Beginning Serious Music Fanatic!!!
review_body: You're considering slipping Bose or Beats your credit card money but you thought to Google some cheaper yet effective alternatives to see if you even need "Audiophile" grade headphones and you keep hearing about these bad boys.I was in a similar boat awhile ago where I almost gave in to the name brand plan of payments to my carrier for great sound and remembered the pair of headphones that started it all which were probably an older version of these.I purchased these and I was back into a land of no regrets high end audio and was happy, but if you're an audiophile already or you're just beginning you may have some questions about these. So let's rate.Comfort: As far as high end over the ear headphones go that are noise reducing these are very comfortable. The metal band makes adjustment easy and you won't have to fiddle with them too much.Design: The coiled cord design is the usual for a studio monitor so mobile it may not make sense to have. The ear cushions aren't water proof either. These were designed for professional studio monitoring and are often used by live sound guys on the sound board. They have a low OhM so most sound cards can drive these without much of a problem. If you're just looking for nice sounding audio without the extra stuff these will serve you well.Sound: This will wildly depend on your sources of audio and your soundcard. Mobile devices such as laptops and phones don't usually come with digital to analog converters DACS to really bring out the functionality of high end headphones and most streaming services have low quality streams. Things you couldn't hear in cheap ear buds will now be apparent so you'll have to update your music collection and how you listen to it if you want to walk down the road of the audiophile. However, these are at a low OhM resistance so you can just rely on your mobile sound cards if you like and it will still blow your mind.But What If I'm Already An Audiophile: Maybe you got a pair of Beats or Bose and heard there were better cheaper and nicer options on the market and these came up. What can you expect?Sound Signature: These aren't basehead cans. The bass is there but in products like beats the low end is over stated. Sony has always had a warm sound signature and engineers have even complained about the inauthentic emphasis on the high end and it hugs it in and gives it a nice warm hug. However, this is where no review on earth is going to help you as sound signature preferences are wildly different from ear to ear and without being able to test them yourself you'll be reading a lot of writer pros on the matter.  I love the warm sound signature of Sony and these guys really produce beautifully for acoustic music and vocals but they disappoint not in the low end as I'm not a bass head who needs my ears thumped off (which someone with beats might have experienced and gotten used to) but I do have one major complaint about these and it's sound stage. Sound Stage is important in Hi Fi and to me is one of the most important things. That's where I'd say pre existing music fans and audiophiles might have turmoil with these. They are flat for a reason, studio work, and they're not meant to be an expansive listening experience. Just a good one. Bose and Beats which is many people's start in this world have more soundstage and are built for enjoyment listening so if Sound Stage matters you need to consider the ATH 50x instead but those also favor the low end and have a colder sound signature.However these are fairly "inexpensive" headphones for what they can do. They produce beautiful audio, and they don't reprocess the music. I know most music lovers have at least one pair of these famous headphones in their home somewhere they are loathe to part with so that says a lot about them.My opinion is that getting a pair if these won't ever be a waste of money, and when or if you get upgradeitis these will still have a place and a use in your music equipment collection.For the price and the sound they product, the comfort, the mobility, and the accurate sound reproduction minus the milf emphasis on the high notes, these at edge absolute unrivaled best in their price range. Period.I truly recommend.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Honestly, I didn't think I would find a pair of headphones to replace my derelict MDR-V600's (now held together with much epoxy, super glue, and duct/electrical tape) but I have. The sound from these little babies (They're smaller than my previous headphones) is downright mind-blowing for their price. I honestly think other reviewers are right and that these shouls likely be 250-300$ headphones.The headphones themselves are circumaural, barely, and adjust easily to my head, even though I have a rather big head.The pressure from them rests evenly around my ears and presses only lightly on the lobes. After wearing them for 4 hours, they are still as comfortable as when I put them on.Speaking of those 4 hours, I've been putting these babies through their paces, and I'm amazed. Everything from Dubstep to Classical plays with beautiful quality, from deep, ear-throbbing bass to crystal-quality treble. The music is as clear as if I'm standing in front of the band/singer.All in all, outstanding 'phones, with sound as clear as polished crystal, for a price that won't shatter your glasses.

review_body: Background:  I got tired of all the mixed reviews of best “closed, around-ear” headphones fewer than $200, so I got  7 of the top recommended brands/models and decided for myself (luckily, they had a 15 – 30 day trial period).  I needed a “closed” headphone so NO sound (for listening enjoyment only) could be heard by people around me.  I’m somewhat of an audiophile and an ex-band director…so perfect sound is important to me (note: I listen to concert band, jazz, orchestral movie soundtracks, choral, classical, and even some pop/rock/country).  My “control” for testing was music from my iTunes Library (apple Lossless files) on my laptop with advanced soundcard.  I wanted to spend fewer than $200.  Here are the following results:1st place:  Audio-Technica ATH-M50x. (score:  90/100 points)  Pros –It does a variety of tasks really good with no real weakness at anything.  It’s best for listening enjoyment…not professional studio monitoring as advertised.  It has very warm sounding vocals, a balanced sound (with very slight favor to lower mid range & upper bass), and comfortable (loose) fit on my ears/head.  It handles thick, polyphonic music passages with ease without distortion…while keeping the main melody/vocals volume and tone quality still cutting through with warmth.  The sound feels like you’re in a very large professional concert hall!  People with large heads will appreciate the fit of these comfortable headphones.  Cons- Although you have the feel of being in a large concert hall, the distance to the stage seems a bit too far away…perhaps the 30th row.  These headphones are the highest price of those tested (around $170…ouch… but, it comes with 3 different chords to the headphones/ and bag).2nd Place:  Sennheiser HD 280 Pro. (score: 88/100 points)  Pros – Very balanced sound throughout the registers…no favors to any register!!!  It can be used for both studio monitoring or listening enjoyment.  The extra-deep bass extension can be “felt” during musical passages…nice.  This Headphone has as a very “live” performance sound…like you’re on the 5th row during a concert.  Best headphones for listening enjoyment under $100 (only $99!).  Cons – The tone of melody/vocals sound a bit thin or “electric” at times during thick/polyphonic textures in musical passages…especially male tenors and trumpet/alto sax solos.  Although you feel like you’re on the 5th row during a concert, it sounds like you’re in a small auditorium rather than a concert hall.  Fit may a bit tiring after a long period (good clamping pressure).3rd Place:  Sony MDR-7506.  (85/100points)  Pros - These headphones must be the best at studio monitoring…or when you need to be critical and “dissect” music…every detail can be heard throughout every register (you can even hear faults in the recording you never wanted to hear before).  The sound feels like you’re in a closed room with a live band)...not a performance concert hall/auditorium (there is a lack of reverb) good for recording professionals (and only $86!).  Very clean and articulate at the “attacks” of instrument/vocal notes (not much sustain with these headphones) throughout all of the registers.  Cons – Very bright sound…taxing to the ears after a while (Treble is very pronounced).  Must use an equalizer to add bass/warmth to the sound for listening enjoyment...Yes it’s a pain, but then they do sound good after those adjustments.4th Place:  Bose SoundTrue, Around Ear. (80/100 points)  Pros – These headphones have a good, balanced sound throughout the registers (Note: you will have to turn up the volume on these headphones).  They are very comfortable and “light” on the head….you almost forget you have the headphones on.  Cons – Sound is very “speaker” sounding...like you’re at a concert to hear your favorite band  in the 50th row, but the stage is full of speakers playing CD recordings of your favorite band; therefore, there is just too much distance from you to the stage.  Price is too much for this headphone ($150).5th Place:  Koss SP540. (75/100 points)  Pros – These headphones are very cool looking, and somewhat comfortable (I have normal/smaller ears).  The sound is not balanced…favors the bass/mids…good for rock/rap lovers.  Mids and treble sounds have been somewhat muffled…so the bass and lower mids “boom” throughout your music.  Cons – Feels like you’re sitting behind the band at a concert.  Not worth the $150 price tag.  Note:  I have a Koss 35 Pro A and love the sound of these headphones (but they are half-open designed, not fully closed) and I hoped these sp540 models could compete…disappointed.6th Place:  JBL J88a.  (68/100 points)  Pros – These headphones are the most comfortable…no competition in this department!  Bass is very heavy….rap/rock lovers will appreciate these headphones.  Cons – The mids and trebles have been purposely muffled…almost non-existent...feels like you’re sitting behind the band during a concert (with cotton in your ears).  Price is good ($99), but come on…try to have some balance throughout the registers.7th place:  Grado SR125. (65/100 points)  Note:  This is the headphone I’ve had for a couple years...and why I started a search for a better headphone.  They are not what I needed because they are “open designed”…thus, people around you can hear them.  Pros – Very crisp and clear mids and trebles…you can hear every detail.  Comfortable fit.  Cons – no bass what-so-ever…thus, bright and airy sound only.  It feels like you’re sitting on the 75th row at a concert!  These headphones are rather expensive (around $120 bucks when I bought them 2 years ago…$150 today).

review_title: I know why so many pros use these headphones
review_body: These cans combine clear, detailed sound, phenomenal durability and a great price. That's why broadcasters like me use them (several people I work with are MDR-7506 owners), as do engineers in recording studios and film and TV soundpeople. These 'phones are almost identical to the MDR-V6, but there are differences that go beyond the cosmetic. The 7506's internal wiring is a bit different, using a separate ground for the left and right channels, rather than the single ground for both channels used in the V6. I like the sound of both 'phones, so I bought both. To my ears, this difference in the wiring gives the 7506's better stereo separation and a more open sound, but the V6's sound a bit "warmer". All in all, great headphones--I just wish they were somewhat looser on my size 7 and three-quarters head!! They do seem to be loosening up a bit. Maybe they just need more time. Love the solid construction. I got the V6's first, on the recommendation of a former co-worker who told me he's still doing his daily airshift with the same cans, after 20 YEARS. A current co-worker let me try his 7506's, and I said, "Gotta have these, too". I highly recommend both.

review_body: I've been somewhat of a fan of Sony headphones for a while, my first pair being the MDR-V150 back in 2006 for $20. I remember at the time thinking how much better those were than anything I had before. A year ago (2011), I had bought the ZX-100 and had that same feeling all over again. I felt everything just had a lot more punch to it with deeper bass and higher highs.The first time I used these was at a friend's graduation party in June of 2012 where he was showing off a game his team had made at Digipen. I put these on and was instantly taken aback by how well the 7506's sealed out the outside world. I fired up the game, and knew right away these headphones were something special. Deep, heart-jolting base... crystal clear highs... simply beautiful. I can't recommend these highly enough. If you're in the market for a decent pair of higher end cans, these NEED to be on your list of considerations. You won't be disappointed.

review_title: An excellent starting point if you want to embrace active hi-fi music listening.
review_body: I don't work in audio engineering and I'm not a well trained music listener (yet), but I bought these headphones anyway because I needed something really good to start with. I wasn't satisfied with in-the-ear and mass market consumer headphones mainly because of the sound quality and general discomfort after briefly using them. So I did extensive research and ultimately it came down to the Sony MDR-7506 headphones.The quality of sound and comfort is the best that I have experienced so far. Since these headphones are capable of near-complete representation of music, I was able to hear more nuances in music with these headphones compared to regular headphones aimed at consumers.From what other reviewers have said, the ear cups of these headphones may tear and wear out easily. I don't have this problem yet, but fortunately the earcups are replaceable. In the package there's a service card that lists all the replacement part numbers in case something breaks.More importantly, these are analog headphones, regardless of what the big print on the packaging says. Therefore, the quality of sound may vary depending on what hardware you connect the headphones to. However, that doesn't make these headphones inferior. In fact, all other competing professional audio headphones operate on an analog signal. You just have to pay attention to the impedance, which is measured in ohms. This particular model, the MDR-7506, has an impedance rating of 63 ohms at 1 kHz, which happens to be adequate for most computers and audio equipment. But if you want to maximize audio quality even further, you have to connect these headphones into a standalone "headphone amplifier" or a similar device that enhances the analog signal strength. This is not necessary for most people, because the audio quality will most likely be already hi-fi on your hardware. But in rare circumstances or in the recording studio, it may be necessary.These headphones are NOT limited to audio engineers / professional use. They are equally appropriate to amateurs who want to embrace active music listening as well as learning technical stuff. I recommend these headphones to anyone who wants to actively listen to hi-fi music.

review_body: The Sony MDR7506 has not disappointed.  Though not a professional musician of any type, I like clear, crisp sound and reliable headphones. The cushioning over the ears is comfortable and never heavy except after hours of wearing.  The cord is extremely long and I often have to throw it over my back when wandering around the house -- they're made for more professional use, I suppose.  But I am more than happy with the Sony MDR7506 and would easily recommend.

review_body: These are pretty much the standard for videography.  Monitoring audio is essential while shooting; no one wants to go over footage later and discover that the picture's great but the sound was ruined.  There is no pair of headphones that are "the best" for everything.  Different things require different cans, lnd these are great for making speech sound crisp.  If you're in the studio mixing an opera track, maybe a different pair is in order.  If you're just listening to your ipod, you can probably get a cheaper pair.The construction seems pretty durable and the whole things comes in a little bag so that they don't get too dirty (important for me since they're banging around with a bunch of other gear all the time.  The headphones fold up into the head strap to make them even more compact and there's an 1/8" to 1/4" adapter that screws in.All in all a great pair.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Good sound quality but with design flaws
review_body: I use these headphones to DJ electronic music. They can be cranked to high volume without sound distortion, and of course they sound great at normal volumes. I have no complaints about sound quality, but about the headphone's design.First, they fit a little snug against the head (and my head is even fairly skinny). They are, however, better than Technics' line of DJ headphones. Those really squeezed my noggin!Also, as several people have noted, your ears get a little sweaty after wearing these for awhile. Not a big deal, but it's a little uncomfortable. And some theorize that sweat causes the earcups to break down prematurely.My biggest complaint about the 7506's design is that one of the foam ear cups came off less than a month after purchase. The cup can be put back on, but not without some hassle. It stays on for several days/weeks but then will come off again (seemingly at the most inconvenient time!).I highly recommend these headphones for their sound quality. But expect problems with the earcups. There's a chance they will either shred over time or come off entirely. No wonder replacement ear cups are so readily advertised on Amazon!

review_body: Some of the most accurate sound reproduction you can get in a headphone for less than $100. review_body: I love these headphones - I have been using them since 2007.Major advantages:- wonderful, reference quality sound- low impedance - they will work with almost any device and will sound good without headphone amplifier- super portable - they fold up (unlike most others) into a very portable package, and also come with a little case - very convenient- super durable - the material of the headphones, besides the ear cushions, is top notchDo yourself a favor and replace the ear cushions with "Beyerdynamic EDT 250 Velour Padded Earcushions" - this made the already "great" headphones become "awesome." review_body: Chances are if you are reading this review, you have read far, and I'm sure I won't tell you anything that you haven't figured out by now, but here is my two-cents worth:I just received these phones today (9/24/2013) and I have been using them for about 6 hours as of the time of this review. I am very impressed with these Sony's. The sound reproduction is excellent, and there is no distortion at high volumes. The lows are there as they were intended, and the mids and highs are crystal clear. It is also worth noting that they are fairly comfortable. They warm my ears a little bit, but nothing bad. Otherwise once you have them adjusted, you can hardly tell that they are on.I consider myself a bit of an audiophile, and I enjoy good sounding music. These 7506's are the first that I looked at, followed by the V6's. These isn't much of a difference for the "average" listener, but the V6's do offer more on the low end and are a little more "warm" in that regard. The 7506's are sharper. Overall, I prefer the 7506 more, and they are really just a newer version of the V6. At the time I purchased these, the 7506 was about $15-$20 cheaper, so based on what I heard testing, I went with these. If you are debating the 7506 vs. the V6, I would go with whatever is cheaper at the time. For under $100, these are arguably the BEST you can buy.If you are wondering about all of the "break-in" stuff, I personally don't believe in it, but everyone has their own opinion. To "break-in" any headphone, I just use them how I normally intend to use them. Overtime, you can pick out minor differences with listening time, but that is just your ears getting used to the sound. Break-in or not is up to you, again I don't believe in 100 or more hours of breaking-in with special tracks, just use them how you will use them.I use these on my computer, Sony CD burner, iPod classic, Samsung Galaxy Note 2, as well as my old LXI series stereo from Sears with a separate amp and EQ. The best sound comes from either the CD burner or the stereo, but those have more power output compared to a computer or iPod. However, these headphones also work well when powered by a computer or iPod. However, if you are using these with MP3's or others of the like, you MUST make sure that you have a good quality file. 128kbps is the MINIMUM! If you have the room, go for 320kbps MP3 or a "lossless" file. These phones will ruin a poor quality file. The best way is to either rip a CD in 320 or lossless or buy high-quality MP3. I don't encourage illegally downloading music, but if you do, that's your choice. Just make sure it is a good, large file or you will regret it.Well, I think that should finish my review. I hope you found it helpful and if there are any other questions I haven't answered, ask me.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: My brother recommended this product. He's an on-air radio personality in LA and uses them constantly. He says they hold up very well in day to day studio abuse and keep on delivering quality sound. These are my second pair of Sonys, but a slight upgrade. I mix a lot of original music via headsets and require something that delivers flat frequency response. The MDR-7506s are lightweight, built well and deliver well balanced, uncolored sound. I've also noticed I don't have to crank up my output source as with other phones.This product delivers what Sony claims and when these wear out, I will replace them with the same model.

review_title: Great for producers or any music lover
review_body: Got these only two days ago and I'm I'm extremely pleased with the headphones. The sounds are crisp, they're comfortable, and fairly light. They even dull outside noises pretty well, which I was a bit surprised by.Sound- I have used a good amount of over-ear headphones, and these are the best I've tried. They look very neat and professional, don't need batteries and are WELL worth the money. All of my previous headphones were less than $100 so I cant compare these to anything super-fancy, but these were the best I've had by a landslide. Comparing these to my last pair of Skull Candy G.I's ($80), I immediately noticed the sounds were brighter and significantly clearer. I was able to hear instruments/sounds in songs that I did not notice at all with my G.I's, which says a lot about these headphones considering G.I's are much better than average headphones. I even could comprehend background lyrics in a song that previously (a day prior) sounded like mumbling. I was quite pleasantly surprised by the amount of bass and low bass these provide, I have not heard any  comparable non-battery operated headphones (which sometimes distort, so watch out).I produce house music using FL Studio, and these headphones have made my mastering and EQ'ing MUCH more precise. There's never even a hint of distortion, even when using some high quality, CPU gobbling VST plugins and heavy kicks. There is a reason most sound engineers use these headphones, these are the real deal. If engineers use these to master, you can be assured that this is the way their music was intended to be heard.Practicality- The wire is thick and durable, no worried about it fraying, and the coiled wire can stretch pretty far if you need it to. It does not take up any more space than other over ear headphones if you tuck in the wiring into the collapsed structure. I personally don't like running with headphones on, but it seems these fit snug enough to run without a problem, provided you have some of that cable in your pocket. Like I said earlier, they're pretty light and quiet some outside noise. These fit comfortably on average sized ears, but I would imagine are also good if you have larger ears because the cushion is very softTo sum up, I guarantee you will not regret purchasing these. Sounds is phenomenal, it's great for the price, and it's comfortable

You put them on and don't even feel them.The only thing they are is big.  Luckily, I have a big head, but if you're a woman with a small head, there is no way to make these smaller.  I wear them without expanding them and they just fit.  I think they're made for men, mostly.I am really grateful that all the other folks who purchased these headphones took the time to review them and that Amazon has this great feature.  It was those reviews that made me purchase these headphones.  Thank you all and thank you Amazon!!!!

It will GO to the full length, but the tension practically pulls it off your head and I need to hold the cord in my hand or wrap it around something to take advantage of the full length---and I still worry about putting that much tension on the jack. review_title: though I do appreciate good quality sound and I didn't want to blow hundreds ...
review_body: I'm not an audiophile, though I do appreciate good quality sound and I didn't want to blow hundreds of dollars on high-end cans that I would be terrified of breaking.  These things are tanks, and they sound great.  They don't have active noise cancelling, but they do a great job of mechanically blocking outside noise.  I have dropped them several times from a few feet up and there's not so much as a scratch on them.  The only thing I would recommend is getting a new set of ear pads.  The stock ones are fine, but they do get a little uncomfortable during long stints.  Then again, I have a giant head, so it may just be me.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I'm very, very pleased with these headphones.  It took me a while to get used to the sound, but that comes from years and years of using headphones that were okay.  The fit of these are perfect for me and my style of use.  The over ear are a must since I use headphones for 8-14 hours Monday through Friday and these feel excellent for how much I use them.  I had spent some time researching when my old pair really started to fall apart and thought I'd like to try these out before buying some, but that uncertainty was put quickly to rest the first time I put these on.  The quality of build is great and, from what I've read, the ability to repair if one piece goes bad or breaks is a great asset.  I have zero issues with these.  Excellent product.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I purchased these headphones to use while playing my Roland electric drums. I was using a turtle beach gaming headset that I thought sounded good til these arrived.These are the best headphones I've ever listened through. The bass is deep and rich, the mids are clear, and the highs are crisp. I'm sure better headphones exist at a higher price point, but these suit me just fine.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Sounds great. Visited KEXP in Seattle and they were using the same headphones in their studio. They're comfortable and fit over and around your ears for long listening.

review_body: Honestly, these are the best headphones I've ever owned! The sound quality is superb and they are comfortable as hell. review_body: These fit comfortably on my large head and I really enjoy the sound quality: a great value. They pack neatly into a small bag, which I've used to transport them daily between home and work. The one big flaw is that there are loose, fragile, thin wires outside the ear cups that catch on things easily. The insulation on my left thin wire came apart after ~30 hours of use and had to be glued back into place. Fortunately the sound quality was unaffected.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Excellent sound without emptying your wallet
review_body: It's hard to believe that these headphones sound as good as they do. They have to be the best sounding headphones for the money available. Unless you are an extremely serious audiophile don't waste your money buying anything else. For that matter even if you are that extremely serious audiophile these will make you smile.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I am not an audiophile but I have a business associate who has 13 years of audio quality design and testing who recommended these headphones or "cans" in the $50 to $100 price range.  And he was right.  Previous to his recommendation I had listened to a number of cans and was zeroing in on the Sony MDR-XB500 or Bose AE2.  My son has the Sony MDR-XB500s and they are very nice: around ear, very soft, cushy muffs, great sound but a little too much bass (that is the XB in the model name) but not so much that it is annoying.  I found the Bose AE2s and liked the smaller profile but still around/over the ear (AE=Around Ear) and great sound.  So I ordered both and got them last night.  Well, while both are great cans, the Sony MDR7506s were clearly a little better sounding: the bass was there whereas the Bose were missing the deeper bass.  So unless my wife likes the Bose AE2s, then they will be going back.  For the money ($87 on Amazon), I think these are the best headphones for the money!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: For the price these are the best over the ear headphones available.  They sound amazing.  I've tried many brands and some much more expensive.  The 7506's are my reference standard.  I've been using them since the very early 90's and they have never waivered in quality.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Quality design with the  sound of more expensive hp.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Buy it Now was invented for this
review_body: Ya, so I donno bout all this audiophile nonsense and burn-ins and whatever, but I've been using headphone for the past 20 years, and these have definitely got to be my favorite medium price over-ear headphones of all time. In the past I've been a big fan of Sennheiser Hd 25-IIs for djing, some of the higher end shure's for in-ear and skullcandy titans for knocking around and letting the dog munch on accidentally. These are the first larger headphone I've purchased in a while and I don't regret it.I could list the cons of the the earpads being mildly uncomfortable for extended listening, and the plug not being L shaped, but it doesn't really matter because these sound better than any other headphone on the market in this price class and certainly a lot that are twice the price. There are also aftermarket earpads that people seem to like better for $20 that'll solve this problem. There's an obvious reason why these have the rating they do on amazon and why thewirecutter.com continues to recommend them and despite me thinking it's mostly nonsense, why audiofile blogs continue to recommend them as well.For my ear, a lot of treble is extremely annoying and I like a lot of bass. These headphone fit the bill perfectly as well as providing great clarity in the midrange. You won't get the ear fatigue from listening to them for a long time like you might with headphone that have excessive high end. And, while the bass isn't going to blow your head off, it just sounds right -- punchy with some oomph.My music tastes vary, but i'm partial to EDM, jazz, classic rock, alternative, and rap. Ya, so you really can't go wrong with them, and if you hate em, you can always return em.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

I have bought sony products all my life... i have rarely gotten disappointed with ANYTHING Sony care to make... folks.. i am a middle age man....lol, this items is NO exception... highly recommended it

review_body: I love these headphones. I am by no means a musician or a DJ, but I love these things.  I constantly put headphones on while I'm on the computer so I don't have to disbturb anyone in the house.  Since I use it everyday, I decided to go w/a pair that would hopefully last.  I really love these headphones!  The are very comfy, sometimes after hours, I forget I'm wearing them.  They cut out a lot of outside noise and in my opinion, produce a wonderful sound.  I listen to a variety of music and everything sounds good in them.  The bass they seem to produce is amazing.  I also love the reach of the cord.I know these might be a little pricey for an average person to buy, but I would highly recommend you pick up a pair.  You'll love them!***December 8, 2012 update****I have owned these headphones for awhile now and I just wanted to do an update.  There is good and bad.  The good is that they still sound wonderful, out of one ear, I'll explain.  The headband has held up, it looks great. The cord is still fine, the ear cans are fine, all in all, they are a great pair.  Now for the bad.  The wires on each side of the ear are exposed which I find is a bad design because these headphones like others fold up for storage.  Well, after using them for awhile I noticed the right ear started to crackle.  Upon inspection, I found that the wire on that ear had been crimped from the parts folding on it.  As I have stated, not the greatest design. I tried to fix it by soldering it, but it didn't work.  So I have no sound in the right ear piece.  The only other thing wrong is that the ear pads are disintegrating but that's easily solved with buying a new pair of pads.  Sadly I won't be buying another set of these headphones.  I'm now looking at the Audio-Technica ATH M-50s.  I just need something more durable since I use these every day of my life :)

review_body: Wow, I just don't get the great reviews for these. I had read many say they love them and that there are no better closed cans for the price. I had also read some say that the highs are just too harsh and you can't use them for casual listening (they're apparently great for sound production). Count me in the second group. I just could not get used to these, they were not pleasant at all to my ears, so harsh and shrill, very fatiguing. It's a shame because they're built nice and they're compact which is perfect for work. With aftermarket pads (HM5 hybrids) they are supremely comfortable. If they sounded better they would've been great for my needs. I've noticed some people say that there are counterfeits out there but I doubt the pair I got from Amazon are fake. On head-fi there are things you can look for to verify their authenticity and my pair passed every check. Shame, I wanted to like these. If you're sensitive to boosted treble (I didn't know I was until I got these) then stay away.

review_body: Received these headphones right before a road trip from Vegas to LA.  My first listen was through my android phone, regardless, my first impressions were "meh".  Finally got home and plugged them into my laptop and they sound a million times better!  I do not claim to be an audiophile and my primary use will be to listen while I work.  These headphones are more than I could have asked for, for the price I paid.  The sound is very rich from the Bass through the high tones.  The headphones themselves seem very well made and I love the way they compact down for travel and stow.  The cord is extra long and is spiraled in the center so the cable is not all over the place.Next thing is a DAC, a coworker says that with a DAC they will sound even better! review_body: I've been a Koss headphone owner for the last two-and-a-half decades.  I remember trying some mid-to-upper end Sony headphones about 12 years ago and I went with a set of Koss TNT-66, which I believed at the time were the best overall headphones for the $75-100 range.  Since then, I've tested a number of headphones (Panasonic, Pioneer, Bose, Sennheiser, and even some buds), but I always came back to my Koss for clarity, bass-mid-highs reproduction, and sensitivity (how loud they play).Only recently, the magnets on the Koss headphones seemed to be getting weaker, and I noticed less punch in the bass.  I started researching various headphone reviews in the $75-150 price range.  To make a long story short, the Sony MDR-7506 had satisfaction ratings that blew anything in the price range.After using the Sony's for about a week, I have to agree with the majority of the reviewers.  These headphones are extremely accurate in reproduction of bass, mids and highs.  Bass is solid and very low, without sounding boomy.  Mids and highs have a remarkable 3D presence, even better than the Koss.  Sensitivity is good, so even portable CD players or IPods can power the headphones, although these puppies are so good that I really recommend them for use with a good home audio or home theater system.  The reproduction is so faithful that the limitations of compressed music (mp3's, etc.) are apparent.Anyway, my recommendation is that these headphones are better than anything in the under $150 range (and sound better that a Bose set for $159).  They may sound better than many headphones in the under $250 range.But don't try to save money by buying a cheaper set of headphones.  I've been testing many of the $25-50 headphones for years - and don't waste your time.  The Sony MDR-7506 is a real set for professionals - and discerning home audio enthusiasts.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: and am very glad I did
review_body: spent hours looking online, reading reviews, etc. for a replacement to a 10-year old pair of these exact same headphones. then I ended up buying them again, and am very glad I did. review_title: Good for Listening to Music Vocal Tracking
review_body: I really enjoyed these headphones. I’ve owned two pair to this date and I enjoyed both. They provide a really nice sound, they’re comfortable, and they’re very portable because they collapse into themselves.PACKAGING:The headphones come in a beautiful packaging. They com in a box with really nice gold trim on the inside and a carrying pouch as well.COSTRUCTION:Overall, I’d say the headphones are constructed very nicely. Real leather wrapped band, aluminum cups. The pads on the cups are made of a pleather like material and I ended up replacing them with some Beyerdynamic EDT250V pads. WONDERFUL set up!Something I don’t like about the construction however, is the 3.5mm jack. It is VERY easy to bend. I’m talking crazy easy. It’s why both pairs of my headphones broke. They still play sound, but only out of one side. Another thing I don’t like is that the band can warp if you store them in a backpack or something. It is pretty much impossible to bend it back to it’s original shape as the second you put them back on, they feel weird.SOUND:The sound is pretty good. Good enough to do some vocal tracking and listen to music. I wouldn’t recommend mixing with these though as the sound isn’t really neutral. It’s slightly colored and accentuates the highs and dulls the lows. I have a pair of Beyerdynamic DT 770 Pros that I use for mixing and recording and I find them to be much more true to sound when it comes to instruments.Overall, I think these headphones are a good buy for those looking to have a nice pair of headphones to listen to music with and record vocals with but I would not recommend mixing songs with them.

review_title: Pads suck but otherwise an impressive headphone.
review_body: I own the mdr-v6 and can’t speak highly enough regarding the sound quality/build for what is really a paltry sum. They punch weigh above their weight. Can be driven solidly and accurately from small usb powered amplifiers, offer surprising fidelity from headphone output of a decent CD player but scale well with better sources and amplification. This headphone is no different in that respect. The build is the same. A red “professional” sticker on the cups versus the mdr-v6’s “Digital”. That’s literally where the difference in build begins and ends. A sticker. Popping the cups open may and probably does reveal more  that causes the subtle yet firmly present change in sound signature. As with the v6, the pads being the same; kind of suck but if you’re invested in these, dekoni makes a utterly delightful pad that while expensive is ridiculously comfortable without screwing up the sound signature. I can’t hear any changes meaningful enough to be able to convince myself it’s there for the better or worse that the dekoni pads effect anything at all.Efficient and accurate, I do feel the 7506 is a little more analytical, not cold or lifeless by any stretch but certainly geared more for the professional requiring accuracy and neutrality but that doesn’t exclude the casual listener or music/headphone enthusiast even the budget oriented audiophile can get a lot of enjoyment from this particular set of headphones. I hear these to be a little more mid range; maybe not forward or emphasized but certainly more mid centric than the mdr-v6 which in and of itself has a very pleasant mid range. The bass; the bass is different. The first evening I had them. I played Aretha Franklins Ain’t no way. I kept hearing these super low tones and thought they were coming from behind me. Kept looking over my shoulder. It was bass I hadn’t heard in the same track before. I played it over and over and it’s the same sub bass, in the same places. Very low. Solidly around 20Hz. Impressive. Not overpowering, flabby or booming but present in justbthe kost convincing way. I feel there’s a difference in sound stage, maybe it’s just in separation but it does feel a tad narrower but still wider than I expect a closed cup to be. Still; to me anyway a very entertaining headphone.Enclosed is a “service manual” of sorts and a parts list of the entire exploded headphone and some online research shows this headphone is certainly rebuild-able maybe even scratch built with parts sourced online. That’s handy if your both a headphone enthusiast and tinkerer. More online research nets very little information on Sony’s website regarding either the mdr-v6 or this set of phones. Only posts under “community” so the fate of these headphones, possibly the provenance may be questionable. I am confident both pairs of mine are genuine and both this and the v6 sound wonderful in their own way. Really a solid purchase. I really wish I’d known about these Sony’s and the koss portapro when all I had for music was a portable CD player/headphones and a binder full of discs. I’d have probably never gone over to the dark side with MP3’s.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: The good and the bad of MDR-7506 'phones
review_body: I've owned a pair of SONY's MDR-7506 headphones since April of 2009 and find them to be very much as advertised. They've got a wide frequency range and perform well with units having flea power output. With a bit of plug position finagling, they'd probably work satisfactorily with an old-fashioned transistor radio --that's how sensitive they are-- yet these 'phones handle the highest volume levels without distortion. They've got rich bass tone and clean high end.DOWNSIDE:They fit on your head like a clamp. After about 30 minutes the pressure can be annoying.Like a bicycle tire, the leather ear pads come off easier than they go on. If you're not careful, you can accidentally knock one off, which is what happened to me once. Getting it back on was a lesson in aggravation.Recently, the coiled main cord of my MDR-7506s got stuck between my couch and an end table. Although I didn't yank it brutally, the amount of pressure I did exert in trying to free it was enough to short out one of the channels. In a case like this, especially when they're out of warranty, SONY does not repair the headphones-- they only offer an eighty dóllar exchange, plus sales tax and shipping.If you are capable, it may be cheaper to buy a replacement cord, splice it in high on the wire, then solder and tape it up. The finished product won't look pretty, but you also won't be out another C note.
