review_title: Exceptionally accurate - but MAYBE not the best for music/casual listening
review_body: First things first, these are studio monitors which doesn't mean they sound the best (Which is super subjective by the way), but it means that they are ACCURATE. They are more or less industry standard, among a few other options.That means if you are listening to really nicely produced music, it'll sound good. If you're listening to crap recordings, they'll sound worse than they normally do. So, just be full warned that they do not hide anything with sound coloring (equalization or shoddy tone production). I personally think they sound great but your ears may say otherwise since they are fairly "flat" and don't color the sound.For prolonged listening, they're not the most comfortable. That's echoed across the reviews. There are other ear pads that might help with that, but some of it just comes down to the nature of over-the-ear headphones. Some people like ear buds better (I usually do) and some people's ears can't tolerate those so, your mileage may vary.I use them primarily to monitor sound recording for video, for that purpose they are amazing. It's much better to get rid of unwanted sound before post-production and these will almost overemphasize imperfections in your initial recording. They don't hide much if anything. If your mix or your recording sounds good in these - it's probably going to sound amazing on a television or consumer grade earphones/laptop/even high end stereos for the most part.The sound reproduction is VERY flat to my ears. I'm no audiophile but they are flatter than most headphones I've owned to be sure and they are even flatter than my M-AUDIO monitors. That said, they're also very accurate and have crisp sound reproduction that are rare in a set of cans in this price range.Quality wise they're awesome. They're reasonably comfortable.They are NOT noise canceling headphones and if you're trying to drown out a coffee shop or airplane noises, you probably want earbud type headphones to block out sound(I recommend the SoundMagic E10 with comply ear tips for a very good value option--though they're not flat and do have some sound coloring which I find pleasant for music).The coiled cord is a very nice touch. The bag it comes with is too, but I found it to be fairly terrible in terms of look and feel. I'll probably seek out a better case in the future for the road. The bag is not really great for road use as it's -- just a bag.I got mine directly from Amazon and they were of course authentic. Mine were made in Thailand.For my purposes (mostly monitoring recording) these are EXACTLY what I want. I just caution those of you who think that buying studio headphones is going to make your music "sound" better that these MIGHT not be the right thing for you. Though, if you do, you might find that after a little adjustment that you prefer them to your old (probably fairly "colored") headphones. Good luck!

review_title: Sony MDR-7506 Vs the Sony V6 Headphones
review_body: Both the Sony MDR-7506 and V6 sound very good,  yet the 7506 seems to have a little more aliveness  in the midrange and a fuller yet well proportioned bass than the more linear sounding yet still nice Sony V6 headphones.  The 7506 also seems to play slightly louder than the V6 at the same volume setting, making them a little more efficient - although both sound good and play plenty loud with an iPod.  Of course, a headphone amp always makes great headphones like these sound even better.Both headphones feel very comfortable and neither one of them presses down too hard on the head.  I have a larger than average head and have no complaints about discomfort.  Both Sony headphones allow the headphones to fold inward and fit nicely in a compact pouch.On balance, because of what I perceive to be better sound, I prefer the MDR-7506 over the V6 and feel that the 7506 are well worth the extra $20.  I also like the full sized non-compact Denon AH-D2000 headphones, and although I give the Denon's a slight edge in sound, I seriously question whether they are worth the extra $200.

review_body: I had a pair of Sony Mdr-V6 headphones for probably 15 years before they developed a short cutting out the right side of the headphones. Then bought a set of Sony Mdr-XB700. Great bass, but sacrificed the mids and highs and again didn't hold a candle to the old MDR-V6 pair I had. Was about to order the MDR-V6 when I came across the Professional Sony MDR-7506 and though I'd try them since all the reviews claim thats what many artists use in the studio. One word, WOW! This is what headphones should sound like. Great balanced sound. Able to handle significant bass without distortion and still have great mids and highs. Fantastic overall balanced sound and to my ears are a step better sounding than my great old MDR-V6. And at $85.00 they're a bargain!

review_title: Good stuff; great value for money, winner in 3-headphone shootout
review_body: My regular headphones are Sennheiser HD650s, which I am quite fond of and are excellent headphones. But, I needed some closed-back headphones for work at the office. So I recently ordered the Audio-Technica ATH-M40x and the Sennheiser HD380 Pros. I wrote reviews on each but basically the Sennheisers sounded good but were uncomfortable, and the ATs were comfortable but didn't sound good. Both sent back.Round 2, based in part on the recommendation of a friend, was these. These I am keeping. Sound is quite good on all but the most difficult material, and sounds like it has a flat response curve. Bass is tight and not over-prominent. Mids and highs are good, again with the exception of difficult material where there is a certain lack of musicality. They don't sound "bad" on this material, but they don't make my ears go "ahhh" like the HD650s do. Which is to be expected, given the price difference.Comfort is quite good. Band padding is a little lacking but they are quite light and it doesn't seem to bother me in practice. Build "feel" is good. Not luxurious, but workmanlike and no impression of delicacy or shoddiness.My one complaint is the coiled cord. Sony, make another version of these with swappable cords for another $15-20. I would definitely trade up and those would get 5 stars.Bottom line: if something like this is what you need, you will almost certainly be well-pleased.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: These headphones are magic for audio engineering. Light weight and sound better than most. Well worth it for my video production editing.

review_title: Quality Issues IMO, Hold Off Buying
review_body: There seems to be some quality control issues going on with this model of headphones. My friend bought this pair of headphones 18 months ago. He never really used them, so I borrowed them for a year. Amazing headphones, loved them. Fantastic sound distribution. I eventually gave him that pair back.I purchased my own. I was really taken back when I first heard them. There was a significant difference between this pair and the pair that I fell in love with. The mids and harmonies were REALLY strong, but the highs were nonexistent. The bass for both headphones was similar. I had a hard time hearing the melody over the harmonies.I returned that pair in exchange for another because Amazon is the best. The new headphones arrived today, and I am still trying them out, but here is my initial impression: These new headphones now are extremely heavy on the top melody line and the harmonies are very muddy. They are better than your standard apple earbuds, but not by much :/I really miss the original pair that my friend bought. I'm going to keep trying this pair, see if they improve at all. If they don't improve, I will likely return them. Sometimes certain batches of product are better than others. Perhaps I just hit a bad batch. I was really disappointed in Sony and I'm going to start looking for other headphones.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Hear more of your music and less outside noise!
review_body: Crisp, clear, depth, vast.  All these words come to mind when trying to describe the MDR-7506 Professional Headphones from Sony. Less ambient noise from around the house if you want to focus as well.  Well played Sony...well played.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: I bought these a year and a half ago now and waited to review. Unlike most of the other buyers, I use them for scoping court cases (court reporters hire me to clean up their transcripts and correct misspellings and similar mistakes). Some of the audio I receive is awful. These headphones have made my job so much easier.Comfort: I wear these for up to ten hours at a shot sometimes (small breaks in between) and they do not pinch or crush or cause pressure points like most other headphones I've tried. The cushioning all the way around makes for great wear over long periods of time. My ears might get a little warm, but it's a small price and easily managed by taking a short break and letting them cool down.Sound: I'm not an audiophile and haven't given them a serious test on that end but my husband is and regularly steals them from me to listen to his music when I'm not working. For my purposes, they are amazing. I have one reporter whose courtroom only has one mic in front of the witness stand that is also supposed to pick up the judge and both attorneys who often sit at their tables across the courtroom. To hear anyone other than a witness, I have to max the volume and deal with hissing of the volume that high. In other instances, a witness may speak very quietly and the judge or attorneys will only periodically ask them to repeat themselves and speak up. Using the same laptop with same sound card, I can much more easily pick out quiet voices and what those voices have to say than the former Bose and Sennheiser headsets I had, both of which cost more than three times the price of these. For some reason, every pair of "noise canceling" headphones I've tried gave me headaches and they also did not help pick out those overly quiet whispers or people too far away from their mic (it seemed to make it harder to hear those very quiet details). The padding on these not only help with comfort but effectively create a noise canceling effect without the downsides of true noise cancellation.Since I started using these, my accuracy has gone up quite a bit. A few of my reporter clients have commented that I pick out details they had to listen several times to confirm and I can often do it on the first or second listen. These are just that good.So happy with these!
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphones
review_body: I have been taking guitar lessons for several years.  Recently, I have started to write songs using a Line 6 UX1 and Garageband on my iMac.  Since I track multiple tracks (guitars, bass, drums, pianos, orchestral strings, etc), I needed to purchase a pair of recording headphones to properly adjust the volume levels of these tracks.  These headphones were recommended to me by my guitar teacher.  He told he personally uses these headphones.  In addition, my guitar teacher was recommended these headphones by a fellow guitar teacher who owns his own professional recording studio.  These headphones are phenomenal.  They cancel out the noise around me so I can properly adjust the volume levels of the multiple tracks in my songs.  I would definitely recommend these headphones to anyone who does recording whether at home or in a professional studio.

review_body: I hesistated at the cost, but now I'm glad I invested in them!  The Sony MDR7506 is the closest thing to a open studio monitor I've ever found in a set of headphones.  The clarity and definition and presence, solid bass and punch allow me to hear darned much everything in my audio now!  Thanks to Sony, I finally have a $300 dollar pair of studio grade headphones with only an $80 price tag!  I'm also hyper-sensitive to the phasing of headphones.  Many sets I've tried over the years seemed lacking in punch, volume or clarity because they weren't in phase with my eardrums.  Now the Sony MDR7506 has lifted the "audio fog" and the set reveals the true audio tone to me.They work great in front of my AT4040 microphone too, which is ultra sensitive to the presence of the "cans" on your head.  The Sony's are barely audible in the vocal mix.  The only way to do better is step up the price tag about 4 times to get a perfectly sealed ear cup.  But for the money, the Sony's are technically superior to anything else I've tried in the "under $100 dollar" range!  If you're on a budget but want superior cans, get them, you won't be disappointed.  The only beef I have with them is the fold up design.  I could live without that and find it a handling nuisance, but for the performance it's a small quirk to put up with.  I wish the fold out design would "soft lock" so they will stay in position while putting them on.  Then if you wanted to fold them, then you would have to push them together in a certain way so that they go in their nice leatherette carry case.  Nice touch, but since these headphones are in my studio all the time, I'll use the carry pouch for some loose camera stuff in my camera bag.Good value and professional performance is the bottom line here.

review_title: Best sounding over-ear headphones for the price (and for prices much higher)
review_body: These headphones are comfortable.  My ears stick out, so after an hour or so I can feel them pressing in, but it's fine as long as I take them off every once in a while.  For people whose ears don't stick out, this isn't a problem.The sound quality is great, especially at this price point.  I prefer the sound on these headphones to many priced much higher.  These are the best headphones I can listen to without a headphone amp.  Higher quality headphones emphasize background noises more and need it.  They also cost several hundred dollars more.  I can plug these into my noisy PC at work, and music sounds clear and detailed without overemphasizing any frequency band too much.  I can hear all the bass easily without it being overpowering.  If I want more bass, I can simply adjust the EQ on my sound source.  The fans and the hard drive in the PC produce white noise that's clearly audible when no music is playing, but once I hit play I don't notice it.  Using a headphone amplifier eliminates the white noise, but I don't feel the need with these headphones.  Everything just sounds good through them.The long coiled cable is fine for an office or a bedroom, but it can be cumbersome on the move.  The headphone do fold up nicely, but they have fragile-looking wires connected to the drivers that makes me hesitate to throw them in my bag.  However, if you treat them with care, you can get away with using them on the bus/plane.They isolate fairly well.  I can still hear people talking nearby, but when I turn on music I can ignore them successfully.  They also do a good job of staying quiet for people around me.  I can play music pretty loudly at work without disturbing my coworkers.

review_title: Need Some Work to Sound Great - Unlike Grado (Initial Evaluation)
review_body: "The "Fresh-out of the box" sound test with my portable iDevice using MP3 tracks I commonly listen too (1 "Pop", 1 "Metal", 1 "Vocal" Tack, and 1 Soundtrack - usually Tron Legacy).First impression:a.) Low-End Bass was way too punchy, and at times over-whelming.b.) The highs were way too tinny and competing, which washed out the mids.Point is my Grado SR-80's were a 5 out 5 out of the box.Since the initial impression I have have been burning them in with pink-noise, low, mid, and high frequency sweeps. I will provide an update after burn-in period is complete (24 Hours).I bring up the Grado's because weather you have the 60's, 80's, or 125 series out of the box they sound warm, well-rounded, with soft high's, and even lows.  The major issue with the Grado's is PAIN.  I have had three pairs and I cant make it past 20 minutes without my ears feeling pinched.These are the second pair of Sony Can's I have purchased. I have the MDR-N60 Noise Cancelling (got on sale in an outlet store).  Those were very accepatble out of the box, however the noise cancellation circuit actual adds noise, so I decided to move up to the MDR-7506 Professional's.Build Quality and Design:a.) These MDR-7506's are well built as far as material qaulity for the price point.b.) Design - There are exposed wires connecting the left to the right can. The issue is that this wire comes out as a loop and is about 18-gauge, which makes me nervous if they catch on anything since the wire is so exposed and at a high-gauge.  I am assuming that this was part of the design which allows the headphone to be fold-able, which by the way, is a smooth and clean action.c.) The cord - The compromise for having that expose wire connecting the two cans is that you have only one side cord-out.  I love having the one-cord design (Which is the other thing about the Grado's which is uncomfortable - two mid-gauge cords dropping from each can).  This cord also has the coil built into it to limit the amount of strain at either end.  The 1/8" and 1/4" male inputs are nicely gold-plated, and the 1/4" connector actually screws onto the the 1/8" part, nice touch.d.) The Cans - Good, but would sacrifice an extra 1/2" -3/4" of depth for a definitively comfortable fit.I know I am being critical considering the 100.00 price point, but these are one of Sony's high-end Headphones (Seen them as high as $229.00 in retail stores).  And I also recognize that I am comparing The MDR-7506's features and benefits to a $500.00 headphone standard.After Burn-in and a few weeks of listening I am expecting the bass will be less punchy, and the mid's will be more pronounced, however that remains to be heard.  I make my initial impression and 2 week impression without a DAC, or any digital signal enhancements.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

When using big speakers isn't possible, I couldn't find a reliable, affordable pair of headphones that could allow me to make accurate decisions when mixing.  Doesn't compare to the AKGq701's in terms of soundstage but for the price range they are in and the reliability they contain, I am very happy that I made this purchase.

review_body: I loved SONY from the beginning. But when my SONY headphones wore out through years of use, I wanted me a new pair. Regardless of media--iPod or just plain listening to your fave video on YouTube--you will be able to hear sounds you have never thought were there before. Try listening to Chicane's Daylight video using a headphone or MDR 7506. You will hear the difference. I was just blown away like I-got-goosebumps-all-over-my-body blown away. The level of sound detail is just amazing. Plus, when you listen, these headphones cancel out noise well such that other people will have to physically let you know they are saying something to you.One of my wisest purchases this year. I'll challenge myself to keep these for the next 35 years because I hear they are that durable.

review_body: I find myself going back to these every time I am in the market. I'm not into hyped cans that amplify and distort the true recording. I use these as reference monitor headphones- plan and simple. Bottom line is, for the money - you simply cannot get a better pair of studio headphones. If you want "entertainment" or true "audiophile" headphones do not get these. If you want flat response for a professional environment i.e. radio, dj, voice over, studio production then these are for you.My only Con is : The vulnerability of the ear pads. They hold up in the studio but I used to travel quite a bit and use them in some hot clubs which will take a toll on them.

review_title: these headphones are fairly amazing. It is a minor miracle that Sony is ...
review_body: Ok, I don't generally take the time to write a review on anything I buy - BUT, gotta tell you, these headphones are fairly amazing.  It is a minor miracle that Sony is able to sell these at this price.  I've been a musician and music fan all my life - I have nearly a dozen headphones.  In the studio I use the Beyerdynamic 770s - these are my favorite - BUT they cost nearly $300 and are quite heavy.  I bought the Sony headphones to use in the car on my commute to work and was really surprised at the quality of sound.  Interestingly, I found out about these from a business news feed that mentioned products that were really worth the price.  Why four stars?  I just got these a few days ago - lets see how well they hold up.  I expect from other Sony headphones I've had (20 years or so ago) they will be fine.  For sound quality and fidelity to the original digital source - you cannot beat these - nothing I've seen on the market can match this quality for 80 bucks - thanks Sony, you hit one outta the park with these.

review_title: DISAPPOINTED - i tried these against other headphones
review_body: DISAPPOINTED - i tried these against other headphones, such as the  Audio-Technica ATH-M50x, V-MODA Crossfade M-100, and the Sennheiser HD 380 Pro, all of which are very nice headphones.  To be fair, the sound is very nice, and balanced throughout the bass, mid range, and the high notes.  At the risk of using a lay-person's terminology, the sound seemed to have a hollowness to it, not as full as the ATH-50.  It was more dynamically correct than the V-Moda, and about on par with the Sennheiser HD 380.To add perspective, I love trio music, such as Bill Evans, and it was a very good test of the headphones, challenging that the bass not be overly forward, and with sparkling highs that let the piano show through.Perhaps if I had not been hearing the great sound of nearly all of these headphones, it would have been more satisfying.  It does have a broad frequency response, not too much bass, nothing overly forward, but that being said, it seemed like nothing really came forward and sounded outstanding.I loved the V-Modas, the size, the technology, but the bass was too over powering for the piano.

review_body: I picked up these headphones because of the great reviews. I am in IT and watch a lot of training videos to learn and keep up with lots of different technologies. I am a photographer on the side and watch videos regarding that and have been getting more into video, and monitoring through the camera manually with Shure microphones. I also enjoy listening to music (mostly rock). So these headphones serve many purposes for me. I have had them only for a few weeks now. I have others by different manufacturers, and a lot more pricey, that have shorted out or have been a lot heavier. I am really enjoying these phones. I can wear them all day and not get too bothered. The only thing I found so far that I don't like is that my ears sweat and I wish I had some foam padding for breathing ability around the earpiece. But then again, I probably wouldn't get the great sound out of them. These are flat, if you want booming bass go with another maker. These don't artificially model the sound. You can easily adjust the tonal wave using some equalizers. The Sonys are wonderful as studio monitors, what they are really meant for. For under $100, these are a HUGE steal!

review_title: They were excellent for dialling in all the Adobe Audition settings and ...
review_body: Short version: these are *studio monitors* and they're designed for accuracy of sound. They are excellent but they might present a much more dry, precise musical image than you're used to.-----------------These were ordered for me at work to do audio adjustments for a series of tutorials my company was producing. They were excellent for dialling in all the Adobe Audition settings and filters to make the speaker's voice sound good. I could hear every detail very clearly and how my adjustments were affecting the sound.But now I'm using them to listen to music, and they sound very thin and dry compared to the other speakers and headphones I use. I can hear every detail of the music, very accurately, but bass sounds lacking, especially if you're used to the kind of (perhaps over-)emphasized bass most consumer headphones are built with these days. Audio purists are going to love these but others should be aware these are studio monitors and they're not going to give you that "sweetened" sound that a lot of consumer headphones have. I think that's a plus.

I knew it wouldn't sound like regular listening headphones (where the bass range is usually amplified in some way) but it felt like the sound lost all of its richness and life in these. It just sounds flat. So I returned my pair.

review_title: Perfect desk headphones, not so great on the go because of curly cord
review_body: Sony MDR-7506 ReviewThese are my second pair of over-ear, high end headphones that I bought for listening to music at work. Previously, I used a pair of Status HD Two. While HD Two was a great pair of headphones, I had its plastic headband snap after regular use. Status Audio replaced it for me, and the second pair broke as well. I decided to try other options, and settled on this classic model from Sony.Status’s HD Two and these Sony MDR7506 headphones are in the same price range, and I can hear this. I would say they sound almost identical. I don’t have *too* much experience with audio equipment, so I won’t attempt to use audiophile terminology and embarrass myself.For everyday entertainment use, these are almost the perfect pair of headphones in my opinion. The sound signature is exactly what I want it to be.I am not a huge fan of the design, although I find nothing about it to be a dealbreaker. The cable could have been detachable. I am also not a huge fan of the curly cable. While I can see its usefulness to many people, I just think it looks unsightly and sometimes gets in the way. I don’t use these on the go at all (only at my work desk), but doing so feels a bit cumbersome because of the cable. The curly wire is heavier than a regular, straight cable, and therefore unwieldy. I really wish that I had the option to swap them out for something more subdued.The rest of the (retro feeling) design is not bad at all. The actual headphones do look much better than what you can see in the low quality product image at the time of this writing. To get a better idea, look up video reviews of this product on YouTube.These headphones are very comfortable to wear, once you adjust the cups properly for your head size (this is *very* important, or you may experience ear ache after a few minutes of use). The whole thing is extremely bendable, twistable and collapsible. This isn't always a great thing, because it feels a bit flimsy at times. But hey, I have used this pair for over two months and nothing has broken so far. The ear cups may be slightly smaller than the ones on Status's HD Two, but they are squishy and comfortable in their own way. The clamping force on the Sony pair is significantly lighter as well, which I really like.The packaging was notably nice; the headphones were cradled in a box covered in a satin-like fabric. I was also surprised to see Sony include schematics of the hardware for repair guidance. The pamphlet even has retro-ish typography on it. While I would have preferred a hard case, the included leather carry bag is appreciated.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Back to the one and only field monitor cans. Working as a FOH engineer, I need a monitoring tool that brings details through a hell of noise. Also, there is a need to understand balances in the mix - frequency- and level-wise. These cans play the mid frequencies precisely enough to detect and locate problems. - The only weakness is the low frequency range where it gets a bit un-precise and "muddy". Plus, there is some dip in the highmid-range (around 3-4 kHz) which is not too bad - this helps details cutting through in noisy environments. - Compact through fold-ability, I very much like to take them along with me everywhere I go.

review_body: I'm quite disappointed in these headphones after reading the mostly positive reviews on them.  I purchased them for use with my digital piano. I immediately noticed that the right earphone had a slight buzz whenever a note was struck. I put in my older earphones and borrowed a set from friend to test if it was the piano and it was definitely the just headphones. It may be that these are just not a good match for use with a piano. I did not test them with anything else. While these headphones lasted the day that I had them before returning them they do not strike me as very sturdy headphones. The picture on Amazon doesn't show it very clearly but the cord that crosses from the left to the right earphone through the headset hangs out on either side quite a bit and appear a bit flimsy to me. In addition, the joints that allow the headphones to fold up for compact storage seem like a weak point that would easily break with heavy use. The joints were also unattractive to me as I wouldn't be packing these headphones anywhere so that option is completely unnecessary to me.All of that being said I would have kept these headphones if not for the buzz in the right earphone. The sound quality was very good (other than the buzz) and the headphones were very comfortable.

review_title: Sound is good, but ear-pads are simply awful.
review_body: These are good-sounding headphones for tracking (I would not use them for mix-referencing, as they are a bit too shallow on the low-end).  The closed-back design helps minimize bleed, and they fold-up very small for use on the road.However, the ear-pads are simply a deal-breaker.  The foam is covered with a super-thin rubbery plastic that frays and tears way too easily.  Also, the only way that this plastic membrane is "attached" to the can is by sliding it in-between two plastic layers, so it can easily slip out of the groove, forcing you to spend quite a bit of time carefully working it back into place (carefully because it is so thin that it will easily tear if you do not do it surgically).  I have to do this about twice per week, so even though the sound on these is good, I look forward to the day when I will eventually get a more well-designed headphone.If you only review these on the sound, then they are great.  But if you care about usability, I would look for a headphone with a sturdy fabric or vinyl ear-cover (similar to my Beyerdynamic DT-880 Pro's--incredible sounding headphone, and the ear-pads will last forever).

review_body: Mine said it would take like 2 months to ship and I was ok with that and it actually arrived in like 6 days! So shipping was pretty nice. Upon opening I could tell right away that these were made solid, and with good material.The size adjustment is made of metal, so that should be sturdy and hold up well. They fold up which is nice and makes for easy storage and overall protection but it looks like that feature might be a weak spot because the hinge is so tiny and dainty looking. The cord is amazing. Very thick wire and it's coiled so there's little chance of a tangley mess. Also the plug comes with the adapter which is actually threaded and screws on, which is a very nice feature. That should ensure longevity in the contact. Also as you can see in the pic there is a small external wire that runs along the side which also looks like it could break easily if not careful. They are very comfortable and fit nicely. They cancel the noise pretty well from the outside but are certainly not quiet headphones to those who may be around you if you're listening to music really loud, others will definitely know. Overall pretty solid specs so that earned it 4 stars. However, In my opinion the overall sound quality wasn't what I was expecting. They sound kind of flat and dull like the eq isn't set right or something. It sounds the same on every device I use it on, just kind of good, not great. Therefore I could not give it a full five stars as I wish they would have sounded sharper and more full (I guess would be the best way to put it.)

review_title: puzzled...REALLY puzzled by these reviews, these are 'monitors'
review_body: *edit update *i feel compelled to update after a week of burn in and experimentation ( again i, in no way, pretend to be an 'audiophile' -however, i am not completely without some background re soundafter they have opened up a bit, i STILL think they are a poor poor choice for relaxing, passive listening.  i believe that while they are very very very clear, they are also a tad harsh and brittle in the highs, although sibilance is minimal.i think that IF, and that is a big IF, but IF you find the right disc ( with the right mix on it ), and have a very good source, you can hit a magical sweet spot with these.  i still maintain it takes a bit of work to get there though.  i still think i am pretty close to spot on when i say that these are stunning for monitoring and mixing ( maybe a little less on the latter ), but the interesting thing is that they will absolutely force you to consider the frequencies and colors of the sources you are using.  you will NOT enjoy these with low quality mp3's.  IF you have a good soundcard, or an amp, and have a properly mixed cd, you can hit an amazing sweet spot.  just don't think these are right for casual listening.  anyway my 1 cents worth on this update.....i am writing this review from the perspective of someone who is NOT an 'audiophile,' an 'elitist,' nor someone who pretends to hear things they don't, just a moderately interested listener with a bare minimum of mixing experience ( digidesign )....regarding these headphones sound, well, i can pretty much suggest the following 3 issues, provided you have any hearing whatsoever....1.  you WILL learn to use the EQ settings on your equipment, you will be forced to, or you WILL have ear and brain fatigue before long2.  you will need to have a pretty good 'source' and equipment both, to enjoy these phones, they will make poorly encoded flac and mp3 files sound VERY bad, in other words, they will EASILY show you how bad ( or good ) the encoding was3.  you will need to allow, i would say, 20 or 30 hours of burn in to get them to open up....just my opinion, not worth much i suppose, but goodness, these things are NOT meant for just passive listening....you just about canNOT passively listen to these...are they clear?  yes.  do they represent the recording? yes.  is the bass controlled? yes.  is the bass 'boomy?'  NO THANK GOODNESS.However, there is not any 'polishing' of the music, and unless you EQ each disc, in conjunction with your equipment, i don't think you will enjoy long listening periods with these.  You will soon hear things that will drive you crazy.  They are AWESOME for teaching your ears to discern different mixes, frequencies and flavors of the disc, but it will soon wear you out.  GREAT for reference, for mixing, for analysis, not very enjoyable at all for relaxed listening.  Know the purpose you have for your headphones before you purchase these.

review_title: How Did I Miss These All My Life?
review_body: I've been through so many headphones over the years, trying to find that satisfying and clean sound, but have always been disappointed and simply settled. I thought maybe my ears just weren't as good as they used to be. Today my MDR7506s arrived and it's like my ears are reborn! The sound stage is so clear and natural, plus the ear pads completely cover my ears and feel tight, without being uncomfortable. My wife had bought me a set of Bose Triport headphones a few years ago. At the time they seemed to sound good, but the MDR7506 sounds soooo much more natural and clear. Plus, the Bose cost over $100 more, are cheaply constructed and uncomfortable in comparison! My only compliant is I wish I had come to these headphones earlier. What a great deal!

review_title: Quit Researching and Pull the Trigger...
review_body: Did tons of research on an affordable set of quality headphones and this Sony Model kept showing up as a viable choice on every site I checked.  It came down to these or the Audio-Technica ATH-M40x.  Went with the Sony because I have so many of their products and "knock wood" have never had any problems.  Also, I like the "over-the-ear" feature as it allows me to listen to music/TV loud without bothering my significant other. As stated earlier I only use these to listen so the DJ, editing, monitoring etc. was of no concern to me.  I do know I would purchase these again and am very happy with my choice.  No hiss, pops, hums, etc. just clear sound.  For the $79.00 I don't believe one could do better.  If you are straddling the fence go for it you will not regret it. I am going to a Best Buy or similar and listen to a set any set of $500.00 headphones just to experience what these could possibly offer that the human ear is capable of experiencing.  I have listened to the $300.00 Dr. Dre "cans" and other than extreme base (which I did like) could really not see justifying that kind of $$$.... But to each their own.  PEACE OUT

review_body: If you're bothering to read starred reviews of this product, it's probably because you don't know what it is. That or for sheer amusement. The Sony MDR-7506 is THE standard of flat stereo headphone sound, by popular acclaim if not for their consistent performance and ubiquitous presence in studios, schools, DJ booths and film sets around the world. Sometimes they break--after years of abuse. Know what? Then you buy the next pair and damn--they sound pretty much the same as the previous pair--incredible. Are they the best headphones money can buy? WTF Of course not. Are they the best for the money and an entry point to the world of real audio? (Yes!) On my third pair in twelve years, and I am a bad, bad person.

review_body: I researched these phones a lot for several days before I bought them. They seemed to be the most reviewed, best rated, best reviewed phones out there in that price range. Listening to music in these phones is like sitting in the very back row of the stadium. The music seems far away - not up close and present. It is clear and well balanced but I'm afraid I'm going to blow my ears out due to the volume needed to get the music to a level where I can actually hear things. The bass is heavier than my near-field studio monitors so I can't trust them for mixing. They might be fine for tracking - I haven't tried that yet. I don't know why they wouldn't work for laying down tracks. You don't need $4,000 phones for that.All in all, I'm a little disappointed but I guess in this price range they are fine.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: After searching across the vast plains of Amazon I finally settled upon the Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphones. These headphones had good specs and great reviews. My main concern was durability. Now after owning them for a year I can attest to their ruggedness. These headphones have survived being stepped on multiple times, thrown around in a 30 lb bookbag, and my little siblings. From these tests I would give these headphones my coveted seal of approval, if I had one. Anywho, these are the headphones you want. (Im talking to you tony.)
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_title: You Can't BEAT the Sony 7506 Cans

review_body: Thumbs Up- I like these.  Originally wanted a good pair of headphones to listen to TV after the kids go to bed.  Good for this. The closed-back design filters out most outside noise and these being studio monitor phones, the sound is crisp, clear, and clean.  No artificially "amplified" bass or other gimmicky crap.  Cons:  These seem fragile.  Not a problem yet, but not a pair of headphones to just toss in your backpack or wear "around".  Would never lets the kids use these- they would destroy them quickly.  Also, maybe a minor "con", but the adapter connection from the smaller to larger plug that came with the HP's is a screw-on, not a simple snap-in.  This limits the cord extensions and other "connections" you can make other than a direct connection to a large port.Overall very good, I'd buy them again, but probably not for everyone.

review_body: Update: After the burn-in phase, the treble subsided and it now sounds great!First of all, I bought these headphones upon the recommendation of thewirecutter.org's "Best Headphone under 150$" shootout.The Delivery was pretty fast and the packaging in silky cloth was pretty good. I've started using it out of the box and it has been a couple of months now. So I guess this review will be based on full capability of the headphone.Pros:+ Very good wide sound stage as described by wirecutter. Although some may feel it artificial.+ Extremely sensitive to input driving levels. Probably the best Headphone with a Good Equalizer. You can sense every single change you make!+ Good Balance of Lows and Highs and Amplified Mids. Does the Job great for recording purposes.+ Distortion free sound even if the volume is maxed out.+ Good Quality plastic. Feels like 80's though. Reliable.Cons:- Ear piercing treble, I mean almost painful for long listening at High volume. I guess these headphones are used in studios for a reason. It is good for recording purposes, but for regular listening I would be happy with probably toned down treble.- Bass is Ok. It is punchy at High volume but if you incline towards bass heavy, too bad you need an EQ or chose another.- Cheap quality ear pads.Overall I am satisfied with the product.If you would like to strap your headphones almost entire day and have a sound that is both clear and pleasant to the ear, I guess the Audio Technica M50s is better. You can do the same with this but with EQ tuning and Beyerdynamic's earpads.Thank you!

review_body: These are simply headphones. Other headphones have added gimmicks, or have terrible sound quality, or are uncomfortable, or have some other aspect that takes away from your aural experience. Not these. These headphones reproduce sound clearly and accurately. The pads are soft and comfortable and fit relatively well around my ears (they do ache after more than an hour of continuous use, but that's still a better track record than most headphones I've used). I was surprised to hear how much more sound I could hear with these. In short, they're almost perfect.The only problem I encounter is with the bass response. They are very "flat" in their output, meaning the bass isn't amped up the way it is on Bose or Beats headphones. This is fine when you're in a quiet listening environment, as the clarity of these phones allows you to enjoy all aspects of sound, including the bass. However, if you're listening on a bus, the low rumble of the engine will drown out the bass, which can be pretty disappointing. If you like a lot of bass, try these headphones before buying and consider getting the very similar MDR-V6 which supposedly has more bass.

review_body: I read tons of awesome reviews and a few really bad on this... and actually listened to a friend's set and was really impressed.  I always have had great success and only  a rare failure with Amazon.  THIS is one of those failures that is probably not the fault of Amazon but the supplier to the seller.The low end is nonexistent... the mids and highs are muted and very unbalanced.  When even slightly adjusting the EQ the sould distorts at ALL volume levels.  I called Sony and they told me they have had reports of fake MDR7506 sets coming from Amazon sellers.  Do not fall for a "break-in" periond... SONY says they shoudl be perfect out of the box.I am returning these and will order direct from Sony for slighly more money and tax.  Not worth taking the chance here.I would have given one star but Amazon gets credit for fast delivery.

review_title: Still satisfied after all these years
review_body: This is my second set of 7506s. My older set is still working fine after 7+ years of use -it only needed replacement of the nylon covers on the still-comfortable ear pads at about 4.5 years. I think I paid about $6-7 for a pair of covers here at Amazon. I've tried a few under-$200 headphones and have not found anything to compare to the 7506s in terms of both flat-true sound reproduction, comfort, and compactness. On the latter, I am submitting a photo that compares the sizes of the 7506 to a pair of the also-excellent Audio-Technica M-50. I got a bad sample of the M50, but I would have tried a second pair if not for their size. I think the compactness of these 7506s is an under-rated feature.My new 7506s are as good as my prior set, although they're a little more base-enhanced, and the coiled cord stretches about 10 feet max, which is couple of feet less that my older pair. Each of these features may be preferred by some, and it is possible that each difference is attributable to age, I especially appreciate that the new phones are as comfortable, and that their build quality is as good as ever.If anyone can recommed a pair that may be a step up to these fine phones, in either an open or closed design, in the under-$200-at-Amazon category, and that is equally compact or nearly-so, please add a comment to this review. Thank you. Enjoy the music regardeless of how you reproduce it.EDIT/UPDATE: As for build quality, the nylon cover on the right ear pad began to come undone at about 7 months. On my original 7506s, the pads lasted about 5 years. I am posting a photo to illustrate the problem with my 8-month-old headphones. Bummer, shame; now I'll have to hassle with a change and add $10-20 to the cost of the these Sony favorites.

review_title: I feel like I robbed SONY.
review_body: I see now why these are labeled "Professional".  The sound quality is outstanding and these are by far the best sounding things I have ever placed on my head.  Granted, I'm no audiophile who nitpicks over brands and has 1000 dollar BOSE headphones or anything.  But I do listen to music quite a bit before I go to sleep, my whole life in fact, and I've used all sorts of brands of headphones from 5 dollar Wal-Mart buds, to some BEATS by Dre.  These headphones are a steal for under 100 bucks.  To me, they sound better then the 300 dollar Dre-phones you get at Best Buy or wherever.  I like a great deal of bass in my music and these deliver quite nicely.  From hip-hop, pop, and dubstep...these really make those low notes sound great.  My rock music has never sounded clearer and classical music sounds almost live.  I am thinking about picking up another set to go on my gaming PC.

review_title: static electricity shocks earlobes, headaches from heavy cord
review_body: They sound great and are comfortable on the ears. They produce a quiet buzz even when nothing is playing, which after a while starts to give me a headache. The cord is heavy and cannot be detached/replaced, constantly dragging my head to the left, and giving me neck pain unless I affix the cord to my belt. When I move my feet across the floor, static electricity shocks my earlobes. I prefer the Bose AE2, which are lighter, more comfortable on the ears, have a detachable cord, and don't shock me with static electricity. These seem to produce more detailed mid-range sounds, and I can see them being the better choice when composing sound, but I prefer the Bose AE2 for listening.

review_body: This headphone was amazing right out of the box.  Very light and very comfortable to wear, even for long durations.  I did not expect too much from these when I ordered them, but was surprised by the clarity and the range.  The bass is very good without being too boomy, the mid-range is very clean and even the highs are pleasantly distinguishable.  I ordered these as my back-up headphones but anyone looking for a good set without spending major bucks should really consider this set.  I would also recommend ordering spare earpad covers for any Sony headphones as they do deteriorate eventually.  Sony has yet to find another material to cover their earpads that will be able to stand up to wear and time; I really don't like those black flecks on my face.  Other than that minor flaw from all Sony headphones I still recommend this set highly.

review_title: From the point of view of a boy's usage, as told by a dad
review_body: Bought these for my son.  So this review is very much focused on sturdiness as much as any other consideration.  These would not be a recommended item for a child who is getting his or her first set of headphones to wear with a gaming device or tablet or for music listening.  But my son had an earlier pair that were meant for children and that item's sound reproduction was lacking, even by his assessment.  I have had my fingers crossed since I gave him the Sony MDR7506 headphones, but in nearly four months, including three plane trips and regular storage in their bag inside his duffel (between homes of his divorced parents), they have held up flawlessly.  They do sound incredible and he loves their fit (and I do, as well, on my seriously bigger head).  And I did buy the extended warranty, just in case.  Conclusion:  These Sony headphones warrant serious consideration for their fidelity and aural excellence, especially at this price point.  And (knocking on wood while typing this) they haven't been slain by the 9 year old yet in his regular usage!

review_title: Great sound at a great price, but not for commuters
review_body: I ended up returning these. I originally bought them based on spectacular Wirecutter and Amazon reviews, and the sound was indeed amazing coming from my FLAC and MP3 files. However the cord was just too unwieldy. I tend to listen while commuting (walk, bus) a lot, and the heavy, long, thick, coiled cord would swing around uncomfortably while I walked. This ended up being a deal breaker for me.In the end, if you're looking for something to listen to while at your desk or immobile, then these are a fantastic deal at a price much lower than similar-sounding cans. However, if you're going to be mobile at all, I'd probably look elsewhere for a set that has a shorter or replaceable cord.

review_title: Outperforms other headphones many times the cost
review_body: I've used these headphones for years for just about any use you can think of.  From listening to music at home or on the metro, to recording in the studio or DJing for a crowd, these headphones have had my back through thick and thin.  First of all, I've owned my pair for around 7 years, and I've only had to replace the foam ear pads.  They're still going strong.  I just ordered this pair for a buddy of mine who I convinced (quite easily, once he heard them) to get a pair for himself.  The sound quality is on par with other studio headphones many times the cost, and will blow most "audiophile" consumer headphones out of the water.  They're snug on the head but not tight and the pads fit very nicely over the ear, offering a decent amount of isolation.  The coiled cable stays out of the way when you need it to, and the threaded 1/8" to 1/4" adapter that comes with it ensures a solid connection if you need to use it.  If you have $80 to spend on a pair of headphones, you won't regret buying these.

review_body: For a short $80, I am impressed!Like many of you I was on the hunt for some high quality - low priced headphones. These are almost perfect. I'm no audiophile, but I enjoy good sound. I haven't experienced any "audiophile" approved headphones yet. My experience includes Apple EarPods, Senheisser 202?, Beats wireless, and my main music player a terrible $30 regent surround system.They do a great job of blocking outside noise and keeping the noise you want to hear in. I do like listening to music loud, until I put these on. It's just not necessary when everything sounds better.Only a few things could use improvement. If you're not in a cool room the pads get a little uncomfortable. It's similar to sitting in a leather wrapped seat of a car with no A/C. You throw some beyerdynamic velour pads on (which i plan on) and problem solved. The other thing, the cable. Sometimes it's nice to have a long cable, but most of the time it's annoying. They are studio monitors so a long cord is necessary. But their is a solution to that as well! Cut it and rewire.It came down to these, ATH-50x, ATH-m40x, and some Beats Studios. Okay, only joking about one of those. They can't be so bad??I'm happy with these and hope to have them around for a few decades like other people before me have.

They feel like they were built to last.The Not So Good:- Incredibly Uncomfortable - ear muffs are just a little too small (over the ear) or too large (on ear) and it pinches my head too much. I can't wear them for more than 30-minutes at a time.In the end, it really came down to comfort for me. review_title: Not that great for casual listening.
review_body: If you're looking for headphones for movies and music then these are not for you. I had them for a week and wasn't really impressed with the sound. The treble is sharp and the bass is weak. Listening to music was really harsh experience that made my ears ring something fierce. After seeing all the gaga reviews about these I thought maybe I just didn't possess the ability to appreciate good headphones. I was going to keep them to see if they grew on me but unfortunately the right side started buzzing at certain frequencies so I chose to return them. I looked around for a pair of headphones that would be more suitable for music and movies and ended up buying a pair of Beyerdynamic DT 770 PRO's and I was blown away! They're very pleasant sounding, the bass is nice and not over bearing, and they're VERY comfortable. If you're willing to spend about $50 more or so (I got mine new for $130, hold out for a deal!) then I really recommend the DT 770's as an alternative choice to these Sony's. If that's a little out of your price range I have friends who swear by the Grado SR80i, which go for about $99. Good luck!

review_body: I considered replacing my noise cancelling headphones with another pair, but have often wondered if there was a trade off between noise isolation and sound quality. Based on the performance of these phones I'd say the answer may be yes. I have heard sounds I never have before. Hands rubbing the instrument, faint sounds from the audience etc., very "balanced" sound, not overdone on the low or high end. The sound is truly "pure", unlike any others I have owned. Note this may not be good for everyone, e.g., if you prefer emphasis on one or the other end of the spectrum.
article: Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphone

review_body: Going from Sennheiser 380 Pros to these, they feel like a step down.  They are listed as "over the ear" headphones but they barely fit over my ears and I have a small head.  Because of this, these pinched my ears more compared to my 380 Pros which are nearly twice as roomy and never touch my ears.  So I would not recommend them for long listening times. I  wish I would have seen these in person before I bought them because they are a lot smaller than I expected.Sound quality wise then are a step down from my 380 Pros which feel more roomy.  But for nearly half the price I paid for the 380 Pros its not a bad deal.  The reason I got these is because after nearly 3 years of use my 380s started to lose fidelity and the ear pads became shredded.  The bass is definitely more pronounced compared to the latter but everything else just seems more flat.  I will keep them though just to have a backup pair but will probably buy Sennheisers again the next time they are on sale.

review_title: Excellent headphones and a great value!
review_body: Clear, detailed, balanced sound. Rich, realistic bass, not artificially boosted. Well made and comfortable on my big head. These replaced a pair of Grado SR80s and IMO the Sony's are clearly superior. The sound is richer, with a wider frequency range and better interior details. I've had 2 pairs of the Grados and both had failures in the non-replaceable cables. The Sony's have more comfortable and better fitting earpads, a longer and replaceable cable, and the materials and construction seem sturdier than the Grados. One potential shortcoming of the Sony's (that doesn't really affect me) is that they probably aren't a good choice for mobile use.  They are pretty bulky and the cable is long. But for high-fidelity home listening, at under $100, I can't imagine how you could do better.  PS, I did notice that the treble seemed a little shrill at first, but they seemed to "break in" and balance out after just an hour or two of listening.

Probably even better with a headphone amp.I don't think I will spend any more money thinking there might be another decent pair than the 7506. Although the Senal smh-1000 which is pretty close with the exception that the 7506 is non-detachable cord. You can actually mod the 7506 with a 3.5MM STEREO PANEL MOUNT JACK from parts-express.com and some JB Weld (or any other epoxy) to hold it strong.Just get a used 7506 on ebay and do the mod if needed.

A hard case is a good investment, as the included soft case doesn't offer much more than collecting the cable (plus it will shed like crazy over the years). review_title: Purchased to reduce distraction in a noisy office environment
review_body: For disclosure, these are my first pair of over the hear headphones.I picked these based on a few podcasters recommending the MDR7506 for professional use, and also a review of them as the best headphones in the $150 category on The Sweet Home.  I'm a software developer in pursuit of less distractions (colleagues having impromptu conversations near me, cell phones going off, others' meeting reminder chimes, etc.) and also having some indication that I am not to be disturbed. I thought I would give it a shot.  In conjunction with a white noise app, these headphones are great at drowning out ambient noise. They're also big enough so that others can see that I'm in the middle of something - I've tried in-ear headphones, ear plugs, and on-ear headphones but none of them say "don't bother me now" to a potential interruption.Another consideration was comfort. I used on-ear headphones for the past few years, and as a wearer of eye-glasses, discomfort would usually set in within an hour or two. With the MDR7506, I can seem to wear them for extended periods of time without any pain.

review_title: By far the best headphones for the price range.
review_body: Make no mistake about the price, these are professional quality headphones. As a live sound engineer and a producer, I recommend these headphones for most live and tracking purposes. I personally use them for monitoring in the studio (not mixing!) and live. If you want to mix live sound, these headphones are great if you don't have money for good in ears. However, I do not recommend these for studio mixing purposes. In simple terms, these headphones do not have a flat frequency response. They have a very high peak towards high end. This is not bad in a live scenario, especially if you have a rig with subs. But in a studio, you will always lean towards a heavy low end mix with these headphones. If you have to mix in a studio with headphones, get a good set of open back cans.

review_title: Best Headhpones - Clear & Rich Sound, Awesome bass response!
review_body: Pros:First I'd like to point out that these headphones most definitely live up to the "studio-standard" name it's been given. The audio response is very well balanced: no piercing highs, no enveloping mids, no muddy/overpowering bass. Every single nuance is represented with pristine clarity, and when people say that you'll hear everything with these headphones, they mean it.To the people worrying about the absence of bass due to these being studio-monitoring headsets, the bass is, without a doubt, there in full presence. If you're used to hearing muddy sounding bass or music drenched in low-end sloppiness, you'll be surprised to hear how warm and how articulately the MDR-7506 reproduces bass, yet still managing to hit the listener with such a convincing punch.The high end is of course a pleasure to listen to. The high notes are crystal clear and do not show any signs of being artificially stressed or represented, giving a very silky smooth sound.As for the midrange? One fear of buying headphones is that you end up with hollow sounding music due to the lack of a solid defined midrange, but the midrange is one more thing to compliment about the 7506's. From prominent male vocals to snares, nothing ever seems overpowered, and yet it manages to fill the space with a full rich sound.Overall, the combination in sound from all the spectrums produces a very unbiased enjoyable harmony to the ears. As I listen to all types of music genres, from ballads to rock, classic to RnB, and pop to techno, I have yet to find a genre that these heaphones fail to reproduce with exceptional fidelity.And did I mention these headphones are very comfortable? I've worn these close to half a day without my ears being fatigued. Many earbuds and headphones have the tendency to make ears hurt/sore after only a short session of listening. I would say I have bigger than normal sized ears and the large-diaphragm design, combined with the very soft leather-wrapped earpads, really helps in making the circumural design (wrapped around the ears as opposed to on top) work well. This also means that sound is sealed off very well, muffling sounds from the outside coming in, and from the music inside getting out. For example, these are the type of headphones you would want to carry with you to public places (bus rides, airplane trips) instead of headphones like the Sennheiser HD595's.Having had these headphones for 1-2 years already, the quality is still as good as when I got them, and I don't doubt that they will be any different for a long long while.Ultimately, with the price tag being conveniently under 100 USD, this is an excellent buy. Even in comparison with higher end headphones, the sound quality for the MDR-7506 is still ranked as the top in my charts, as well as many other people's. If you look closely at professional settings around the world (i.e. studio performances, behind-the-scenes movie sets, & radio stations), as I have started to notice recently, you will see this exact model appear time and time again for a very good reason.Cons:The only con I would like to point out is that the earpads do tend to wear out after prolonged use. Since they are very soft to the skin and thus are made from very fine material, they are subject to wear & tear. Though, replacement earpads are cheap, easy to find, and easy to install. In total, i've only had to replace the earpads once since I got the 7506's, and that's with the headphones going through daily abuse.

review_title: Good Sound, Comfortable Fit, Great Price!
review_body: If you’re looking for a good set of headphones at a reasonable price, look no further than the Sony MDR7506 (or its sibling the MDRV6). I wasted far too much time searching for a good pair of consumer grade headphones in brick & mortar stores before I finally came across these ones here on Amazon, and let me tell you I couldn’t be happier with them.When I first started shopping around for a decent set of replacement headphones, I was looking for something that had a good frequency range, no added bass, comfortable ear pads and a coiled cord at an affordable price. The Sony MDR7506 fits the bill on all counts. The only weak link appears to be the earpads as many have pointed out. The good news is replacement pads are readily available, which is something you can’t say for several other headphones currently on the market.The sound quality on these is really good whether I’m listening to music on my iPod, computer or watching TV thru my amp. And unlike several other headphones I’ve used recently, these ones don’t make my head feel like its been in a vice after only a short period of time wearing them. And although they fold up nicely and come with a travel bag, I bought these specifically for listening around the house. So if you’re in the market for portable headphones, you might want to look elsewhere due to the long coiled cord.Overall I’d highly recommend the MDR7506 to anyone looking for great set of studio monitor headphones at a very reasonable price.

review_body: I purchased the Sony MDR 7506 headphones to use at work.  I have worked parttime in radio for 30 years and have always used cheap headphones.  I thought I would treat myself to a better pair.  These have not disappointed.  Great sound quality, comfortable and block outside sound very well.  I like the fact they fold up nicely and come with their own carrying pouch.  After I bought these I noticed that Bob and Tom use them on the air.  I watched a youtube video of Here Come The Mummies, live in studio, singing on the Bob and Tom show.  They were all using these headphones.  I also own a very nice pair of AKG K271's.  The AKG's are very nice but I think I might like the Sony's just a tad better.  I know I like how the Sony's fit me better.  I truly don't think you will be disappointed in the MDR-7506 headphones.  The knock on Sony headsets is usually the earpads.  I've seen many cheaper pairs and have heard that the pads on these tend to wear quickly.  Go ahead and make the buy.... Then Rock On!

review_title: I found out about this product because I was searching for good studio headphones that were a good price
review_body: The product that I will be reviewing are the Sony MDR7506 Professional Large Diaphragm Headphones. I found out about this product because I was searching for good studio headphones that were a good price. The reason why I wanted to purchase these was because I needed Industry standard headphones for music production. These headphones are ideal for sound monitoring in recording studios, radio, film production, video, and electronic news gatherings. Sony 7500 Series headphones offer a practical range of choices for everyone from the casual user to the studio pro. The headphone type is Dynamic, Closed. The cord length is  9.8 feet. These headphones are also ranked #24 in Musical Instruments.  The reason why these headphones are appealing to people is because they're cheap, have great sound, and comfortable. Usually Industry standard headphones like these are very expensive ranging from 200 to 1000 dollars. This product only costs 90 dollars. This was probably why the Sony MDR7506 headphones are so popular in the music industry and also media industry due to their unbelievable pricing. Another reason why these are so popular is because of the sound. In my opinion the sound frequencies that these headphones deliver are excellent. Compared to consumer headphones such as Beats and Apple headphones, these overkill them. It brings out the clarity and bass from songs. When it comes to buying headphones, comfortability plays a big role for your choice. The ear pads are really comfortable and easy to adapt to various ear sizes.  The main weaknesses of this product is that their sound isn’t the best until you use a amplifier, the cord is too long, and it’s not detachable. Connecting these headphones straight to a computer is okay, but if you can connect it to an amplifier, you can increase the bass and clarity of an audio piece. I haven’t purchased a amplifier yet so I don’t know what these headphones sound like at their full potential. Having a cord that's too long can be a hassle. Usually people use these headphones up close to their computer so you wouldn’t really need a long cord. It sometimes gets annoying.  Overall, these headphones too me are still good. You still receive excellent quality from a headphone that’s very cheap compared to others. Even though it has it’s struggles, the grad i give these is an A. The reason why is because of it’s very good build quality, decent midrange performance, and it’s excel performance at live sound monitoring. I think if any consumer buys these, they would not regret it because these headphones deliver so much at a low price.

review_body: I can't believe so many people are raving about these headphones. I was a faithful buyer of the SONY MDR-V600 headphones for years and years. I absolutely loved them. The sound of them could be loud, clear and  expansive. No tinniest whatsoever. Then someone at SONY made the dumb decision to discontinue them. I was hoping the MDR7506 would be on par with the MDR-V600 but boy was I wrong. The MDR7506 sound way too tinny. You could crank up the volume to no end on the MDR-V600 and they would sound great. The more you crank up the MDR7506 the tinnier sounding they get. If you're into hard rock or heavy metal and like your music loud don't buy these. I was very disappointed. Please Sony, bring back the MDR-V600 over-the-ear headphones and not their so-called replacement.

Also when the earpads wear out, they can shred tiny black flakes onto your head.Brainwavz Hybrid Memory Foam Earpad - Black PU/Velour - Suitable For Large Over The Ear HeadphonesI put these on my Sony MDR-7506 headphones and find them much more comfortable now, with less sweating and more space for my ears. review_title: like zillion of other headphones on the market
review_body: I just bought a new pair of 7506. I have owned another pair for several years. I have a home studio. The reason these have been so popular and hanging around every recording studio for decades is that the reading is flat, analytically neutral, i.e. very close to the original recorded sound. They used to output a balanced sound throughout the frequency spectrum. I say used to, because they don't anymore. My new pair is definitely bass tinted, like zillion of other headphones on the market. Why did Sony do this? Are they using cheap chinese components to save money? Are they trying to reposition this product on the market to reach the bass freak people, which is about 80% of music listeners? I think it is a bad decision for 2 reasons. First, they are going to lose the studio market. Second, you can find lots of cheaper and more confortable bass tinted headphones out there. They could have issued a 7506 ''B'' product, for example, for the bass idiots and kept the pros satisfied, Bad decision, guys...

review_body: These are the headphones you put on to tell which of your favorite songs are actually mixed well. And the included 1/4" adapter actually screws in to place which is dope.Only complaint is that after an hour or two of continued wear they start to feel like they're digging into your skull. No biggie, just take them off for 5 minutes, your ears deserve the break anyway. Gotta suffer for your art sometimes, you know? review_title: Good sound quality but lacking in other areas...
review_body: I bought these for recording music and practicing on my bass (via plugging them into my amp).  All the reviews I read were said they were great and even a friend at a music store said they were the best on the market.Got them today and the first test was listening to some music on my stereo.  They sounded very good and may have been worth the price right there.  Recording was very good with them, all the instruments came out sounding clear.  The deal breaker was when I plugged them into my amp; they produced a horrible feedback that was simply too much to get past.  When I plugged in my old headphone kit (a 5$ pair of Panasonics with a 2$ jack adapter) I noticed that there was NO FEED BACK AT ALL.  Sure the tones did not come out as rich as on the Sony's but that didn't matter when the rich tone was covered up by a great deal of feedback and buzzing.At that point, I immediately decided to send the back for a refund.  They are great headphones but, for 99$, I don't want my 5$ headphones beating them in any areas.  Also, the design seemed a little cheap on them; the wires that connect the ear pieces together are left very much exposed and are just begging to be pulled out.  Again, I have a 30$ pair of Koss that sound like crap but the design is much more stable then these.

review_title: Two years later, still going strong.
review_body: I spent days, sometimes weeks, poring over every piece of hardware I purchase. I want to stay within my means, but get every ounce of performance for my money. At first I was squeamish, as when I bought these (the price was higher at the time) but I am impressed.I am by no means an audiophile, I don't want to hear the loose booger whistling in the guitarist's nose in the song. However, as a person going from cheap Logitech headsets that would break in four weeks, I felt like I had spared no expense in quality.There were undertones, notes, everything I was missing in music I had listened to for years. Games were crisp, the surround sound performance is robust for headphones. Above all, they're comfortable and fit my rather large head. Not long after I bought a pair for my brother. As time wears on I'm ready to pick up a second pair "in case" (though I've had these for about two years and they're still amazing). Highly recommend these to someone wanting some powerful sound but doesn't want to blow their cash on exorbitantly priced headphones.

review_title: Very clean sound - great deal for the price!
review_body: I was looking for <100 headphones with good sound quality that would also be useful when mixing or editing music. These fit the bill exactly.Pros:- High quality music sounds really clean and really good- Very comfortable (for me at least)- Very useful for mixing and editing music (they are the standard after all)Cons:- Cord is pretty long, and since it is coiled it is rather thick, so sometimes it gets in the way- You can hear every mistake in the music, so if the recording is of bad quality it emphasizes what is bad (note: this is great for mixing music or editing music, but not great for just easy listening)In the end the headphones were exactly what I was looking for and the cord being too long is not close to a big issue, and definitely not worth taking a star off for.

review_title: Great headphones if you want to hear exactly what the source material sounds like.
review_body: Updated review:I am updating this review based on the replacement set I received today.  See the originally posted version at the bottom for details.If you're looking at this review, it means you're probably looking for high quality neutral sounding headphones  If you're looking for overemphasized bass, there's always Beats by Dre.  But if you want/need to hear the music as it was originally recorded/mixed then these are the phones you want.  These are very neutral headphones designed for hearing the any flaws in the signal.There's a reason that these are #1 on the DJ Headphones list.For reference, when you add these headphones to your cart Amazon will recommend a 8 inch headphone case.  This case is very roomy and fits the headphones fine.  However, these headphones are collapsible.  I chose a case designed for collapsible phones (the SLAPPA SL-HP-01).  It's significantly more compact and is the minimum size to hold these headphones.  I did a review of it separately.These headphones have an impedance of 63 ohms, which can make them a difficult load for some portable devices.  I purchased the FiiO E06 Fujiyama headphone amplifier which is about the size of a book of matches.  It's currently rated #1 on the Headphone Amplifier list.  Again, I reviewed it separately.As expected, these headphones are great.  The sound quality is excellent, with smooth response and good clean sound. Very highly recommended if you want neutral sound.Original review of initially received pair:This is a temporary review, while I am waiting for a replacement headphone from Amazon.I've had a pair of MDR V6 headphones since 1987, and they've been awesome.  However, years of use on board submarines have taken a toll.  I recently replaced the cushions, but the headband was going to cost almost as much as a new pair.  While looking for a new pair, I found the MDR7506 was on sale for the same price so I ordered them.  While researching, I discovered that these headphones are commonly counterfeit.  I watched some unboxing videos on Youtube which showed what to look for and expect when receiving a new pair of MDR V6 or MDR7506.I received the headphones today.  While unboxing, I was saddened to find that the headphones had been previously used.  The cable should have been in a clear plastic bag with yellow tape closure.  Instead the cord was stretched and kinked in several placed, and was unbagged.  The black pouch, which should have been folded in quarters, was laying flat in the bottom of the box.  The pouch still has crease marks from being previously folded.  On the back of the right earcup, there's a dried residue of what looks like sweat or some other liquid.  The warranty card is missing.In short, someone opened these, used them for a while, and then put them back into the box. If the cable were unkinked, I'd probably just keep these.  Since I want (and paid for) a pristine pair, I notified Amazon for an exchange.  The replacement pair should arrive tomorrow. I will update this review based on the replacement pair.  It'll probably be a 5 star, since I really like the sound of this series of headphones.

review_body: I read a LOT of the reviews and comparisons and a lot of them saying to save yourself a few bucks because the MDR-V6 is exactly the same as the MDR7506. NOT! Let's cut to the car chase... I've been recording my own music since the early 80's. Way back when I tried several different headphones and settled upon the MDR7506, hands down.Recently, after years of use I decided to get another pair. Actually, I don't NEED them as this original pair is still kicking! However, I tried the MDR-V6 and a new MDR7506 and according to my ears there IS a difference. A BIG difference to me. Mostly to me mid-range frequencies are not nearly as clear, they are too muddy.You can't go wrong paying an extra $20 - $30 for the MDR7506.Of course, this is my opinion. review_body: These headphones only sound "O.K.", which is why I gave them three stars.  (4 stars is "Great", and 5 stars is "Outstanding").  The low bass is good, but the mid-bass is lacking.  The midrange and high-end are  slightly exaggerated and strident.  Cymbals are unnaturally bright, and the spoken/sung "S" letter has too much sibilance in some cases.  I have been comparing these headphones with my pair of MDR-V900 headphones.  Although the mid-bass of the MDR-V900 is a little muddy compared to these headphones, they don't have the high-midrange to high-end over-exaggeration that the MDR-7506 headphones.These headphones are a decent value, but are not better than "O.K.".  They are adequate for general use.  I bought them for my 10 year-old daughter's use with her first MP3 player (a Sansa Fuze).  They are wildly better than the earphones I see so many people using.If you want "great" to "outstanding" headphones, you are well advised to look elsewhere.
